PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator D. J. Hamer) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Sex Discrimination Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including the moral development of their children.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 84 citizens) and Harradine (from 106 citizens ).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Button (from 17 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 60 citizens) and Collard (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BAUME; BUTTON; CARRICK; CHANEY; HARRADINE; SIBRAA
PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc. for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 42 citizens), Button (from 45 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 614 citizens), Chaney (from 99 citizens), Harradine (from 111 citizens) and Sibraa (from 52 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
(1) Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

(2) Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
(3) Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

(4) Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 71 citizens), Harradine (from 17 citizens), Peter Rae ( from 30 citizens), and Walters (from 234 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Cadet Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Cadet Corps has great value in the development of youth in the schools of Australia.
That the reorganisation of the Australian Cadet Corps will disperse accummulated expertise and interest of those involved, and in some cases negate the efforts of many people over many years.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reconsider its decision and that the Government will not reorganise the Australian Cadet Corps.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia, being parents and other persons concerned about the education of all children, showeth that the present Government has commenced a policy of reduction and eventual abolition in Government funding to independent schools. This policy has been adopted without an appropriate and reasoned consideration of the circumstances of those schools and the parents who choose to send their children to them. In particular the Government, in making its decision, has failed to take into account the impact on the state school system of an increased enrolment of students who otherwise would have attended independent schools in the event that Government funding had not been reduced or abolished. The change in policy overlooks the fact that the cost of educating a child in a government school is two to three times the cost to the tax-payer of educating the same child in an independent school.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled reverse the decision of the Government and re-instate funding on an equitable basis as has been the case in previous years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every child in Australia is entitled to government financial support for their education whether they attend government schools or non-government schools .

You petitioners therefore humbly pray that urgent consideration be given to a favourable decision for the continuation of Federal Government per capita grants payable in respect of all children in non-government schools at a rate calculated as a percentage of government standard costs at a level not less than that prevailing in 1983.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the senators of the Senate of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. A Bill is now pending in your honourable House entitled ''A Bill for An Act relating to discrimination on the ground of sex, marital status or pregnancy or involving sexual harassment.''

2. Your petitioners say that the effects of certain provisions of the Bill if enacted into law will be to enable persons to coerce women to engage in paid employment, and to surrender the care of their children to child care institutions, to grant rights to foreign persons upon a United Nations Commission to enter upon Australian Territory with powers to inspect, investigate and to seek to influence, to report and recommend, with the object of procuring total employment of Australian women, and that all of these things will lead to the elimination of the traditional family unit.

3. That your petitioners say that the Bill if passed into law as it now stands will be insulting to the women of Australia, harmful to our families, and a grievous interference with the freedom of the Australian citizens.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Bill may not be allowed to pass into law as it now stands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSFER OF PRISONERS BILL 1983TRANSFER OF PRISONERS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Ordered that the Bills may be taken through all their stages without delay.
Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TRANSFER OF PRISONERS BILL 1983

The Transfer of Prisoners Bill has evolved as a result of agreement by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General to introduce a legislative scheme to permit the transfer of prisoners between the various Australian jurisdictions for welfare purposes or trial.

State and Northern Territory legislation will deal with the transfer of prisoners serving sentences of imprisonment for offences against State or Northern Territory laws. The Transfer of Prisoners Bill will deal with the transfer of prisoners serving sentences of imprisonment for offences against Commonwealth laws and prisoners serving sentences of imprisonment for offences against the laws of the Australian Capital Territory, Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and Cocos (Keeling) Islands.

As I have indicated prisoners may be transferred for the purposes of welfare or trial. The transfer of prisoners for welfare purposes will assist the rehabilitation of prisoners and minimise the hardship caused to the families of prisoners. Procedures for this type of transfer are to be initiated by written application of the prisoner to the Commonwealth Attorney-General. The Attorney- General may make an order for the transfer of a ''Commonwealth'' prisoner from one State or Territory to another if the appropriate minister in the receiving jurisdiction consents and the Attorney-General considers that the transfer would be in the interests of the administration of justice and the welfare of the prisoner. It should be noted that these two considerations are not exclusive and that the Attorney-General may accordingly consider any other relevant matter in exercising his discretion.

The transfer of prisoners for the purposes of trial will remedy a deficiency in Australian law which prevents a prisoner being moved from one jurisdiction to another to stand trial until he has served his prison term in the first jurisdiction. If the prison term in the first jurisdiction is a lengthy one there are obvious difficulties for the prosecution. Such transfers will accordingly benefit the administration of justice within Australia. It will also be of benefit to prisoners who are anxious to have all outstanding charges in different jurisdictions dealt with rather than serve a sentence in one jurisdiction and thereafter be extradited to another jurisdiction.

Procedures for this type of transfer depend on whether the charge in respect of which the prisoner is to be transferred is a Federal or Territory charge or a State charge. Where the charge is a Federal or Territory charge the Commonwealth Attorney-General may, either of his own motion or at the request of the prisoner apply to a court of summary jurisdiction in the jurisdiction in which the prisoner is imprisoned for an order transferring the prisoner to the other State or Territory. That application shall not be made unless the appropriate Minister in the receiving jurisdiction consents. Where the charge is a State charge, the application is made by the appropriate State Minister, either of his own motion or at the request of the prisoner and the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth must consent.

The court of summary jurisdiction is obliged to make an order of transfer unless it considers that the charge is trivial, the application has not been made in the interests of justice, the transfer would prejudice the conduct of proceedings to which the prisoner is a party or it would be unjust to grant the application.
The decision of a court of summary jurisdiction is reviewable by the Supreme Court.

The Bill must of necessity deal with various technical matters relating to the status of prisoners who are transferred, the effect of the transfer on the sentence or imprisonment, and the procedures for returning prisoners, transferred for trial, to the original jurisdiction.

To simplify release procedures Territory prisoners who are transferred become prisoners of the jurisdiction to which they are transferred. Thus, an A.C.T. prisoner who is transferred to Queensland will become a Queensland prisoner. This change of status is not necessary in respect of Federal prisoners who will continue to be housed in State gaols throughout Australia as Federal prisoners. To change their status if they were transferred would only complicate release procedures as such prisoners are released pursuant to Commonwealth law.

As far as the sentence of imprisonment is concerned the broad effect is that once a prisoner is transferred the sentence imposed in the first jurisdiction is deemed for all purposes, including the exercise of the royal prerogative, remissions and release on parole, to have been imposed in the jurisdiction to which he has been transferred. Remissions earnt and non-parole periods fixed in the original jurisdiction are applied in the receiving jurisdiction.

Where a prisoner is transferred from jurisdiction 'A' to jurisdiction 'B' for trial there is provision for his transfer back to jurisdiction 'A' if he does not receive any sentence in jurisdiction 'B' or a sentence shorter than the unserved balance of the sentence applicable in jurisdiction 'A'.

The costs which will have to be borne by the Commonwealth as a result of enactment of this legislation are not substantial. The Commonwealth will have to bear the travelling costs of Federal and Territory offenders transferred for welfare purposes and all offenders who are transferred to answer Commonwealth or Territory changes. Existing arrangements provide for the Commonwealth to bear the cost of housing Territory prisoners and the States to bear the cost of housing Federal prisoners. The Commonwealth will not incur any additional costs with respect to the housing of prisoners because of this Legislation. It is estimated that about 10-15 Federal and Territory prisoners will be transferred per annum with the likelihood of more prisoners seeking transfer this financial year than in subsequent years. The Travelling costs of transferring prisoners under escort should average out at approximately $1000 per prisoner transferred.

The introduction of these Bills represents the Commonwealth's contribution to a legislative scheme which will greatly benefit the system of administration of justice within Australia, assist the rehabilitation of prisoners, and reduce the hardships suffered by the members of prisoners' families.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TRANSFER OF PRISONERS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

This Bill is necessary to resolve possible conflict between the Transfer of Prisoners Bill and other Commonwealth legislation which authorises the removal of prisoners. The Removal of Prisoners (Australian Capital Territory) Act 1968 and The Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act 1923 authorise the removal of prisoners from the Australian Capital Territory and the other territories, including the Northern Territory, respectively, and, in certain circumstanes their return. Since the Transfer of Prisoners Bill will also authorise the transfer of prisoners, there is the possibility of conflict between that Bill and these two Acts.

Because of the difficulty in identifying the circumstances in which a removal Act should be used rather than the transfer legislation, and vice versa, the Bill provides for the Commonwealth Attorney-General to make a choice of the appropriate law according to the circumstances of each individual case. In addition it should be noted that The Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act will be amended by the Bill to no longer apply to transfers from the Northern Territory. This amendment has been requested by the Northern Territory and henceforth all transfers from the Northern Territory will be dealt with by the Northern Territory transfer of prisoners legislation.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES (WORKS AND HOUSING) ASSISTANCE BILL 1983NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANT (SPECIAL ASSISTANCE) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 November 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senators who have taken part in this debate. I, like them, do not wish to delay the passage of this legislation. I certainly do not want to enter into the internecine dispute which was exemplified by Senator Kilgariff's half- hour burst yesterday afternoon against the honourable member for the Northern Territory, Mr Reeves. I note that Senator Kilgariff expressed some concern at the time that there was a review of assistance to the Northern Territory but I point out to Senator Kilgariff that this review is part of the normal process which takes place in considering financial assistance between the Commonwealth and the various States and Territories. If, as Senator Kilgariff says, everything is so fine and well in the Northern Territory and that the Northern Territory Government is acting in the way that he claims it has acted-I would need more proof than the tabling of a few Press statements from the Treasurer of the Northern Territory and a few signed documents from public servants from the Northern Territory to be convinced of that-surely he should not have any concerns about the normal review processes taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: I found some difficulty understanding the logic and the approach of both Senator Messner and Senator Sir John Carrick in their speeches last night. It seems to me that both honourable senators complained bitterly that the present Government, as I heard it, was spending too much in this form of assistance to the housing industry in this community. Senator Sir John Carrick suggested that this would not create sufficient jobs. He suggested that the best way to create jobs was to continue with the bicentennial water scheme which he, as a Minister, had something to do with, which would have involved $70m in the next few years and which somehow or other apparently was more labour-intensive than the housing industry in this community. That is something that I do not understand. What we faced as a government was the fact that the housing industry last year was at a record low; under the previous Government it was at a record low. If one wanted an example of an industry in recession one looked at the housing and building industry generally last year.

In the light of Senator Sir John Carrick's speech yesterday we must also ask where the previous Government was going to perform the economic magic of carrying out all the capital works it intended to carry out and, at the same time, reducing the expenditure in the way Senator Sir John Carrick apparently believed it should be reduced. Senator Messner similarly took the approach that in fact we should spend more on large capital works and, at the same time, reduce government expenditure and reduce taxation, something which I find very difficult to understand but, I suppose, it is easy enough to say that sort of thing from the Opposition benches.

Both Senator Messner and, I believe, Senator Kilgariff, talked about the Alice Springs-Darwin railway link. They talked about the importance, as they saw it, of this project to the Northern Territory. Senator Messner in particular talked about its importance in the whole Australian job scene. But again, we are talking about a project which would cost some $600m and which would have needed a subsidy in excess of $1m each year to run. We have made an offer to the Northern Territory. We have said to the Northern Territory Government that if it has the great conviction that it claims to have that the railway line should be built and if it insists on proceeding with it the Northern Territory Government should make some contribution towards its construction. The Northern Territory Government cannot expect the Commonwealth to fund both a railway and a road without any contribution from the Northern Territory. We will see what the Northern Territory Government has to say about that.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, I do not believe this legislation should be delayed. I believe it is an important part of the Budget. It is an important part of our attempt to increase the number of jobs and to increase them in those industries where there is the greatest spin-off. The simple fact of the matter is that in seasonally adjusted terms in the last few months there has been an increase of 80,000 in the number of jobs available in this community . The simple fact of the matter is that we said at the time of the May statement , before that statement and at the time of the Budget that we did not expect a sudden decrease in the number of people unemployed. We accepted and the community accepted that that was so and that the Government could not suddenly turn around the unemployment figures in the way that Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Messner apparently believe is possible but was never possible when they were in government.

Finally, I make the point that in the last couple of months there has been a decrease-the figure has decreased to 602,000-in the number of people receiving the unemployment benefit. Our Budget prediction was that on average 600,000 people would be receiving the unemployment benefit this year. Neither I nor anyone in the Government is claiming that that decrease is anything more than a return to the normal pattern of unemployment beneficiaries throughout the year. But even that, in itself, is a considerable achievement, considering that last year from May through to December there was an absolute skyrocketing of the number of people on unemployment benefit resulting in almost a doubling of the number. The fact that we have had a decrease in recent months and the fact that the pattern is, maybe, at least returning to the pattern of previous years and may constitute a greater decrease than there was in recent years demonstrate some hope that the unemployment levels themselves are steadying out.

I point out that the number of people on unemployment benefit is an absolute figure; it is not a survey figure, as are the other figures that are frequently quoted around this place. If the figure continues as it is, our estimates are that the amount of money needed for unemployment benefit this year will be considerably lower than the Treasurer (Mr Keating) predicted in the Budget. That will also be a good thing for this country, this Government and the budgetary implications generally. I believe that there is no need for the gloom and doom that we have heard from those opposite during this debate.

I shall seek answers to the couple of specific questions raised by Senator Kilgariff. I would have thought that if he spent more of his time working on the positive aspects of what can be done in the Northern Territory rather than spending every speech in this place condemning the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves)--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so pompous and condescending. That is a ridiculous statement.

—For Senator Walters to accuse anyone of being condescending in this place is the greatest example of Satan condemning sin that could be demonstrated. I merely make the factual point that Senator Kilgariff never rises to his feet in this place without spending half of his speech attacking the member for the Northern Territory. If he wants to do that instead of taking up positive aspects, that is fair enough. For Senator Sir John Carrick to complain about anyone attacking anyone else in this place is absolutely outrageous. He is always very keen to bucket people in this place, but he does not like it when he gets the same back in kind.
—Never on a personal character basis.
—'Never on a personal basis'. What Senator Sir John Carrick does in this place is to take the coward's way out. He collectively blackguards people, but he never does it on an individual basis.
—Never on a personal basis.

—I will follow it on an individual basis. I will respond to that sort of tactic of Senator Sir John Carrick by taking it on on a personal basis, as I have in the past. The trouble is that he gets up and whinges when he gets it back; he whinges and screams in this place. We need to take a more positive approach in debates such as this. If we are to have whingeing from the back benchers on the other side, we can. They will not be here for very long. Their time has run out. I thank those honourable senators who have taken a positive approach to this legislation. I hope that in future in the area of Commonwealth- State co-operation we shall continue as we have started, making positive approaches to assist in the areas of housing and of assistance to the Northern Territory in a way which will have positive effects on not only employment prospects but also the economic prospects of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With some concern, I draw the attention of the Government and the Committee to clause 9 of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill 1983, on which I would like to have the comments of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). I will read through at least the first few lines of the clause to make the point. Sub-clause (1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer may, during the period of 6 months commencing on 1 July 1984, make payments to a State specified in column 1 of the Schedule, for the purpose of financial assistance for expenditure . . .

The point I make is that this Bill appears to authorise expenditure in a year other than this Budget year which we are currently examining, and apparently authorises expenditure out of the next financial year for which no budget, as far as I know, has been considered by the Government or indeed by the Parliament . It seems to me an unusual procedure for expenditures to be authorised in this fashion. I do not know why it is deemed necessary to have this kind of clause in a Bill like this, although I can imagine that there may well be projects which flow over from one year to another. The point that I make is that quite clearly in the Schedule there is a ceiling figure authorised, some $489m, by virtue of this Bill for expenditure out of the next financial year's Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer-I certainly am the last person to claim expertise in this area-is this: From my reading of the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill-there are similar provisions in the other piece of legislation that we are examining-it is a long-standing arrangement which enables the Commonwealth, by agreement with the States, to make payments and to arrange the level of payments for the next financial year as a result of negotiations this year. I do not think what Senator Messner has brought up is any different from the procedures which have taken place in other years, from my memory. I will certainly seek further details as to the accuracy of that statement. We need to allow advance payments for arrangements for 1984-85. The inclusion of clause 9 is a contingency to allow for the possible continuation in 1984-85 of arrangements similar to those provided by this Bill in relation to 1983-84. It provides for that continuity and for the sort of planning of which I would have thought Senator Messner was in favour. Sub-clause (1) authorises the Treasurer to make payments to the States of nominated amounts during the first six months of 1984-85 up to the limit of the borrowing element of their 1983-84 Loan Council program to provide that flexibility and continuity. I do not know how that can be done without making arrangements like this and I do not think that the amounts involved will be destructive of any future Budget. I believe that that procedure has gone on in the past. I would be open to correction if it has not.

—I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for his reply. In my remarks I did acknowledge the point that he has made that there would obviously be some need for provision of on-going funds in the event of a project running beyond the end of this financial year. However, it strikes me as rather odd that this Bill authorises expenditure out of a future year's Budget rather than this year's Budget. I make that point merely as one of financial control and the control of the Parliament over the expenditure of moneys by the Government. Although I acknowledge the point that the Minister has made, I am not convinced that this kind of thing is necessary in legislation of this kind because, as the Minister has acknowledged, there certainly is some kind of contractual arrangement or obligation on the part of the Commonwealth to meet its financial commitments in the year ahead in relation to the States and the Northern Territory, that being the purpose of this Bill. But I think that is a different question from the authority for allocating finance up to a certain definite amount of $489m out of next year's Budget. I would like to draw that point to the attention of the Government and ask the Minister to examine the question and bring down his reply later for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly do that, although I must point out to Senator Messner that in other areas such as my own Department-I do not know about his old Department-forward commitments are made, albeit the volume of money is less. I refer particularly to the funding of aged persons accommodation and the like, where such a provision allows departments to plan ahead. I would not have thought that this situation was so different, except for the volume of money. The clause that we are talking about allows for advances for nominated funds should the Government decide that the arrangements will continue. I think it is a mechanical provision designed to overcome difficulties that have been experienced in making payments to the States this year. But I accept Senator Messner's point that we are making commitments for a Budget a year ahead. I will seek further details from the Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.
