Debate resumed from 7 September 1983 on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Migration Amendment Bill and the Migration (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill. I intend to confine my remarks to the Migration Amendment Bill 1983. The Opposition is not opposing either of these Bills. However, as would be very well known, in the House of Representatives an amendment was moved to the Migration Amendment Bill which I give notice that I shall move in the Committee stage. There was a full debate on the Bill in the House of Representatives. It is not our intention to recanvass all the issues of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I state briefly the Opposition's attitude towards the amendments to the Migration Act that are contained in the Migration Amendment Bill. The first and very important amendment-one which the Opposition supports-is designed to remove the distinction that has existed in the past in the Migration Act between the terms 'alien' and 'immigrant'. An alien was someone who came here from a non- Commonwealth country. The term 'immigrant' applied to someone from a Commonwealth country. That distinction is removed by these amendments and people previously referred to as either aliens or immigrants will now be referred to as non-citizens. As clearly as possible I say that the Opposition has no objection to, and, in fact, supports that change. There was some confusion in the House of Representatives when other issues in the Bill were being debated. Some Government members did not understand that the Opposition was not opposing that change.

The second aspect of the Bill is a restriction on the right of the Minister in relation to deportation. During the election campaign the Australian Labor Party gave several undertakings in relation to deportation and the Opposition accepts that it has a right to fulfil those undertakings. It basically eliminates the deportation power of the Minister over a non-citizen who has had 10 years residence in Australia. However, it also defines in a different way the grounds for deportation of a non-citizen by the Minister. People may wish to criticise the previous grounds but the fact is that they will be replaced by new sections and new grounds. Our main criticism of this new provision is that we believe that the Government is being too restrictive on itself. The point was made at length in debate in the House of Representatives, and I will make it only briefly here that in defining grounds for deportation the Migration Amendment Bill provides, in broad outline, for deportation of non-citizens present in Australia for less than 10 years who are convicted of crimes where the offence is an offence for which the person was sentenced to death or to imprisonment for life or for a period of not less than one year. Because that is so restrictive a number of anomalies could arise. It has been pointed out that not very many States have the death penalty any more; so that is a provision that is becoming less likely to apply. Life imprisonment is most likely to be given as a penalty for murder. However, in regard to the third section-the period of not less than one year of imprisonment-while one accepts that the Government does not mean that provision to apply in petty or trivial circumstances, nevertheless it is possible to have a habitual offender against the law who at no stage actually receives a single sentence of one year. So we could have an anomaly where an individual who receives a sentence for a crime of one year is liable to deportation and another individual who has received over a period a number of convictions and a number of sentences, each of them for less than one year, who in toto may serve in prison a substantial period of time, is not liable for deportation under this Bill. That criticism has been made and it may be that the Government could look at tidying up that part of the Bill.

The more serious criticism we have relates to the deportation of non-citizens upon security grounds. Clause 11 of the Bill amends section 14 of the Migration Act and specifies that certain sections of the Crimes Act will become grounds for consideration of deportation. Those sections are section 24, which relates to treason; section 24AA, which relates to treachery; section 24AB, which relates to sabotage; section 24C, which relates to certain kinds of sedition; section 25, which relates to inciting munity; and section 26, which relates to assisting prisoners of war to escape. In being so restrictive the Government has almost got itself into a nonsense situation. In fact, those offences specified from the Crimes Act are offences for which there has either never been a conviction in Australia or for which there have been very few convictions. The likelihood of people being convicted of treason, treachery, inciting mutiny- which has never carried a conviction in this Commonwealth-or assisting prisoners of war to escape is very remote.

On the other hand, the Government seems to have overlooked certain other sections of the Crimes Act which one would think would be rather more likely to apply. In debate in the House of Representatives it was pointed out that, for example, one could reasonably expect offences under section 78 of the Crimes Act , which relates to espionage and similar activities, to be a little more likely to occur, as would offences under section 81, which relates to harbouring spies. When the Government made its decision to pick out sections of the Crimes Act one assumes that it would have made a deliberate decision. It is hard to understand why it would pick out in section 24, to which I have referred, crimes which are highly unlikely to be committed but ignore the sections 78 and 81.

The Opposition approached this matter in debate in the House of Representatives on the basis that it was an oversight, but apparently it was unable, through debate-I have read the record of the debate very thoroughly-to penetrate this point to the Government. The Opposition pointed out that other sections of the Crimes Act, which one would expect the Government to consider very seriously, are not covered in this provision of the amending Act. Therefore, the Opposition moved to amend the Bill-as we shall move at the Committee stage-in very broad terms to cover the sorts of offences which I have mentioned and some others. We wish to make the point that whilst the Government has deliberately set out to restrict the basis for deportation-that is its choice-we think it has gone too far and it may regret having gone as far as it has in its restrictiveness. I think there are people who would agree that there are types of offences which could be committed by non-citizens which would indicate that the person involved is somebody who we would not want to have as a member of the Australian community.

The subject will be debated in more detail at the Committee stage. I state it at this stage in order to give the Government the opportunity to respond at the second reading stage, in whatever general terms it sees fit, to the general criticism which was made in the House of Representatives and which, frankly, was not responded to by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West). The Minister sought either to misunderstand or misrepresent the Opposition's view in relation to the alien immigration section, which I reiterate we are not opposing. In relation to the specific amendment the Minister merely said that the Government had the numbers. That was about as much interest as he had in the actual amendment. I hope that in response to debate in the Senate the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes), who represents the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, will take this matter a little more seriously and will be able to explain better to the Parliament why the Government would seek overly to restrict itself in this way and why it would find a distinction between the sections in the Crimes Act which are specified in the amendment Bill and the sections to which I have referred, namely, sections 78 and 81.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two migration Bills cognately. There are two principal matters involved in the Bills. One is to remove distinctions between various non-citizens of Australia, which have operated to this point, so that non-citizens are treated alike. Secondly, there is no longer to be a distinction between Commonwealth citizens, who are not citizens of Australia, and persons of other nationality, who are otherwise called aliens, persons of Irish nationality, for whom some special category existed in the past, and protected persons, that is, persons from former colonies of Australia. Those persons, all of whom are non-citizens of Australia, will by this amendment be treated alike as non-citizens. In this respect there is bipartisan support in the Senate and in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike earlier generations in Australia when these sub-categories of distinctions were important, it is mature, reasonable and reflects public opinion in Australia for us to not have discrimination between persons who have the capability-it does not matter from which country they originate-to become full citizens of Australia. In the process of a person becoming a full citizen of Australia, whether that person comes here as a visitor or as a permanent resident with the appropriate visa to remain in this country-in most cases such a person would go on to become a citizen of Australia-we ought not to distinguish between a person coming from Britain, the Commonwealth countries, Ireland, former colonies of Australia and other countries. They are all alike. In the two most recent decades they have been given the opportunity to become good Australian citizens and genuinely part of this country and we ought not in this preliminary way to discriminate between them.

Australia has had and continues to have special relationships with various parts of the world. We talk about Australia having a special relationship with its immediate neighbours in the South Pacific and South East Asia. This is true. However, I do not think that this relationship should move us to create a distinction in terms of our Migration Act by making it easier under law for people from countries that have a special relationship with Australia to be given some special migration status in respect of entry visas. Nor should there be any special migration status for those coming from the United Kingdom or Ireland, places from which the majority of people have come over the last two centuries. We recognise and we are proud of that part of Australia's cultural heritage. But notwithstanding the special relationship we have traditionally had with the peoples from the United Kingdom and Ireland, we can no longer discriminate under the Migration Act and give them special status. In the same way, we can say that New Guinea has a special relationship with Australia. As a nation, we were responsible for the government of Papua New Guinea throughout most of this century. We sought to give the people of Papua New Guinea the opportunity to conduct their own independent government and become a nation of the world. This has happened. We have strong, close and almost kinship links with that former colony of Australia. But, again, that is no longer any argument that the people of Papua New Guinea should be given a special migration status.

It is undoubtedly true that people from every part of the world have made their homes in Australia. Some of these people have been refugees. Some have come to fulfil their own aspirations to settle in a new country. Some have come to escape from poverty of their original country or a suffocating class structure. They have come because of the idealism we have tried to express and show as able to be achieved in Australia.

I think we are now in a reasonable and mature way removing the distinctions that would advantage, in favour of or give a special migration status to discriminate people from countries, whether they be in Asia or Europe, which have had a special relationship with Australia. Therefore, I say again that there is bipartisan support for that part of the legislation before us that relates to citizens and non-citizens. There is only a transitional group-that is , persons from all national backgrounds who, although permanent residents of Australia, are not citizens. To the extent that they are permanently resident in Australia they are regarded as being part of our country and are put in a special category for visa status purposes. We are now removing the notion of an alien, of a protected person and of any special status given to British subjects or to Irish citizens.

Whilst there is bipartisan support for the major part of the amendments, we ought not to assume falsely that this means that in Australia's foreign policy we will no longer have special relationships in the world. In our immigration procedures, by this amendment to the Migration Act, we will no longer make category distinctions and discriminations between persons who would be excellent Australian citizens. We will not discriminate against them by way of category distinctions. We are not dealing with individual persons in our foreign policy, but we are dealing with national interests, with countries and with regions.

I urge the Government most strongly to maintain our special and quite discriminating relationship with the Commonwealth. Australia is part of the Commonwealth. We should co-operate with other members of the Commonwealth in our foreign policy to achieve peace in a special way in troubled periods in Commonwealth countries. We should seek to help each other and uphold the interests of the Commonwealth against those of other parts of the world. Similarly in our foreign policy we will discern a difference between countries in our region such as the countries which are members of the Association of South East Asian Nations, the countries of the South Pacific and Papua New Guinea. We direct most of our development assistance and overseas aid to those parts of the world. We should continue to do so. We should be quite discerning and discriminating about Australia's national interest and about our regional interest to assist in the development of our closest neighbours. So no false assumption should be inferred from these amendments to the Migration Act which remove discrimination between individuals of different national origins in coming to Australia that the Bill in any way removes any of our foundation approaches to foreign policy.

I turn now to the second matter of substance in the Bills before us. This matter concerns the removal of the power of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with regard to deportation of offenders who are not citizens of Australia but for whom, in the protection of Australian citizens, a case could be made for their deportation. This Bill is unwise and overreaching because it removes the proper discretion from the Minister. The Government is binding itself by this law not to have freedom of action to protect the citizens of Australia. Australians should be alerted by the fact that this Government is throwing away part of its sovereign responsibility as the elected government of Australia to protect the citizens of Australia. It has done so out of, I think, some perverted sense of civil liberties. The case put by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) in the other place was that anyone who has lived in Australia for 10 years ought to feel that he is home and hosed and that he is above being deported from Australia whatever offence he commits against the citizens of Australia.

I think that is a perverted sense of civil liberties. The Minister has always had the ability properly to weigh up the situation, take advice, hear directly the views of the person to be deported and make a judgment that takes into consideration the rights of that individual and his family. He has been able to weigh up the individual's civil liberties against the offence and make a judgment as to whether it is appropriate for him to be deported. But that discretion, by this legislation, is to be removed. The Minister will not be able to make that judgment, to weigh up the evidence in respect of persons who have been permanent residents of Australia for 10 years. So it is clause 11 of the Migration Amendment Bill 1983 which is offensive to us in the Opposition. Even now we urge the Government to reconsider that and to accept the amendment that we will be moving in the Committee stage. I give notice that we will move that in clause 11 we insert the following new sub-section:

'' '(1A) Where a person who is a non-citizen has either before or after the commencement of this sub-section been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs, or has been convicted in Australia of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years, the Minister may, subject to this section, order the deportation of the person'.''.

We want to add to the Government's proposed highly restricted list of grounds for the deportation of a non-citizen who has been a permanent resident here for 10 years. That highly restricted list refers only to treason, treachery, sabotage, seditious acts, inciting mutiny or assisting prisoners of war to escape. To that restricted set of very rare but very serious offences against the citizens of Australia, we want to see added two categories. The first is trafficking in dangerous drugs. Who can doubt that the citizens of Australia are concerned at the offences committed against them, their families and their communities by those murderers who traffic in drugs? If the Government, by its measure, is washing its hands on the grounds of some perverted sense of civil liberties for such offenders and saying that it should not make a judgment as to whether to deport such non-citizens of Australia, its action is without foundation or popular support. I believe Australians are concerned about those who traffic in dangerous drugs. There ought to remain in the Migration Act provision for the Minister to make a judgment after weighing up the various aspects of the case. If it is in the best interests of Australia and not grossly offensive to the individual and his family, I believe the Minister ought to be able to make the judgment that that person should be deported from Australia.

The other category which we seek to have added would cover a person who had been sentenced for a serious crime. We judge the meaning of 'serious crime' to be a crime which attracts imprisonment for a period of not less than five years. The Minister ought to be able to make the judgment to deport such a person from Australia if he is a non-citizen and only a permanent resident. As a result of this Government's proposal a man who has been a permanent resident in Australia for 10 years, notwithstanding his offence against the citizens of Australia, may assume that he is home and hosed, that the Government cannot touch him, that he cannot be deported. For any organised crime, drug trafficking or any other serious offence a person can serve a sentence, perhaps reduced on appeal, and then go on with his former associations. I believe the Minister ought to have the power, as he has had in recent years, to make a judgment in these matters. So in this the second of the most substantial parts of these Bills before the Senate the Opposition is resolutely opposed to the Minister tying himself and cutting out the ability to make a judgment. In the Committee stage I hope that we can persuade a majority of honourable senators and see the Opposition amendment brought into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that the Opposition, as in the other place, is not basically opposing the Migration Amendment Bill and the Migration (Miscellaneous Amendment) Bill. What the Government is trying to do with this legislation, and I believe is doing, is tidying up and, as Senator Teague said, bringing into a modern form legislation which deals with what were previously described as aliens and the various migrant groups in the community. I can appreciate Senator Teagure's capacity for putting up straw men and knocking them down but he said that under our foreign policy we will have certain relationships with other countries, for example, special relationships with countries such as Papua New Guinea, a former colony of ours, and other members of the Commonwealth and that no-one should believe that this legislation will reflect on that policy. I just make the point to him that this is a migration Bill and it is under the auspices of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West). As far as I know, there is no suggestion in any speech by any member of this side of the House or any member of the other side of the House, apart from Senator Teague, that this legislation has anything to do with our relationships with other countries. This is to do with the treatment of people who are non-citizens but permanent residents in this country. If he wants to come in here and try to sow some suspicion in the minds of people outside that in doing this we are somehow altering our approach to foreign affairs, he can do it. He does it on legislation regularly. I remember he did the same thing with the Overseas Students Charge Act. I put it to the Senate that it demonstrates a lack of responsibility, but I suppose we will have to put up with that in every speech.
—I was not making any such suggestion.

—Of course the honourable senator was. He was putting up straw men and knocking them down, the way he always does, but we can put up with that. Let me come to a second point which I believe is important. I only wish that Senator Baume had been in the chamber to hear Senator Teague's remarks-I exclude Senator Martin's remarks-on the problem facing those Ministers who have to deal with drug offenders. When Senator Baume and I were on the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare he was very keen on saying-and, as far as I know, is still keen on saying-that the biggest drug problem in this country was the perception of the drug problem. People such as Senator Teague who speak in this way, feeding off the justified fears of various people in an irresponsible way-I suggest with respect that they have not done it with any sinister intent-are committing the same offence in proposing the amendment the Opposition has put forward. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a person who is a non-citizen has either before or after the commencement of this sub-section been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs-

What is a dangerous drug? No attempt was made by Senator Teague to define this. The six States and two Territories of Australia all have different pieces of legislation. They all have different concepts of what a dangerous drug is. If we go to Queensland, Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen would quite happily gaol people for 10, 15 or 20 years for trafficking in cannabis. In other States, people would not take that view. The Opposition comes into the Federal Parliament and puts forward an amendment which talks about dangerous drugs, without any definition or anything else. The amendment goes on to state:
Or has been convicted . . . of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years-
Why five years? Why not four years? Why not one year or why not 6 1/4 years?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not 10 years? What is magic about 10 years?

—We will come to the 10 years in a moment. There is no definition of 'an offence' or anything else. There is no definition of the different laws in the different States. There is no worry about the different people who are sitting on the different benches who have very different views. There used to be a magistrate in Wollongong who would have quite happily gaoled drunken drivers for about six or seven years and maybe some of us here would do that too. The Opposition comes into the Senate with a loose amendment of this type. I put it to the Opposition that if its position is put in the way that Senator Martin put it, I can understand it and I can certainly understand her concern and the concern of some members of the Opposition that maybe the Government has gone too far in this regard. I will come to that point in a moment. But if the Opposition comes into this chamber or goes to the public and talks in the terms that Senator Teague used, about hoards of migrants selling large amounts of dangerous drugs, putting the youth of this country in danger, and carrying on in dramatic terms that, it creates a great offence against any attempt to get a rational debate on drugs and the misuse of drugs in this community and it does not assist the Senate or the community at all. It is very easy to get headlines by behaving in this way. It is very easy to get populist applause by making remarks such as that, but I put it to the Opposition that it does not help the people who are trying to legislate and it does not help the people who are trying to reform the system.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague and others in the other place have talked about the importance of this ministerial discretion to deport and to affect the lives of those who are non-citizens or citizens, but particularly non-citizens who are permanent residents. We believe that it is an important discretion. We believe that it is a discretion that should be restricted. We believe that there should be some firm ground rules and we believe that a migrant country such as ours, which takes in migrants in this way, also has responsibilities as have the migrants who come here. We partly believe this because of the behaviour of some people in the past.

Let me talk about a related area which is dear to the hearts of many of us. There was the discretion available-it is still available-relating to the approval of citizenship in this country. There are members of parliament in this country who were previously denied citizenship by Ministers in this place on the most spurious security grounds. I refer to not only members of parliament; many other people in this community, because of the hysteria of the times and because of the sorts of reports that used to be made to Ministers, were refused citizenship in this country. The same thing applies to people who were deported. It was out of a desire to protect the rights of such people-they have rights just as much as citizens and this community have rights-that this Government and this particular Minister sought to amend this legislation to provide what were considered to be more fair rules, to provide what would be considered to be a more basic civil libertarian approach to this problem.

I point out to honourable senators that while the so-called 10-year rule applies to the conduct of non-citizens under proposed new section 14 (1) of the legislation, there are, I believe, compelling humanitarian and compassionate reasons why this should be so and there are reasons why the Minister and the Department should have strict guidelines and should be more strictly confined in how they use their discretion. As someone who was, for a short time, the Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and who had to make the decision on whether to deport or not to deport, I can really have some sympathy for the present Minister, and previous Ministers who have had to deal with it all the time. This is quite distinct from the conviction section under proposed new section 14 (2) of the legislation. I do not think that honourable senators opposite should interfere in this area.

I make the following points-they are the same sorts of points that the Minister has made-that a large migrant country such as Australia must at some stage accept responsibility for the conduct of migrants who are accepted for permanent residence. That may be offensive to some people who believe that there is this great distinction between people who have not been born here but may have lived here most of their lives, and people who are born here. But we do have the situation under the amendment that if someone is convicted for possession of or trafficking in dangerous drugs-whatever drug that is-and is sentenced to imprisonment for not less than five years under the legislation-the person may have been here for 20 or 25 years and the conviction may have been 20 or 25 years back-a Minister, using this discretion in an untrammelled way, can deport that person. We do not believe that that is right. We believe that 10 years is a reasonable period. We believe, and the Minister believes, that 10 years is a substantial period for the conduct of a permanent resident to be vetted by the Government and for a person's security risk to be assessed. I most certainly share that view. Maybe some people think it should be 10 years; maybe other people think it should be 15 years. I certainly do not believe that it should be life, as Senator Teague and others apparently believe it should be. The Minister also believes that regardless of the deportation provisions in the Migration Act the criminal justice system in this country should be adequately equipped, and I believe it is to deal with people who constitute a security threat. If it is not , we should do something about it and not try to pick out one group of people with whom we want to take the easy way out and deport, no matter how long they have been here, under the circumstances that the Opposition apparently wants us to adopt. We also believe that a permanent resident whose conduct is suspected of being a threat to security has the right to expect that within 10 years of his grant of permanent residence that conduct will be asessed and a decision made whether to deport him or her then, not to have it drag on and on.

The amendments to the deportation section, proposed new sections 12 and 14, limit deportations for the first 10 years. That was clear Government policy. It was Government policy before the election, it has been government policy and remains so. I believe that the Minister has attempted to tighten up this discretionary area to protect the rights of people, citizens and non-citizens, and to ensure that everyone understands what the rules are, that everyone understands what the position will be in the future and, at the same time, provide a provision to protect the country in the way that Senator Teague and others want it to be protected.

Legislation such as this will always be kept under review. Of course, the operation of legislation such as this will be kept under review and I dare say it will be kept under review by the Opposition as well as the Government. But we believe that it is a reasonable and sensible approach to take in this part of the twentieth century. I am glad that the Opposition welcomes the rest of the legislation which removes some of the distinctions which have worried not only citizens but also non-citizens and many members of our large migrant community in the past. I thank the Opposition, up to now at least at the second reading stage, for its co-operation in the passage of this legislation which I believe, despite the remarks of some honourable senators opposite, does represent an advance and a recognition that this is a changed country. It also recognises the contribution, in an indirect way, of so many migrant groups to this community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to clarify some remarks I made at the second reading stage. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) said that I had set up an aunt sally of my own accusing the Government, by inference, of removing in its foreign policy some of the special relationships that Australia has with the Commonwealth or countries in our region. I rise briefly to point out that that was not my accusation. I was not seeking to accuse the Government of denying completely the special relationships in our region. Rather, some of those people who are listening to this debate could assume that the bipartisan support for removing these distinctions between persons of various original nationalities may infer some watering down of our foreign policy. For the sake of those members of the public who might be anxious that that is the view not only of the Government but also the Opposition, I made the rejoinder that no false assumption should be made that because certain discriminations are being removed by this legislation with regard to the original nationalities of persons that that has any inference whatsoever to the foreign policy of the Government or the Opposition. I think perhaps that the Minister was oversensitive and he certainly misunderstood my intention. I made only that brief rejoinder.

—I merely say that I do not believe that Senator Teague has helped the situation very much. The Migration Amendment Bill 1983 and the Migration (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1983 have been debated in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. No one in his right mind, except Senator Teague, would have ever assumed or drawn the inference that the passage of this legislation has anything to do with our international relations or anything to do with our relationships with various groups or countries other than our own. I am sorry if Senator Teague is somehow offended that I rose and said that, by bringing up this matter, he was doing what he had done in the past, that is, imputing some motives to the Government which did not exist. If he was not doing that, I cannot for the life of me think why he bothered to say it at all. However, that is up to Senator Teague. Maybe he was just padding out his speech, I do not know. Perhaps he thought he had to speak for more than 10 minutes or something like that. However, I repeat-I believe Senator Teague repeated what he had said-that this is a migration Bill. It has nothing to do with our relationships with the Commonwealth, the Association of South East Asian Nations, Papua New Guinea, the Pacific nations, the Upper Volta or anywhere else. That is the point I wished to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments about clause 10. Unfortunately representations have been made to me since the matter has been dealt with in the House of Representatives. I am sorry to raise this matter at this late stage. I do not intend to move an amendment. I suggest to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) that there is a serious illogicality about the provisions of clause 10. They should be looked at and repaired. The provision in clause 10 relates to people who are non-citizens who have been here for less than 10 years and are convicted of crimes. One of the requirements is that they can be deported if the offence is an offence for which the person was sentenced to death or to imprisonment for life or for a period of not less than one year. I hope the reference to 'sentenced to death' will soon be removed when the two recalcitrant States of New South Wales and Western Australia, which still have the death sentence on their statute books, remove this objectionable provision.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is with the imprisonment period of not less than one year. It has been put to me that it is quite illogical to say: 'Yes, there is one offence for which there is an imprisonment period of one year'. I must point out that this seems to be a great improvement on what was previously in the Act. The difficult situation that now arises is that if a person is convicted of 10 offences and is given six months imprisonment on each charge or a person is convicted of six offences and is given 10 months imprisonment on each charge, that person will go to gaol for five years. That person is not caught by this legislation. But a person who is sentenced to imprisonment for a period of one year-he might not be in gaol for one year; he may be in gaol for only six months or so--

TALK.START.PARA: —For one offence.
—Yes, for one offence. That person can be deported. But the person--
—Subject to deportation.

—He is subject to deportation. But the person who has been guilty of a number of offences-possibly that indicates a greater contempt of the law of this country than someone who makes one mistake-is not subject to the same provision. I believe that this point has substance. I believe that the Government, even at this late stage, ought to consider changing the legislation so that provision is included in it which covers the situation I have mentioned. After all, a person might be here for less than 10 years and might be sentenced to gaol for four or five years. Surely in that situation he ought to be subject to deportation rather than the person who has been sentenced to imprisonment for one year. I put it to the Minister that there is substance in this objection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the point that Senator Missen has made. I make the following points: First of all, deportation involves people who are deported for serious offences rather than petty offences. I suppose that the term of a year is an attempt, albeit a clumsy attempt under our legal system, to draw a distinction between what is a--
—Especially when you take the argument you raised a few minutes ago about the attitudes of different States.

—Yes, the question of what is a serious offence or not is raised. I put it to the Committee that we may have some State in this country which will start putting people in gaol for a year for vagrancy. I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) because I understand the problem Senator Missen is facing. As for those people who may commit 10 offences and be imprisoned for six months on each charge or those who have committed six offences and are to be imprisoned for 10 months on each charge, I remind the Senate that when people are in gaol for that period they are extending their 10 years of permanent residence in Australia. In the case raised by Senator Missen I think it would be 15 years.
—You start counting again.

—One does not count the periods when they are locked up. I appreciate that this is a difficult area. I do not think that anyone in this place pretends that the whole area of deportation and what should be considered a serious crime and what should not be is not a difficult area. I suppose that there are many views in the community. I reckon that there would be more extreme views in the community than one would ever find in this place. There are some who think that we should deport pick-pockets or perhaps a better example would be deportation for a first offence of shoplifting; there are others who believe there should be no deportation at all. I can understand that difficulty. As I said when winding up the second reading debate, this is an attempt to bring in some sort of rationality. I think that Senator Missen conceded that this was better than what was there before. I dare say that we can do better still. I shall refer Senator Missen's remarks to the Minister and the Department to see what we can do about them.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 11 (Deportation of non-citizens upon security grounds after report by Commissioner).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 11, paragraph (a), after proposed new sub-section 14 (1), insert the following new sub-section:

'' '(1A) Where a person who is a non-citizen has either before or after the commencement of this sub-section been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs, or has been convicted in Australia of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years, the Minister may, subject to this section, order the deportation of the person'.''.

I should like to refer to the second reading speech of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) and the philosophy behind the Bill in relation to deportation. The Minister, in his second reading speech, said:

The legislation does not define the basis on which decisions are to be taken; that is the purpose of the policy. Experience has shown that it is not feasible, nor do I believe that it is proper, to define by legislation precisely who must be deported from Australia. Discretion must continue to be vested in the Minister to consider each case on its merits. The exercise of discretion under the Act must continue to be guided by statements of government policy.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) representing him in this chamber made comments to that effect in replying to the second reading debate. However, in the introductory second reading speech, the Minister went on to say:

The Government must be able to protect the Australian community from non- citizens whose serious crimes show that they are a threat to the community. The Government must retain the legislative power to remove criminals and undesirables who have chosen not to commit themselves fully to Australia or who, through their own criminal actions, do not qualify for membership of the Australian community.
That is a statement with which the Opposition would certainly agree. I draw attention to a statement a little further on in the speech, however, which says:

The overwhelming majority of non-citizens who settle in this country are law- abiding members of the community and have a right to expect, after 10 years of lawful residence, that they will not be expelled.

Again, the Opposition would support that sentiment. However, there is some conflict in that sentiment and some of the other comments that have been made in debate. I wish to quote one other sentence and then to return to that matter. The Minister said:
I must emphasise that the purpose of deporting a criminal is to protect the safety and welfare of the Australian community.

I emphasise that myself: The purpose of deporting a criminal is to protect the safety and welfare of the Australian community. So the Government has decided to keep the power of deportation but it has made a couple of fairly arbitrary decisions of its own.

Senator Grimes, in response to the second reading debate, asked why, in our amendment, we said, for example, that there should be a right to deportation of someone sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years. He asked 'Why five years?' One could as easily say to the Government 'Why 10 years as the period of immunity?' That might seem an arbitrary figure. It is arbitrary in the sense that the Government has picked a figure, but then 10 years, perhaps , notionally is a period which seems reasonable. At the same time, a period of five years might seem arbitrary, but notionally we suggest that it is reasonable , because people who are sentenced to imprisonment for five years have, on the whole, committed fairly serious crimes.

I draw out some of the contrasts in the penalties for which people are liable under the provisions of the Government's Bill and some of the provisions to which we have referred which are not in the Bill but which we think should be in it. For example, the Bill gives the Minister the right to deportation for someone who has offended against section 6 of the Crimes Act, which carries a maximum penalty of two years imprisonment, or against section 86 (1), which carries a maximum imprisonment penalty of three years. There are two cases that the Govenment has specified in this Bill which are less than five years, so I would think that in saying five years we were actually not being super- restrictive against the Government's view but being rather generous. We were guided by a couple of other sections, to which I have already referred, that is section 78 of the Crimes Act, relating to espionage, which carries a penalty of seven years imprisonment, and section 81, which relates to harbouring spies, which also attracts a penalty of seven years imprisonment.

In looking at those sorts of serious crimes, which the Government has, either deliberately or inadvertently, left out of this reference to the Crimes Act, we thought that five years was reasonable in those circumstances. The Minister is very well aware that one makes a decision such as that somewhere along the line, so I do not think that the period of five years in itself is an objection. In fact, someone who receives a penalty of five years has committed a serious crime , and the Government would have to agree with that, as I have said, because some of the offences that it has chosen to single out and include actually carry penalties of only two or three years.

On the matter of the dangerous drug objection, I agree with a lot that the Minister for Social Security said in response to the second reading debate on the subject of people having different ideas about what is a dangerous drug, and we will find some variance between the States as to what penalties the same offences carry. Nevertheless, I point out that after all, we are talking about a ministerial discretion. The amendment says 'the Minister may, subject to this section, order the deportation of the person'. Our concern in moving the amendment is to widen the Minister's discretion. We say that in narrowing the Minister's discretion to the extreme degree that the amending Bill does, the Government has made a mistake. It has left out crimes of a like nature to those that are included, and it has too far restricted itself on ministerial discretion. I remind the Minister that in the second reading speech the point was made that discretion must continue to be vested in the Minister to consider each case on its merits. Our concern is that the Minister will not have, when the point comes, enough discretion.

The Opposition will be moving to a division on this amendment. The Minister in the House of Representatives gave an utterly unsatisfactory response to the amendment. There is nothing in the debate on the amendment, which I have read carefully, which would deflect me or the Opposition from our view on its seriousness. If the Minister in this place wants to say that there may be good intent in this but he wants to nit-pick about, for example, dangerous drugs, it is up to him to declare whether the Government will accept the thrust of our amendment, which is that the present amending Bill is too restrictive, that the Minister will need more discretion and that it would be accepted by the Australian community that a Minister for immigration ought to have discretion in relation to people who, as the Minister said in his second reading speech, have chosen not to commit themselves to this country even after a period of 10 years. I do not have any difficulty with the term 'dangerous drug'. To me, that means drugs such as heroin and cocaine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tobacco.

—That is a drug. I would not include it in the dangerous drug category we are discussing here. Just as the Government can notionally come up with 10 years as the period after which people will generally not be liable to deportation, we can have a sense of what dangerous drugs are. If the Government wants to spell that out, it has the opportunity here or on reconsideration in the other place, and it is free to do so. But I challenge the Government to turn its attention, at least in the Senate, in our House of review, to the intention and the thrust of the amendment, which is meant to be helpful to the Minister. It is meant to aid the objective, stated by the Government in the second reading speech, that the Government must be able to protect the Australian community from non-citizens whose serious crimes show that they are a threat to the community. I hope that the Government will accept that our amendment is in accord with the intention of the Bill as outlined by the Government. I hope that it will accept the Opposition's bona fides and agree to this amendment or else, maybe here-there have been two months between debate in the House of Representatives and debate here-put forward an alternative amendment in the same sense but with some wording that the Government may wish to claim is superior.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Migration Amendment Bill 1983, which changes the discretionary power of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to deport people. This legislation proposes that a non-citizen, that is, a person who was not born here and who has chosen not to be naturalised even though he could have been naturalised but who has been a legal resident of Australia for 10 years or more, could not be deported unless he is convicted of an offence of a national security nature. We are talking about a class of people who have been here for the required time, who could have been naturalised but who in many cases, for good reasons to them, have chosen not to renounce their former country and accept the oath of allegiance to Australia and therefore have chosen not to be naturalised. In passing, I make the point that I respect the decision of those people who choose not to be naturalised. I hope that they will change that decision. Once they have made the overt decision that it is in their interests not to be naturalised, I believe that they cannot rely on the privileges of citizenship if ever they get into trouble. I think that is a fair proposition which they go into with quite open minds.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation means that the Minister's discretionary power to deport people on the basis of criminal conviction will no longer apply after a person has been here 10 years, regardless of whether that person is naturalised, unless the person is charged with offences involving sedition, treachery or treason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Convicted, not charged.

—I am sorry; convicted of offences involving sedition, treachery or treason. I thank Senator Missen. The Opposition's amendment wants the Minister to retain discretionary power over deporting non-residents after 10 years in two circumstances, one of which is where a person has been convicted of drug trafficking. The Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, quite properly points out the difference of approach and attitude to and definition of what are dangerous drugs throughout Australia. I remind him that what Mr Bjelke- Petersen thinks of marihuana is totally irrelevant because we are now dealing with Commonwealth jurisdiction.
—Not for Queenslanders.
—For the purpose of this argument.

—For the purpose of this argument, we are dealing with an amendment to a Commonwealth Act and it is the Commonwealth's prerogative to determine what it believes to be dangerous drugs. Mr Bjelke-Petersen's view, or a State Premier's view, or anyone's view of what a dangerous drug might be is irrelevant.
—That is not right.

—Senator Missen says that is not right and I always respect his interjections, particularly on legal matters. It is my understanding that the Commonwealth could define specifically in legislation, in particular in this legislation, the kinds of drugs in which a person has been trafficking.
—This amendment does not do that.

—I agree with that. This amendment does not do it. If the Commonwealth Government took this amendment on board, it could so amend the Act to overcome the proper objections that Senator Grimes mentioned. That is the point I am getting at. The second prong of the amendment relates to an offence with a sentence of five years or more. The Opposition believes that 10 years of lawful residence by a non-citizen is not enough of a contribution to society to waive the threat of deportation. As I understand it, the Government rejects the amendment on the ground that it would create a discretionary sub-class of non- citizens who would be subject to deportation. I remind the Government that that sub-class exists now; this Bill will not remove it. The sub-class is restricted to people convicted of offences of sedition, treachery or treason. What the Opposition wants to do is to increase the potential numbers of that sub-class to cover people convicted of drug trafficking or any other offence which carries a sentence of five years or more.

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of those fascinating arguments one strikes in politics where one can see good points on both sides. I respect what the Opposition is putting, yet at the same time I acknowledge the wisdom of the Government's refusal to accept it. We have to make decisions in this place and on balance we lean to the Opposition's view and we will vote with the Opposition on the amendment. We do not make a big deal of it because we concede the judgment of the Government. We support the Opposition's amendment which, of course, will ensure that it will be passed. It will then go to the House of Representatives and we hope that the serious debate that has contributed to this question in this chamber will be contemplated by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) and the Government's Immigration Committee and that they might reconsider their stance on this to contemplate accepting the Senate amendment before returning the legislation to the Senate later. If, however, they choose to be obstinate then, while the Australian Democrats would wish on balance the amendment to be incorporated into the legislation, we would certainly not adopt a barricade position. We would accept what the Lower House decides on this. We hope that the sensible and sensitive debate that has taken place here will commend itself to the Government and to members of the House of Representatives.

Let me give an example of a person born in, say, a non-English speaking country who migrates here and has been here for 12 years. He overtly decides for some reason or another not to take out citizenship. Let us further assume that he has been involved in drug trafficking for five or six years, importing drugs or growing cannabis sativa somewhere where it grows well. I will not name a State; there are plenty of places in Australia where it grows well. Let us assume that he has made a lot of money and that in his twelfth year in Australia, still unnaturalised, he gets caught, arrested and convicted. Why should he be able to rely on the fact that he has been here for more than 10 years to prevent his deportation? Why should we hamstring the Minister and say: 'No, you can no longer deport this person'?

Some dreadful creatures come to mind who have been in the business of drugs, mentioned by royal commissions, and who fit into this category. Some of them deported themselves before they could be brought within the jurisdiction of Australian law. Let us assume that a person is caught here. I do not necessarily have to mention names in this debate, but people named in the report of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and other royal commissions are well known. They came from non-English speaking countries. They were involved in the Mr Asia syndicate. They imported millions of dollars worth of heroin. To my knowledge, they were not naturalised. It is preposterous that such people might be found guilty in an Australian court and yet the Minister would be powerless to deport them. As I understand it, the Opposition amendment proposes to remedy that. To put a finer point on it, why should the Australian taxpayer be asked to keep such offenders in Australian gaols for long periods if the offences are serious? After they are released from gaol, why should they be allowed-unless they are totally rehabilitated-to rejoin the Australian community and prey on it again? There are a great many Australian-born habitual criminals, totally amoral and immoral, who prey for profit on weaker groups in our society and whom, if I were a Minister, I would like to deport. Unhappily, the law does not give us an opportunity to deport Australian-born people. There would be no place to which we could deport them. However, I can see no argument whatsoever that could be advanced, or has been advanced to this point, for why the Minister should not, in any case he chooses, have the option of deporting people who have come here of their own free will, chosen not to renounce allegiance to a former country but to retain their former citizenship, entered into a life of crime and been convicted. For that reason, the Democrats will support the amendment moved by the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since it seems fairly clear that the Opposition amendment will probably be carried and there is to be a division, I must set out some views. I will certainly vote for the amendment the Opposition has moved. I saw it only this morning. I regret that in this Parliament it is impossible to keep up with the things that are going on. Therefore, I would certainly not take my colleagues by surprise by voting against the amendment. However, I think it is a very sloppy amendment. Although I will vote for it, I hope that a lot of very careful consideration will be given to it before it is dealt with in the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that there is a lot of sense in the views expressed by Senator Chipp. This amendment would provide that under two certain circumstances discretion would remain with the Minister to deport people. I make the preliminary comment that the amendment is being inserted in clause 11, which has as its heading 'Deportation of non-citizens upon security grounds after report by Commissioner'. It is very difficult to see what the content of the amendment necessarily has to do with security grounds. Perhaps the amendment should be inserted somewhere else in the Bill. That is the point I am making here. For example, trafficking in dangerous drugs is generally highly offensive, but it may have nothing whatsoever to do with security, unless we take security in some sort of vague sense as affecting the general well-being and security of the country. But that is not what is intended by security grounds.
The problem as I see it-one that strangely has not been raised on this side of the House-is that in a sense a penalty is being imposed retrospectively. This amendment states:

(1A) Where a person who is a non-citizen has either before or after the commencement of this sub-section been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs, or has been convicted in Australia of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years, the Minister may, subject to this section, order the deportation of that person.

The amendment sets out two specific areas where the Minister may use such discretion. Senator Chipp has said that if 'trafficking in dangerous drugs' is taken wrongly and the States take a very savage view that a drug is dangerous, although Senator Chipp or I may not think such a drug is dangerous, we can solve this problem by excluding it from our Acts. That is a very indirect way of doing it. Meanwhile, the person engaging in such trafficking has probably long since been deported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a regulation making power under the Act, and could that be used to overcome problems?

—I think it could, but there is no provision in this amendment for regulations to be made. The amendment as it stands does not cover that. But perhaps the point that Senator Baume has made is one that could be covered in a reconsideration of the terms of the amendment. My first point is that the amendment creates a retrospective penalty.
—No, but they are now subject to deportation.

—They are subject to general deportation. There is a specific provision in this amendment for deportation at the discretion of the Minister if a person has been convicted of trafficking in dangerous drugs. If a chemist sells by error to another chemist some drugs which under the national health provisions he is not entitled to sell, it may be said that he is trafficking in dangerous drugs. It would depend on the definition of dangerous drugs in a particular State or Territory. He may be convicted, but he may not be sent to gaol; he may be given a bond. On the other hand, the second leg of this amendment deals with persons convicted of offences and sentenced to imprisonment for a period of not less than five years. It can be inferrred from the length of imprisonment that it is for a serious offence. My main worry is with the provision concerning offenders who have trafficked in dangerous drugs. It is very easy in this community to say that trafficking is a bad thing; it is. Dangerous drugs are terrible. Generally speaking, the community is quite right in its great abhorrence of those things, but they are not defined clearly. We could find very great differences in the way in which the various States treat offences.

SPEECH.PARA: We are then met with the fact that the Minister has a discretion. Of course he can say that he regards the law of the State of X as crazy and refuse to deport on convictions made under that law. I do not know what that might do for State- Federal relations. But the Parliament has generally resisted excessive discretionary powers for Ministers. Those of us who have served on committees of the Parliament scrutinising legislation and regulations are concerned about excessive discretionary powers. I know that the legislation is taking away discretions rather than giving them, but the discretion given by this amendment seems to be very vague. I think there are problems with the amendment. It seems to have been drafted somewhat on the run. I will certainly vote for it because I think the matter deserves further consideration, but I think that since there will be a division on the matter one must make clear one's reservations about the language of the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Missen has said, this amendment and this clause are about discretions. The Opposition wants to broaden considerably the discretion of the Minister under the legislation. The Government-quite unashamedly and as we have said before coming into government we wanted to do-is trying to narrow down that discretion because there is no question but that in the past the discretionary power of the Minister to deport and to approve citizenship has been abused. We all know of cases of abuse. There have been considerable differences between the Minister and, for instance, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the courts in very recent times. The Minister has overruled the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts and used his discretion under the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I make it clear, first, that I am not questioning the motives of those who are bringing forward this amendment. I specifically said that in the second reading debate. One is in the old position that all of us in this place end up in when looking at an amendment of this type. As I asked in the second reading debate, what on earth is a dangerous drug? That point was raised by Senator Missen. He added another point when he asked: 'What is trafficking?' They are very serious questions in a country which is made up of six States and a couple of Territories, all with differing laws. I would have no hesitation in saying that if the discretion to decide what was a dangerous drug and what was trafficking were in the hands of Senator Martin or certain other people in this place I would not have any worries about it. But it would not always be in the hands of Senator Martin. There are other people in this place to whom I would not give this discretion or any other discretion. Therefore, I believe that we have to narrow it down as much as possible. That, in fact, is what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) has tried to do. He has tried to do that particularly in this area of drugs and drug trafficking because that is an area which in the past has obviously created great difficulty.

As I said, again in the second reading speech, one of the problems we have is the way people approach the so-called drug problem. We are always trying to get at 'the problem' by attacking it through the penal clauses of legislation, including penal clauses of the Migration Act in this case. Too often people involved in politics believe they are tapping the populist views of the community by making the sorts of speeches that are sometimes made, suggesting how these creatures should be thrown out of the country and that if they are not willing to accept our citizenship they should not be protected by our laws, et cetera. Honourable senators have all heard that over and over again and we will continue to hear it over and over again in this place. Sure it goes down well in the community but in the meantime the drug situation in this country stays the same or gets worse because the real methods of overcoming the problem certainly involve the certainty of detection and certainly involve the certainty of penalty. But they also involve so many other things concerning the attitudes of those who take drugs and those who do not.

If people kid themselves that passing a loose amendment like this, which talks about dangerous drugs without defining them, which talks about trafficking without defining it, which does not take into consideration the differences between the various States and does not take into consideration the effect of the varying attitudes of the community on the Minister who is making the discretion, will take even a small step towards solving the so-called drug problem then they are having themselves on. If we have to weigh the effectiveness of legislation and the potential for offence against civil liberties or the privacy of people, be they citizens or not, then I come down on the side of the Minister; I come down on the side of the Government. If this amendment is passed-as it seems likely to be-then I agree with Senator Missen and Senator Chipp that we will certainly have to go away and have a hard look at it and see how we can redefine the situation if the Parliament insists on that being done.

As for the second part of the legislation, as to whether someone should be deported after being convicted of an offence which carries a penalty of imprisonment for a period of not less than five years, I merely raise the points that I raised in the second reading speech. This is a matter of fine judgment. We should not put an arbitarary figure in the legislation to broaden the capacity of the Minister to deport. It is a matter for judgment what offences should or should not be included in this area and how much responsibility a migrant country, such as ours, should have. We accept people as migrants and as permanent citizens. We do not have rigid citizenship provisions like some other countries for checking up on people who come into the community and for checking on the capacity of our system of justice and our system of detection of crime to monitor what is happening with these permanent residents. I think we get onto dangerous ground, as we have been on dangerous ground in the past, when we set arbitrary penalties of this type, particularly in view of the fact that we have a system of justice which varies so much between the various States.

However, if the Senate insists on the amendment the Government certainly will consider its implications and obviously will have to consider the intent and the motives of the Opposition in moving the amendment to see whether we cannot come to some compromise with those who are so concerned. I certainly believe that we will need a better, more tight and less sloppy amendment than the one that has been moved. I presume the amendment was moved to make a point and to try to get the Government to change its point of view, but the amendment will need much more refining if it is ever to go into legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief. I was disturbed by some of the words used by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in his response. At the beginning of his response in the second reading debate the Minister accused Senator Teague of setting up straw men in order to knock them down. I suggest that that is what the Minister has just done. He attacked us on the grounds that we were suggesting that this amendment in relation to the deportation of non-citizens could be some sort of solution to the drug problem. We have not suggested that it is a solution to the drug problem at all; we have just supported the Government's sentiments, expressed in the second reading speech, that the Government must be able to protect the Australian community from non-citizens whose serious crimes show they are a threat to the community. That is the spirit and the intent of the amendment. I make that point because I will not have it suggested that we have been suggesting that non-citizens are the source of the drug problem in Australia. We have not said that. It was suggested in debate in the House of Representatives, although it was suggested by Government members. No member of the Opposition said anything of the sort. I reject again on behalf of the Opposition that there is anything of that sense in what I have said about our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Martin took such offence. I made it clear at the start of my remarks that I believed her motives were pure and that the Opposition's intentions were honourable. But in light of the fact that so much is made in the Opposition's amendment of dangerous drugs and trafficking-that is such a large element of the amendment-I felt bound to point out that it is terribly easy to come in with amendments of this type, which are vague and sloppy, to make remarks about protecting the citizens of this country from creatures-I think that was one of the words used-and to get support for attitudes and amendments like these, giving the impression to ordinary citizens of this country that by so doing we are making a hell of a difference to the drug problem, as it is called, including the amount of drug trafficking.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to weigh the effectiveness of the legislation in that regard against the potential capacity of the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) or future Ministers to use that discretion in such a way as to create more difficulties and more offences against civil liberties and more problems than are caused by the problems that we are trying to attack. That is the only point I wish to make. We will certainly consider the amendment moved by the Opposition, as we must, but I make the point that we will have to consider it and put it into proper legislative form if it is ever to be properly a part of the legislation.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Martin's amendment) be inserted .

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bills-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bills reported with amendment; reports adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.
Date resumed from 19 October 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Before proceeding to the second reading debate of the Appropriation ( Parliamentary Departments) Bill it might be helpful to the Senate if I explain the way in which it is intended to deal with the Appropriation Bills. Following the second reading of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill the Senate will proceed in Committee of the Whole to consider the votes for the parliamentary departments in the order in which they were considered by Estimates Committee A. Following the normal practice, honourable senators will be given an opportunity to move motions in relation to those departments as well as seek further information. After the Senate has dealt with the Appropriation ( Parliamentary Departments) Bill the votes in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) will be considered together in the normal way in the same groupings and order as the departmental Estimates referred to Estimates committees A, B, C, D, E and F respectively. To assist the Committee of the Whole in its consideration of the Estimates, a schedule of departmental Estimates has been distributed to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to honourable senators to move motions expressing opinions or making recommendations based on the report of Estimates Committee A; that any motion or motions shall be disposed of before the question is put on the vote before the Chair; and that any resolutions be reported when the Chairman makes his report to the President at the conclusion of proceedings in the Committee of the Whole.
Senator Chaney-Mr Chairman, I just seek clarification. Are we dealing still with the parliamentary departments as set out in group A-the Senate and so on?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chaney-Is it currently open for any honourable senator to raise matters relating to the Senate, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and so on?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is: That the Bill be reported.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick-I take a point of order. As I understand it, we are dealing only with the Parliament at the moment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick-Is only that part of the Bill being reported?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It is a separate Bill.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Chaney-There is obviously great satisfaction within the Senate about the state of the parliamentary appropriations. There was just some concern among Opposition senators that we might be dealing with appropriations for departments other than the Parliament. But that is not the case. I understand that the Bill has now been dealt with by the Committee.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a third time.
(1) That clauses 1 to 9 and Schedule 1 be postponed till after the consideration of Schedule 2.

(2) That, unless otherwise ordered, the votes in Schedule 2 be considered in the same groupings and order as the departmental estimates referred to Estimates Committees A, B, C, D, E and F, respectively, as follows:
Advance to the Minister for Finance 150,000,000 47

(3) That leave be given to senators to move motions expressing opinions or making recommendations based on the reports of the Estimates Committees; that such motions be moved when the appropriate vote is under consideration; that where more than one motion is proposed in relation to a particular vote, the motions may be debated together, but in all cases a motion or motions shall be disposed of before the question is put on the vote before the Chair; and that any resolutions be reported when the Chairman makes his report to the President at the conclusion of proceedings in Committee of the Whole.
