SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity afforded by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) to express some opinion in relation to the vote for the Department of Industry and Commerce which amounts to $178,943,000. I think members of the Senate, certainly on the Opposition side , and members of the community view with some concern the Government's lack of commitment to honouring its election promises in the small business and manufacturing areas. I think that the Government since coming to office has tried to develop policies in isolation. It has looked only at particular departments rather than at the effects that some policies could have on other departments. For example, we will be faced with an unemployment rate of over 12 per cent in February next year. We are seeing industry within Australia being virtually wiped out by wage increases and competition from overseas. However, we are not seeing an integrated approach from this Government. In other words, policies on wages, employment, industrial relations and taxation should be an integral part of industry and commerce. Senator Button is probably doing his best to espouse good policies in relation to industry and commerce. However, those policies have had absolutely no effect because they have been outweighed by what is happening in areas such as industrial relations and, particularly, taxation. I remind him of what was said in the Australian Labor Party's policy speech. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot satisfactorily rebuild our workforce unless at the same time we rebuild our manufacturing base.

This objective requires measures to deal with both the immediate crisis-there is no excuse for delay-and the long term situation. It is disappointing that we did not see in this Budget any measures designed to attack the immediate crisis. The possible exception may be within the steel industry whose delicate situation Senator Button and the Labor Party may have further exacerbated. However, jobs continue to be lost in the manufacturing area. We all recognise that the small business area has the potential to generate jobs and we are disappointed that more was not done to develop a greater capability in this area within the Department of Industry and Commerce or to establish a portfolio to deal with small business.

Let us look at the figures. Small businesses can generate more jobs per sales dollar than larger companies. This fact is recognised not only in Australia but also around the world. Let us look at the United States of America because our situation is not all that different from what prevails in that country. For example, sales of $1 billion by small companies in that country create more jobs than $37 billion worth of sales by large companies. Small companies are very much more capable of being innovative. The figures suggest that they are four times more innovative than medium to large firms, and 20 times more innovative than large firms. So the facts speak for themselves. Small entrepreneurial operations have the capacity to generate jobs. Although the Labor Government acknowledges that something must be done in the short term, it is doing very little to generate jobs in the small business area against the background of rising unemployment which is forecast to be over 12 per cent in February next year.

There is a need for a change of attitude and a recognition of the importance of small business and the wealth that these businesses can create within the community. Unfortunately, the Labor Party seeks to attack all forms of wealth. However, it does not seek to adopt measures which create wealth within the community. We must encourage enterprise. There are within the Australian community 617,000 enterprises-or 81.8 per cent of all enterprises-employing one to four persons, and 93 per cent of all enterprises have fewer than 10 employees .

The contribution from small business is very significant. We are seeing continual attacks on the business sector. In fact, one insidious measure now being undertaken is the use of the exchange rate. What effect is that having? It is leading to an over-valued currency and creating problems for our export industries. Already we see pressures being placed on the coal, iron ore and wool industries. The major importing countries of these materials are looking elsewhere, to South America and to Africa. If we look at last week's wool sales, we see that the price of wool is in the doldrums. Why? It is in the doldrums because of an over-valued currency. Further, there has been a dramatic promotional program by man made fibre industries in the United States to counter the effects of an earlier increase in wool usage. What has the Australian Labor Party done? It promised $28m for wool promotion, pre-election, and delivered only $20m. That was a broken promise to the extent of $8m. In recent weeks we have seen dramatic falls in prices for livestock. The prices for lambs and cattle are down. A lot of this is directly attributable to an over-valued exchange rate. Exporters are being asked to pay the price for the ineptitude of this Government.

On the other hand, the Government has hit exporters both ways. It has introduced meat inspection charge levies which are completely unrelated to costs and make the export position so much more untenable. I think we have to acknowledge that the drop in the inflation rate to 9.2 per cent is one of the benefits of the wages pause. The Fraser Government introduced that pause. Since then what has happened? Wages have escalated; they are out of control. This will lead to increases in business costs. The small business area will be first affected by this rise in costs. What is the Labor Party doing? Essentially it is pump-priming the public sector and hitting the private sector. The Labor Party has acknowledged the effect that high wages are having on industry. The Treasury Budget Statement No. 2 said:
'A wages outcome higher than currently assumed would have an especially damaging impact on business confidence and private sector spending propensities' .

The Government was told of the consequences, but what is it trying to do? Firms are being forced out of business. We have seen problems with Nestle Australia Ltd. A recent Press statement by my colleague the shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Peter Rae, stated:
NESTLE'S FACTORY CLOSURE A DISGRACE
'Union bans which have forced Nestle Australia Ltd to close its Pakenham factory are a national disgrace' . . .

There were 176 jobs lost in that area. The Government's wages policy, industrial relations policy and employment policy must be integrated into a sound single policy relating to industry and commerce, otherwise unemployment will escalate to very unacceptable levels. I believe that there is an urgency for the Government to look at its commitments and to start implementing them rather than playing around with a lot of issues that will not have any great impact on the economy. The great national issues have to be resolved. Instead, we are mucking around. We are spending far too much time on peripheral issues such as the sex discrimination legislation. We would be far better to debate issues related to improving manufacturing capabilities and the competitive performance of industry in this country. It is therefore with some concern that I note a lack of initiative in relation to the votes of the Department of Industry and Commerce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek from the Government some firmer indication of its estimate of the number of unemployment recipients for the current financial year. During the Estimates committee hearings in respect of the Department of Social Security, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) informed us that, in fact, there would be an average level of unemployment benefit recipients in this current year of about 680,000. He informed us this morning by way of answer to another question that arose in respect of debate on the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Bill that the current level of unemployment recipients-I take it the figure used was for September 1983-was 602,000. The point I seek clarification from the Government on is whether that level of benefit is an indication of a fall in the expected average estimate for the year, whether it is expected that 602,000 will be the level of unemployment recipients as at June 1984 or whether the Government has some other figure in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the unemployment level fluctuates throughout any financial year. We expect changes month by month and certainly year by year, between the figures which apply at the end of each financial year. In fact, I believe that the Budget referred to an increase of about 26,000 in the number of unemployment benefit recipients between the year ended 30 June 1983 and the year ended 30 June 1984. It is confusing for those of us who are trying to understand the patterns of unemployment which this Government is expecting in this current year unless we can get clearer indications from the Government as to exactly what it expects the unemployment figure to be. It is clear that the Budget spelt out the intention of the Government to try to create more jobs in the economy. It claimed also that there would be a rise in unemployment this current year. It claimed that that rise might be modest.

Now, if Senator Grimes's remarks this morning are to be given credence, there seems to be some considerable change in the level of unemployment recipients. There are two questions at issue. Firstly, is it that the estimate of unemployment was so considerably out of line when the Budget was drawn that the factor was significantly overstated in the Budget, thereby building a higher deficit into the Budget than was actually likely in the circumstances? Secondly, is there simply an element of deception in the Government's approach to the whole question of unemployment, and is the Government playing safe by hedging its bets against the results as at June 1984? We have not at this stage had any clear indication but if in fact it is the first case, that indeed there has been a serious overstatement of unemployment benefit recipients, did the Government deliberately do this in order to create the very high deficit declared in its Budget for this financial year and to blame the former Government as part of its strategy to mislead the Australian people about the real situation in the Australian economy? We would like very clear answers to those questions. There are numerous details which we would like to pursue in the debate on the estimates of other departments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like just to touch on the matter which Senator Messner has raised. Unfortunately, between my office and the chamber I did not hear all that he had to say on the subject, but the question of the estimates of unemployment is important to our understanding of what the Government sees as the likely course of the economy and what it sees as being necessary to ease the position of the unemployed. We are all approaching this with the very fresh memory of the inaccuracy of the estimates upon which our own Budget was based last year. We had certain estimates with respect to the number of unemployed. They formed an important element in the calculation of the costs of a major Budget item, namely the cost of unemployment. There was a very significant and sudden increase in the number of unemployed over the post-Budget period and that, of course, caused a substantial revision in the total government expenditure and the total deficit. From my recollection of the process whereby the Government arrives at a figure, contributions were made by a series of departments. The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs was one and Treasury was the body which was actually responsible for the final figure which was accepted by the Government. There was very limited input from what was then my Department of Social Security because we did not have the economic forecasting facilities that are involved in getting those figures together, but again my recollection is that there was not complete unanimity between those departments that regarded themselves as having some expert knowledge to contribute to those estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget Papers give an annual figure, which is the same arrangement as applied in the Budget Papers which were brought down by us last year. There is an average monthly figure for the financial year. The figure of 680,000 was put in the Budget Papers and formed the basis for the calculation of unemployment benefit. I think it was in the post-Budget period last year, and due I think to matters which were raised in the media and perhaps by the then Opposition-I cannot remember-that I became aware of the fact that there were monthly estimates and that the annual figure was in fact the aggregation of a set of monthly estimates. So those figures presumably are available and presumably the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has figures which it regards as being the likely figures for the balance of this financial year. I think it would be of assistance to us if those figures could be made available.

Quite recently I came across an article in the National Times which suggested- indeed it appeared to me to be a piece of very good news for both the Government and for Australia-that there were significantly fewer applicants for unemployment benefit currently than had been predicted. I must say in the present state of statistics there seems to be very great confusion about just what the employment and unemployment position is in Australia. I think the latest monthly 'Round-up of Economic Statistics' from the Treasury makes the point on its front page that there is a great deal of variation in the figures as they have become available month by month. I perhaps should mention this, Mr Chairman, because it explains the reason for the Opposition's interest in the figures which might be available and which might help us all to understand what is happening in the Australian economy and what might be thought to be going to happen in the future. I am sure it is fresh in the memory of all honourable senators that the August figures showed a most disappointing drop in unemployment and showed a quite extraordinary drop in the participation rate since the Labor Government was elected-I think a 1.5 per cent drop in the participation rate, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for August this year. Of course there was an apparent recovery in September. I have not been able to find anything authoritative which would ease my mind about the possibility that we are having some statistical aberrations which make it very difficult to know just what the facts are.

An important part of the process of understanding the Government's Budget, what the Government sees the future as holding and what various expert departments might anticipate the future to be, would be to have the departmental estimates of employment and unemployment for the balance of this financial year. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) whether the views of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations could be made available to the Committee for our consideration of the estimates. It has, of course, direct budgetary relevance because if there is a significant reduction in the number of people on unemployment benefit and if the sorts of rather hopeful signs alluded to in the National Times article are true, of course the deficit will be rather less than that which was predicted by the Government, and that would again be a matter of some significance to all of us and would have potential impacts on other areas of the economy, such as interest rates and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you would be pleased?

—Any good news for Australia is something we should welcome. The fact that it makes life easier for the Government is a matter on which even I would try to suppress my partisan satisfaction. But there was in this area a significant problem for us as a government last year. I acknowledge that. It was a source of considerable criticism from the then Opposition. The view was expressed that the figures had been cooked-I think that was the colloquial expression-because we were seeking to hold down the--
—I beg your pardon.

—Not Peter Cooked-we will have no Dudley Moore of that. The significant point is that there was an allegation that we had played around with figures because we were trying to keep them down. I think there has been some response from the Government that in this circumstance it cannot be criticised, because if the figures are too high all it is doing is making the position look worse for itself. I am not suggesting that there has been a cooking of the figures. All I am looking for is some guidance as to what the rest of the year holds and the extent to which the estimates on which the Budget is based can in fact be relied upon by the Parliament and the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a brief contribution at this stage. Although the matter being debated does not come within my area, it is a matter in which I have shown some interest in the past, as Senator Chaney knows. First of all I deal with Senator Chaney's last point. Last year on Budget night there appeared in the Budget statements figures which clearly, on five minutes contemplation that night, it seemed were underestimated by about $200m, and which after a couple of weeks it was clear were underestimated by some $600m. Week by week the Treasury and the Minister for Social Security had to admit this. We were in a situation in which a Budget brought down was clearly a pre-election Budget. The Government, in our view, was quite clearly trying to understate the deficit. We pointed that out and what we pointed out was perfectly true because the estimate of average unemployment beneficiaries in the Budget of that time was 395,000. It turned out in the end to be 540,000. This year the figures were calculated in much the same way as Senator Chaney experienced-by contributions from various departments but ultimately from the Treasury. We believed that, despite the fact that there would be an increase in employment, which there has been and which will continue to be the case, there would be an increases in the number of unemployment beneficiaries. It was estimated that they would average about 680,000. As Senator Chaney says, the actual figures, and in this case they are the actual figures-they are the only actual figures we have-have gone from 634,000 in July to 622,000 in August, to 610,000 in September to 601,584 on 21 October 1983.
—What was that figure again?

—On 21 October 1983 the figure was 601,584. That is a completely different pattern from what was happening last year when the number of unemployment beneficiaries was going through the roof, as Senator Chaney will well remember. What that means is that if that pattern continues, that number of 680,000 average will be considerably lower. But I have not crowed about it in this place, to use the word that Senator Chaney used; nor have I said that these figures herald the brave new world of economic recovery because I do not think that we can make those assumptions when, at the same time, we have had survey figures which have shown that in one month the work force participation allegedly dropped and in another month it went up considerably and when we know perfectly well that we are coming up to a situation in the new year when the school leavers hit the job market. All I have said to anybody who has asked me is that these figures are certainly hopeful. I think I said in debate this morning that these figures demonstrate at least a return to the normal pattern, last year's pattern being extremely abnormal. But I was not attempting to put any more interpretation on them than that. The figures are available to anybody who asks for them. But certainly I doubt whether the Department of Social Security or any Department would make actual predictions as to what will happen month by month because of the economic circumstances and because of the difficulties. All we are saying is that there is an increased number of people in employment. There is a decrease in the number of people that we estimated would be on unemployment benefit. We are hopeful, but we are not claiming anything more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer my question to the Attorney-General. I remind him of an answer he gave to Senator Chaney in the Senate yesterday in which he said that he had read six to 10 pages of the transcript of telephone tapes concerning the former Minister, Mr Jackson, 'with some care'. I also remind him that he further said:

QUESTION.PARA: I also scanned-that is the appropriate word-rather more briskly the whole bundle of material in front of me-

I think that in other information provided yesterday the Attorney-General indicated that the material contained about 700 pages. I now ask the Attorney- General: How long did he spend scanning this material? Did his scanning involve looking at each page? If not, how many pages did it involve?

TALK.START.PARA: —This series of questions is almost becoming surreal, but I will do my best to answer. I would say I spent approximately 20 minutes looking at the material in front of me. That followed, as I indicated yesterday, approximately half an hour of oral briefings. So it was in the nature of confirmation rather than any full or major study. The particular pages I read closely were those, as I indicated yesterday, which related to particular conversations involving Mr Jackson that had been brought to my attention. I described yesterday the particular context in which I was looking at those particular pages. As to the rest of it, I did no more than turn over the pages and ask occasional questions of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police as to the significance of particular matters that leapt out of the pages at me. Beyond that, I cannot add anything significant to what I said. It was essentially a scanning of the whole bundle of material and a reading more closely of that part of it which had immediately to do with the matters which have come into public contention.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Do I understand from that answer that the major portion of the time the Attorney-General spent looking through the material was spent giving close attention to the pages dealing with Mr Jackson's conversations?
—Yes, that is what I said.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MOUNT ISA: MOBILE OUTBACK SUPPORT TEAM

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware that the future of the mobile outback support team based in Mount Isa has been placed in jeopardy because of the dismissal of its only two staff members as from the end of November? Is the Minister further aware that this decision has been taken apparently by the sponsor, the Queensland Country Women's Association, without reference to the Office of Child Care in Brisbane or the Mount Isa branch of the Country Women's Association, both of which have nothing but praise for the work of this team? In view of the Federal Government' s commitment of $58,000 to the project which benefits outback families, can the Minister give an assurance that this service will not be discontinued because of an arbitrary decision by a Brisbane-based sponsor? Furthermore, can the Minister indicate what options are available to his Department to ensure that Federal funds are in fact directed to the Mount Isa region where this service operates so that this type of interference cannot occur in the future?

—I am certainly disturbed to hear the comments in the question by Senator Reynolds. I was not aware of the situation as she described it. I will certainly endeavour to find out just what has happened--
—You are obviously not controlling your department.

—It just proves that the question is not a dorothy dixer. I certainly would be concerned if an important service like this to people in the outback of Queensland were to be cut off for some arbitrary reason as Senator Reynolds suggests. I will seek an answer from my Department as soon as possible and let the honourable senator know as soon as possible just what can be done. I would certainly intend that such a service continue. Until I have investigated the causes of what has happened I cannot give any assurances to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General whether, in the light of the answers which he has just given to Senator Durack, he will now admit that he was in no position to be personally satisfied that, as he told the Senate on 12 October, in no way, shape or fashion a breach of Commonwealth law was involved in the information which was provided to him and that, instead, he relied solely upon the advice of the Australian Federal Police Commissioner in relation to that.

—I remain wedded to the view that in relation to that part of the transcript material which bore upon the particular conversations involving Mr Jackson and raised the question of possible corruption in the administration of the early release scheme, I was satisfied that nothing in the material that I read in that respect gave rise to any question of a breach of Federal law. It was in that context, of course, that I was answering the question in the Senate on the earlier date to which Senator Peter Rae refers. As to whether or not any--
—Re-read it and you will not say that again.

—If Senator Peter Rae will curb his racing hormones and listen for half a moment to the rest of the answer it will, I hope, become clear . To the extent that wider questions arose of possible breaches of Federal law which should have been dealt with by the Federal Government, I was essentially relying in that respect on the advice given to me by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police because I was in no position, on the basis of a scanning as cursory as that which I have described, to reach any wholly satisfactory concluded opinion. But the particular context in which I was answering that question was and always has been the context of the matters immediately involving the former New South Wales Minister. The honourable senator opposite can rise triumphantly to his feet, grin away and present some sentence of mine, perhaps suggesting a context to the contrary, but my answer will remain exactly the same.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that ballot papers printed for a ballot conducted by the Australian Electoral Office for the New South Wales Branch of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union have been printed by a leading computer manufacturer, Rank Xerox (Aust.) Pty Ltd, a non-PKIU establishment? Did the Minister on 15 August assure the National Secretary of the PKIU that the facilities of the Government Printing Offices would be used unless there were real problems in those printeries meeting the deadlines required by the Electoral Office? Is it a fact that the Australian Government Printing Offices are currently not working to full capacity, particularly in New South Wales? If so, why were the ballot papers not printed at the New South Wales branch of the Government Printing Office where there are full security arrangements to protect the integrity of ballot papers?

—I am not sure that I have a sufficiently complete brief to be able to fully answer the questions put to me by Senator Childs. But what I can say is that although commercial facilities have been used on occasions it is the standing policy of the Australian Electoral Office for the printing of industrial ballot material to be carried out by the Government Printing Office unless there are real problems in those printeries-I would imagine by that it is meant to include the New South Wales branch of the Government Printing Office- meeting the deadlines required in the conduct of such elections. Where the Electoral Office's needs cannot be met by the Government Printer, commercial printing facilities are used under a contract arrangement. That is the generalised answer. As to the specific circumstances of the printing of the ballot papers for the PKIU election to which the honourable senator refers, I will seek further and better particulars from the Minister and advise the honourable senator accordingly.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did he see the Four Corners program last Saturday, which contrasted vividly the welfare of the people of Costa Rica, which has no army but instead a comprehensive health and welfare program, with neighbouring Honduras, where health and welfare services are grossly inadequate but where there is a large military establishment from which it appears, among other things, the current United States invasion of Grenada was launched? Will the Government consider establishing a special relationship between Australia and Costa Rica with the objectives of providing moral and material aid for Costa Rica? Meanwhile, will the Government take what action it can to inform the Government of the United States of Australia's support for the current non- military posture of Costa Rica in the midst of the series of ugly wars oppressing Central America, and seek positive guarantees from Washington of Costa Rica's neturality?

—I did not see the Four Corners program in question, but I am aware of it; it was drawn to my attention. To answer the first part of the question, the Government understands that the United States forces which intervened in Grenada were seaborne elements which had been diverted to the area following the coup against Maurice Bishop. To answer the next part of the question, the special position of Costa Rica as a democratic state with a neutral and pacifist foreign policy is well known to the Government. Costa Rica is certainly concerned at the threat posed to it by the increase in tensions on the borders with Nicaragua. The Foreign Minister advises me that he wrote recently to the Costa Rican Foreign Minister acknowledging the special place of Costa Rica in Central America as a country committed to the traditions of representative democracy. The Government will continue to support Costa Rica and seek to identify ways in which this can be achieved by developing Australia's bilateral relations with that country. I am advised that, given other competing priorities, it is unlikely on present indications that this would extend to the provision of material aid of the kind to which the honourable senator refers. As to the final part of the question, Costa Rica has close relations with the United States and, to the Australian Government's knowledge, it is not seeking guarantees of its neutrality from the United States Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the payment today of $10m to the Tasmanian Government on the initiative of the Federal Labor Government under the financial agreement negotiated after the High Court decision on South West Tasmania. I ask: Have moneys been available to the Tasmanian Government for many months so that the Federal Government might fulfil its promises to the Tasmanian people? Was delay in transferring funds due entirely in the first instance to Mr Gray's failure over many weeks to sign the agreement handed to him personally by the Prime Minister on 31 August and then, secondly, the failure of Mr Gray to make the necessary request or claim as provided under the agreement? Will the Government ensure that the Tasmanian people are not again held to ransom by Mr Gray, who is using them as hostages whilst he continues the politics of confrontation and bluster?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear all of the question because my listening was interrupted.
—That will not stop you answering it.

—Not at all, no; let there be no delusion about that. I did not hear all of the question because of a lot of bluster from a Tasmanian senator on the other side of the House. But that seems to be customary in Tasmanian conservative circles. The answer to the questions that Senator Tate asked relating to the availability of funds to Tasmania over a considerable period, the failure of the funds to be made available because of Mr Gray's reluctance to sign the agreement in question, and so on, is yes. I remind the Senate that the agreement was signed by the Prime Minister and Premier Gray in August, and the relevant clause of that agreement, clause 5 (2), which provides for the payments , is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Subject to the provisions of this agreement, payments of financial assistance shall be made by the Commonwealth to the State from time to time at the request of the State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quote the next bit. Come on.

—No such request was ever received from Mr Gray. As a result, the well-being of many Tasmanians, about whom Senator Walters has professed over many months to be concerned, was adversely affected. I take it that the welfare of Senator Walters was not affected, sitting over there, as she is, earning a very substantial salary. As a result of Mr Gray's failures in these matters, the Tasmanian economy has been in even more trouble than it has been in for the last two or three years. The Minister for Finance in the Federal Government responded to an urgent request only yesterday, not from Mr Gray but from ex-Senator Wriedt , the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, when, following the refusal of the Premier of Tasmania to make such a request, Mr Wriedt made the request for the provision of interim financial assistance to Tasmania. The Minister for Finance approved the making of an advance of $10m to Tasmania under this provision, and that amount was paid today.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate, particularly Senator Walters and Senator Archer, the standard bearers for the conservative forces in Tasmania, that this step was taken following a responsible and decisive intervention by the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania and not by the Premier, who has devoted a lot of time to grandstanding in relation to this issue, which is his hallmark and the hallmark of his representatives over here. This Government could not stand idly by and watch the Tasmanian Government jeopardise the wellbeing of thousands of ordinary Tasmanians. It is the well-being of ordinary Tasmanians and the economic health of the State of Tasmania that this Government is concerned about. The Tasmanian people will undoubtedly wake up to the shortcomings of their representatives in Hobart, to those of the Premier of Tasmania and, very quickly thereafter, to the shortcomings of their noisy representatives in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Leader of the Government table the papers from which he has quoted and, in particular, the agreement?
—That has been done.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I preface it by reminding him of what he said to me in answer to a question on 12 October. I quote from the last paragraph of his answer to the initial question. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: In regard to the third point raised by Senator Chaney as to whether the circumstances are such as to make the matter one of Commonwealth concern, yes, of course, it is a matter for Commonwealth concern in the general policy sense in relation to the condition of law enforcement in this country, and we make no bones about that. But equally clearly the particular matters of criminal investigation that are involved in this case do not in any way, shape or fashion raise questions of possible breaches of Commonwealth law. I have looked very carefully at this aspect to satisfy myself personally that that is so, and I am satisfied.

There is more there, but that quotation is adequate. I ask the Attorney-General, in the light of that statement and particularly his statement that he looked very carefully at this aspect to satisfy himself personally, and in the light of the answers he has given today about the fact that he relied upon the Police Commissioner other than with respect to those few pages which he read carefully, will he now agree that his answer given in the Senate on 12 October is misleading, and will he now apologise for that answer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not do anything of the kind, because the particular answer that I gave on 12 October was really quite explicit as to the context in which it was being given. The very passage that Senator Chaney read out contains the expression 'in this case', and I repeat the full sentence in which it appeared. What I said was:

ANSWER.PARA: But equally clearly the particular matters of criminal investigation that are involved in this case-
I emphasise those last three words-
do not in any way, shape or fashion raise questions of possible breaches of Commonwealth law.

The particular context in which I was answering that question and the particular case to which I was referring related to the very allegations involving a senior Minister of the New South Wales Government which had been the subject of reference by the Commonwealth to the New South Wales police force and which had been the subject of report by Commissioner Abbott to the New South Wales Government, which report was the subject matter of Senator Chaney's question.

Senator Chaney's question was not canvassing the whole content of the Federal narcotics investigation in the course of which this matter arose. Senator Chaney 's question was canvassing, as did all the questions at that time, the particular circumstances involved in the allegations about a particular senior New South Wales official. That was the context in which I was answering. That is the context in which I continue to answer to this day and, under those circumstances, I simply shall not even begin to treat with any respect the kind of question that has just been put to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Since the Minister has the question in front of him, would he look again at the question which I asked of him? Does he agree that my question was in fact much wider than one limited to the narrow question of the particular matters affecting Mr Jackson?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not agree.
—Read it out.

—In respect of the relevant part, I am perfectly happy to do so because the answer speaks for itself. The relevant part of the question opened with a reference to the Abbott report, and then Senator Chaney, in his second sentence, stated:

ANSWER.PARA: In that report it is stated that information on early release of prisoners was obtained by telephone taps by Commonwealth Police during surveillance of 'drug traffickers involved in international drug smuggling who by covert means had associated themselves with the Minister of the Crown responsible for the early release of prisoners'.

He then referred to other aspects of the Abbott report which were related squarely to that context. The context was that of allegations involving a Minister of the Crown and official corruption. It was in that context that I gave my reply and it is in that context that I do so today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister outline the Government's position with regard to American intervention in Grenada? Why has the Government indicated that Australia will not participate in a Commonwealth peacekeeping force, a concept which apparently enamours those opposite?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position about Grenada has been pretty clear right from the beginning and quite clear since the meeting of Cabinet on Monday.
—Really?

—From the interjections I divine that some members of the Opposition think the Government's position was not as clear as it might have been last week. Let me say, first of all, that one of the interesting aspects about the Opposition was that it was absolutely clear on what the Government should have done about Grenada over the weekend. It was absolutely clear about its position. It was the only political party in the western world that was. For example, on Sunday on television I saw the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr MacKellar-this time he was on television; he did not just have a set under his arm-in the course of a quite lengthy discourse about foreign policy, suggest that the Government's position in Australia was part of some move to the Left by the Labor Party in Australia on international issues. It was the most plausible rubbish I have ever seen from an Opposition spokesman talking about foreign affairs issues, trying to make a thesis out of a set of straw facts.

ANSWER.PARA: The same could be said about the performance over the weekend of the Leader of the Opposition in relation to Grenada. It was quite clear that the Leader of the Opposition was prepared to lead the charge of the Australian light brigade to Grenada, if it became necessary-something which he refrained from doing on a previous occasion when he had the real opportunity to do so.

In terms of international views about Grenada, as distinct from the views of the Opposition in this country, let me say this: I have had the opportunity of looking at the expressions of opinion about the United States intervention in Grenada as expressed by many governments throughout the world. Those expressions of opinion vary from very strong criticism by countries such as Sweden, France and other European countries to, at the other end of the spectrum, a view expressed by the Government of Guatemala, of all places, which welcomed-the only country, I believe, which did-the United States intervention with all the ramifications.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Grenadians?

—Senator Lewis says: 'What about the Grenadians?' The Grenadians, Senator Lewis and the Government of Guatemala welcomed, according to Senator Lewis, the United States intervention. That matter needs some explanation. Let me be quite clear about the situation of world opinion on this issue.
—What about ASEAN?
—I do not wish to take up other interjections but Senator Rae, for goodness sake, invites me to comment on what ASIO thought about it.
—ASEAN.

—You said ASIO, but ASEAN, ASIO, it does not matter in the spirit of your interjection. Does Senator Rae want to know what the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations said about it? Is he suggesting that any of the ASEAN countries, either collectively or on their own, welcomed the intervention? I would like him to show me the material which suggests that, because it has not been available to the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the Government's response, there was grave difficulty, as there was for all governments, in finding out the precise set of circumstances which had arisen in Grenada. All governments had that difficulty-Canada, the European countries and Australia-but not the Opposition in Australia. It was the only group that did not have any problems about that. As I said earlier, the Opposition placed itself in a unique position in relation to the situation which developed.

The Government's response was a cautious one, in the circumstance of trying to establish the facts about what had taken place. When the facts were established, on Monday the Government issued a statement about it which, amongst other things , said that there would be no commitment by the Australian Government to a peacekeeping force in Grenada. The reasons for that, as I divine them, are quite clear. For many years, for many decades-since the Australian intervention, I believe, in Sudan, but certainly since the Boer War-Australian troops have been involved in one way or another in pursuing the escapades of other countries in places remote from Australia.

It is not the Government's view that the very good relationship which this Government has with the United States of America in any way requires that commitment, just as such a commitment would not be given by the United States, I imagine, if Australia invaded Timor, for example. We would not expect a commitment of support from the United States in such a circumstance and it is not entitled to expect a commitment of support from us in what are very similar circumstances. There will be no commitment of Australian forces to a peacekeeping force in Grenada. The reasons are historically valid-valid in terms of international affairs and valid in terms of the best interests of this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to his answer to Senator Durack yesterday concerning allegations by Mr Bob Bottom, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It is not my knowledge that the Australian Federal Police has any other information in its possession which would give credence or support to what Mr Bottom is saying. I will inquire further of the Special Minister of State to see whether that is so.
I refer also to his answer to Senator Rae, in which he said:

It was in the light of Mr Bottom's allegations, which appear on their face to have about as much substance as Mr Sinclair's, that I asked Mr Beazley, with his senior police officers, to check the material in question to see whether there was any foundation for those allegations.

In the Attorney-General's Press statement of 28 October he said that he would check this matter out fully with his colleague or the Federal Police. I ask the Attorney-General: Has he checked this matter out either with his colleague or with the Federal Police and, if so, with what result?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have raised the question with my colleague. I have not yet had a fully concluded response from him except inso- far as the question has now been raised of a judicial inquiry to be held in New South Wales in relation to which my colleague the Special Minister of State this morning informed me of his position and that of the Federal Police and, indeed, the Government. Our position would be to make available to that judicial commission of inquiry in New South Wales all material of relevance that is within the possession of the Commonwealth Police and which we have the legal capacity to make available. It will be appreciated by the honourable senator that there are some limitations as to what can be made available under the explicit terms of the Telecommunications Interception Act. It may be that that may impose some constraints.

ANSWER.PARA: I have no further information as to whether there is any specific material in the possession of the Commonwealth police which specifically advances the cause of Mr Bottom's allegations. I await further information from the Special Minister of State on that. I have heard nothing from him to suggest that my answer was in any way inaccurate, at least so far as it bore upon the particular subject matter of the transcripts which have so far received public attention. As I indicated yesterday, I am not really in the business, nor is the Government , of confirming or denying any other aspect of the subject matter of those transcripts, because to do so would be quite irresponsible, given the nature and sensitivity of the material involved. Thus, I think it is unlikely that I will be able to say anything more on the public record about this, even when I get a full and final report from the Special Minister of State. I believe it will be the case that the Government's position, as I have just described it, will be that anything in our possession that bears upon the accuracy or otherwise of Mr Bottom's allegations will be made available to the New South Wales commission of inquiry to the extent of our legal capacity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show that private foreign capital continues to flow into Australia at a significant rate, and that this trend is increasing? What short term problems will these capital movements cause the Australian economy? As private capital inflow has always been a strong measure of business confidence in the economy, what credence can be placed in the claims by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard, on 6 October in the House of Representatives that the Government does not have the support of the business sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last part of Senator Richardson's question asked what credence could be placed in the claims of the discredited former Treasurer. I think the answer to that is quite clearly none. No more credence can be placed in those claims than can be placed in his, to say the least, highly misleading statements -the Standing Orders preclude me from using stronger language-which he endorsed in the week prior to the last Federal election when he said that the then Government was facing a prospective deficit in 1983-84 on a no policy change basis of $6 billion when, in fact, he had been told by the Treasury Secretary that the prospective deficit being faced at that time was $9.6 billion. So no credence, I suggest, could be placed in anything that the discredited former Treasurer and evidently aspiring Leader of the Opposition might claim about anything.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn now to the other matters raised in Senator Richardson's question. I have statistics that show that for the September quarter of 1983-the last quarter for which figures are available-private capital inflow into Australia was $1.847 billion, which is of the order of magnitude to which we have become accustomed in recent times. Therefore, there has been no falling away in capital inflow. That fact, of course, reflects confidence in the management of the Australian economy. It is a recognition that Australia now has a government which exercises fiscal responsibility. Statistics released last week show a very substantial fall in the rate of inflation, a fall which, though not specifically predicted in the Budget Papers for the September quarter, was predicted for the financial year as a whole. It now seems at least possible that the consumer price index increase of 7.5 per cent for the whole year as forecast in the Budget Papers may even be a little above that which is likely to occur.

Heavy capital movements into Australia, the subject of another part of Senator Richardson's question, do cause some secondary problems. They obviously expand the money supply and place pressures on the Australian dollar for revaluation. To some extent, of course, those pressures have been reflected in recent statistics and recent movements. That is a problem which is recognised by the Government and to which the Government continues to address itself.

In conclusion, in a report published a couple of weeks ago-I think in the Australian Financial Review-attention was drawn to a very significant fall in capital inflow in the June quarter of 1983 as against the June quarter of 1982. Whether that was a good thing or a bad thing may be a matter of opinion, but in the June quarter of 1983 capital inflow into Australia fell by 60 per cent compared with the same quarter the year before. That, however, presented a very distorted picture of what was actually going on as capital inflow in the June 1982 quarter was at an extraordinarily high level. On a year on year basis, or on a trend basis, private capital continues to come into Australia at a rate slightly below that which had applied in the previous couple of years. But that should be seen in the context of the fact that in the previous couple of years- that is the 1981-82 and 1982-83 years-private capital inflow was at an unprecedented high. In the first of those years it was $9.7 billion; in the next year it was $8.4 billion. These figures were probably higher than is economically desirable, certainly in the long term.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the tapes concerning the early release of New South Wales prisoners. I ask him: Was there anything anywhere at all on the tapes suggesting arrangements for the payment of any money to any person?
—We ought to have some tapes on you and Askin.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order about the interjection of Senator Grimes which was highly offensive to Senator Sir John Carrick.
—I do not understand how it was offensive. I said we should have some tapes on Senator Sir John Carrick and Sir Robert Askin.
—Senator Grimes, you should withdraw the reflection on Senator Sir John Carrick. Please withdraw.

—With respect, I said we should have a tape of conversations between Senator Sir John Carrick and Sir Robert Askin. I did not imply there was anything on those tapes that was offensive or otherwise. If Senator Sir John Carrick is concerned about what might be on such tapes, I can understand his agitation.

—I rise to the point of order, Mr Deputy President. I did not raise the point of order, but I now invite Senator Grimes to inform this Senate at any time of anything he knows concerning anything to my detriment, with regard to either a former Premier of New South Wales or anything else. I do that because repeatedly Senator Grimes makes innuendos, and I reject every form of innuendo that he seeks to make.
—Mr Deputy President, on what I assume--

—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. This is not an appropriate time for the invitation to be taken up. Standing order 418 prohibits any reflections on honourable senators. The implication of the interjection by Senator Grimes is a clear reflection on Senator Sir John Carrick and I direct him to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—I now call on the Attorney-General to answer the question.

—Mr Deputy President, I hate to interrupt this dialogue; it is far more interesting than my answer will be. As I recall Senator Sir John Carrick's question, he asked whether there was any mention in the transcripts I read of anything which suggested that arrangements had been made about the payment of money to persons in relation to the early release of prisoners scheme . I do not propose to give any detail about the content of those transcripts or to say anything which would either confirm or deny any proposition such as that advanced by Senator Sir John Carrick. All I can do in this respect is repeat what I said yesterday in answer to one of Senator Chaney's questions, that there were passages in the transcript which had an element of ambiguity about them, as to whether the subject matter of the conversation was something which might be regarded as part and parcel of a ministerial carrying out of ordinary portfolio responsibilities or, on the other hand, as I said yesterday had something about them containing a suspicion of criminality or corruption. There were passages in the tapes that had that element of ambiguity. Beyond that I do no propose to answer Senator Sir John Carrick's question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. Since the Attorney-General has said that his perusal of the tapes was directed towards determining whether there was any federal offence or likelihood of a federal offence, quite clearly if there was a discussion on money that would have demonstrated the likelihood of a federal offence. I ask him: Was that ambiguity concerned with conversations about the payment of money?

—Yes. In case there is any ambiguity about that response, let me add this: Yes, the passages in question were ambiguous as to whether or not the subject matter of the conversation did concern money or did not. If there have been explicit references to money in the transcripts, clearly it would not have been possible for me to answer in this place as I have done. The whole question in issue was whether the subject matter of the conversations was to be regarded as being about money or whether, rather, it was in fact wholly innocent. It is that element of ambiguity which caused me to answer as I did and which in fact caused Commissioner Abbott to conclude as he did in his intitial report to the New South Wales Government.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I would like to know what proportion of Commonwealth drivers are female, where they are employed and what steps the Government is taking to increase that proportion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Currently some 442 Commonwealth drivers look after the needs of members of parliament, public servants and officers of statutory authorities. Of those 442, there are no female drivers. Of course, the Government is committed to a policy of increasing the percentage of females in such occupations within the Commonwealth Public Service, and I might add that we have seen a quite dramatic change come over this Parliament, in which there are 19 female members, on both sides of the House. It is interesting to note, however, that the ratio in this regard is more than two to one in Labor's favour. It seems obvious that a policy of discrimination has been practised in the Department of Administrative Services, led by various Ministers from conservative governments. There has never been an attempt to overcome the obvious discrimination that exists. Despite this, many members will acknowledge that we have from time to time been picked up by female drivers from the hire car services and the taxi service which are sometimes provided when an inadequate number of Commonwealth cars are available for members of parliament at a particular time.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1975, when the Liberal-Country Party came back into office, there has been no recruitment at all of drivers to the Department of Administrative Services. The Government is changing that situation and is inviting applications from interested parties to become drivers for the Department. The Government has indicated that it will apply the principles of equal opportunity in this respect and therefore women drivers who have the competence and meet the criteria will be given equal consideration for such appointments. I just happened to look at the number of persons here representing the journalism profession. There are 14 journalists in the Press Gallery, if my mental arithmetic is correct, and half of them are females. So it seems that no discrimination is practised there, even though discrimination was practised by previous Liberal-Country Party governments. It is the Government's intention not only in respect of the Sex Discrimination Bill but also in practice to see that women are given fair representation right throughout the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to the disturbing report on Capital 7 television news last week that a person whom it was alleged had defrauded the Department of Social Security of some $10,000 had been relieved of restitution and/or prosecution as a result of the Minister's intervention and direction to his Department not to prosecute? Can the Minister confirm whether the allegation is true, or substantially true, and if so can he advise the Senate of the name of the person involved and the circumstances of the case? Did any intervention arise from representations by the honourable member for Fraser? Are decisions about prosecution and the restitution of moneys lost through fraud normally a departmental function? Finally, will he explain to the Senate the reasons for his action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have heard a second- hand report of such a program on Capital 7, although I have not seen details of it. From memory, I believe it can refer to only one case. That was a case which I believe involved not $10,000 but approximately half that amount. It was to go before the court. I received representation on a couple of occasions at least-again, I am speaking from memory-concerning this case. I receive representations on many occasions from people on both sides of this Parliament about such cases and about the prosecution of such cases. On this occasion, after examining the situation and talking to officers of my Department I decided that I would use the discretion I had and that prosecution would not proceed. I would expect that in the vast majority of cases I would not do such a thing. The only cases on which one can take action are those about which representations are made by members of parliament or others. I cannot remember the individual's name and I cannot recall the exact details at the moment, nor do I believe it would be proper to expose publicly the circumstances of such a person, and probably the person's name, in this Parliament, although I will consider that.

ANSWER.PARA: Representations were made to me on this occasion by the honourable member for Fraser, Mr Fry. As I say, on other occasions I have had representations from people on both sides of this Parliament. In other similar cases I had representations from an ex-Minister in the previous Government. It may be that Senator Messner does not believe there should be any ministerial discretion in such situations. It may be that previous Ministers have not exercised such discretion; I would not know. In this situation there is such a power. I had to make a judgment. I made that judgment. I would have to consider whether I should give the personal details of why I made that judgment. As to my decision on whether to proceed with the prosecution, my memory is that it had nothing to do with restitution of the funds. I will check on those facts and let the honourable senator have the details later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to reports in which the Tasmanian Minister for Health blames the Federal Government for delaying a major nursing home development which he claims would immediately overcome bed problems at the Launceston General Hospital? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether these claims are correct? Is it true that the Masonic Nursing Home development has been delayed because of tardiness on the part of this Government? In any case, how would the Masonic Nursing Home development solve the bed problems of the Launceston General Hospital?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the question should have been directed to me in my capacity as the Minister for Social Security rather than as the Minister representing the Minister for Health. In the statement referred to, Mr Cleary blamed me personally for the bed situation at the Launceston General Hospital and for the delay, as he put it, in the approval of the project at the Masonic Nursing Home. I think it is worth while looking at the facts. I realise that Mr Cleary has been under considerable attack in the last week by the Press in Tasmania and that he had to cast around to throw a stone somewhere.

ANSWER.PARA: On this occasion I believe the facts should be put. First of all, as Senator Coates and other Tasmanians would know, there is a problem at the Launceston General Hospital. There has been a problem for many years. One of the causes of that problem is the fact that stage 2 of the building of the hospital has not proceeded. The previous Government, in its seven years in office, absolutely refused to make any commitment to fund stage 2 of that hospital, despite the fact that the member for Bass was a Minister and despite the fact that he continually claimed that he supported such a proposal. The second fact is that there is a problem in the Launceston General Hospital in that there are 550-odd nursing home beds in the north and north-eastern region of Tasmania and 104 of them should be acute beds in the Launceston General Hospital. The problems have been: Firstly, the lack of construction of nursing home beds in the north-east of Tasmania in the last few years; secondly, the closing down of a couple of nursing homes in recent times; and, thirdly, the fact that the hospitals have had a lack of funds in recent years and have been unable to extend their operations.

The facts about the Masonic Nursing Home and nursing home beds generally in the north and north-east in Tasmania are these: The Masonic Nursing Home sought approval initially for 30 hostel beds. In fact, that approval and approval for the capital funding of those beds was given. The Masonic Nursing Home decided not to proceed with those hostel beds until it had received approval for 40 beds specifically allocated for senile dementia patients, 20 respite beds in a nursing home and a day centre. As distinct from approval for funding, that approval in principle was given by the Commonwealth Department of Health in January 1983. All funds for the construction of nursing home beds in the year 1983-84 have been allocated. Those funds were allocated by the previous Government-not this Government. They were allocated for the period from November 1982 to January 1983. This Government is in the process of making approvals. I am informed that my Department will be giving me recommendations in the next week for approvals for 1984-85. That is the way in which approvals proceed. That is the way in which approvals are done and have been done for many years.

Until the article in the Examiner today-I understand that it referred to a letter that Mr Cleary had sent to me the day before yesterday-I had not been approached by Mr Cleary about the Masonic Nursing Home proposal, although I had been approached by members on both sides of this House. Whether or not the Masonic Nursing Home receives funds-I certainly am in favour of its project which I believe involves an important and advanced concept-depends on approvals for the whole of Australia. For me to approve the construction of a nursing home of this type in isolation from all the other approvals, quite apart from the fact that it happens to be the home town from which I come, would be quite improper and I would create considerable criticism from both sides of this Parliament, and so I should.

Apparently, Mr Cleary claimed that sudden approval in the next week or so of these nursing home beds would solve the problems of beds in the Launceston General Hospital. There are 104 long stay patients in the Launceston General Hospital. Many of those patients are in what should be acute beds. The building of the nursing home by the Masonic Nursing Home would not take up those 104 beds and it certainly would not be completed before another 12 months at least. Mr Cleary should stop grandstanding. He should consult more with the Federal Department of Health and his own colleagues to see what can be done with the situation in the Launceston General Hospital, the problems of which have been obvious to everybody who lives in that town and obvious to everybody who has had anything to do with the hospital in the last several years. For Mr Cleary to suddenly blame this Government and this Minister for the mess that he and his Department are in is improper and indecent, and is just indulging in party politics. I reject the claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Finance to a media release by the Tasmanian Wilderness Society of 20 October which claims that an interdepartmental confrontation in Canberra is blocking urgently needed funding for rangers in Tasmania's world heritage area. Will the Minister comment on the claim that officials of the Department of the Treasury are apparently blocking funds for 12 rangers which were promised by Prime Minister Hawke? Given the large number of rafters, cruise tourists and bush walkers who are expected in the region this summer and the fact that November and December are the most perilous months of the rafting season, I ask the Minister: Firstly, will the Government, as a matter of priority, take steps to resolve this interdepartmental problem so as to ensure that the necessary funds are made available to employ rangers during the summer months; secondly, what action is being taken by the Australian Government in its discussions with the Tasmanian Government to facilitate the development of a management plan for the South West heritage area to protect the unique environment and to ensure the safety of those many people who use it; and thirdly, what action is the Australian Government taking to ensure the use of rangers to protect the world heritage features of the area, in particular the Huon pines and the priceless archaeological records in the Franklin caves?

—I presume that Senator Missen was not here when I answered a similar question yesterday, although it was not as extensive. The effective additions to yesterday's question cover matters outside the strict responsibility of the Minister for Finance. I will approach the relevant Minister to see whether he has any information to provide on that part of the question. As to whether the Government will seek to resolve this question, I will certainly endeavour to have that done. The essential features which I outlined yesterday were that the Prime Minister approached the Tasmanian Premier on, I think, 31 August; I cannot remember the precise date. There was a time lapse of almost six weeks prior to the Premier responding. When the Premier did respond he significantly expanded the ambit of the claim he was making. That, I understand, was the cause of the delay. I will see what additional information can be found.

—I ask a supplementary question. That does not answer the kernel of my question which was whether there is an interdepartmental confrontation in Canberra blocking the use of the funds. In other words, I am asking whether it is inside the department-the Treasury-in Canberra. The Minister has not answered that.
—Not to my knowledge, but I will make further inquiries.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a letter circulated by a group of doctors in Tasmania who are canvassing their colleagues for funds for an advertisement in local papers stating that Medicare is detrimental to the best care of patients, will lower the standard of treatment and is intended as nationalisation of medical practice? Does the Minister not agree that this is misleading to the public and mischievous?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be surprised to know that I have seen such a letter which was forwarded to some of my medical colleagues in Tasmania.
—Are you on the list?

—I am not on the list, unfortunately, Senator Coates. The letter in fact comes as a result of a forum which was held in Tasmania on 7 October which no-one in this place would be surprised to know was organised by the General Practitioners Society in Australia and was funded by certain pharmaceutical firms in this country. At that meeting, apparently, some 49 doctors volunteered to put their names to a full page advertisement in the Hobart Mercury stating their opposition to Medicare. The person who wrote the letter and organised the meeting was Doctor Denis P. Mackey who is well known to most of us and who was formally President of the General Practitioners Society in Australia and, I believe, editor of its journal the GP Society. He was also previously associated with a well known right wing political party in this country which has since gone into oblivion.

ANSWER.PARA: Many people listed were willing to sign the advertisement. Some of them are general practitioners and some are consultants, including a well known consultant who, a couple of years ago in the 1980 election, allegedly representing the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons, put in a party political advertisement urging people to vote against the Australian Labor Party . The spouse of a well known senator from Tasmania apparently is also willing to have his name included. He was also formerly director of the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd, which is a fund organised by and for doctors. I hope that the spouse of that person will declare an interest when any further Medicare legislation is introduced.

It was intended to put an advertisement in the Hobart Mercury costing about $1, 800 for which doctors were being asked to contribute $20 a head. I think the intended wording of the advertisement is very interesting. It goes:
We the following medical practitioners declare that we are totally committed to the provision of private medical and hospital care for all patients who wish it.
I do not see anything offensive about that. I doubt whether anyone else here sees anything offensive about people providing private medical care for those who wish it. It continues:
We regard government intrusion into private practice as detrimental to the best care of these patients.

I always find that an interesting comment in an advertisement of this type because there has been government intervention and intrusion into private practice in this country from time immemorial. For instance, some of the very people who have signed this advertisement have put people into private hospitals which receive public funds and public subsidies and they are perfectly willing to be paid through private health insurance agents such as the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Ltd which are licensed by government and whose practices are protected by government. The next line says:
The Government's proposed Medicare scheme will inevitably lower the standard of treatment our private patients can obtain.

The words 'our private' are cut out. They obviously were not willing to put in an advertisement that they in any way may have been affected in how they could practice. So they cut out the words 'our private'. The final sentence says:
We therefore reject the Medicare scheme which prohibits patients from insuring for private medical care of their choice-

The words 'which prohibits patients from insuring for private medical care of their choice' are crossed out because suddenly even those doctors realised that that was an outrageous and a lying statement. The letter goes on:
. . . and the intended nationalisation of medical practice.
I think that hysterical advertisements like this are an insult to the intelligence of patients. It is an insult to request doctors to pay money to put an advertisement such as this in a newspaper.

I repeat: Medicare is about health insurance; Medicare is about the proper provision of health insurance; Medicare is about enabling people to pay a fair share towards the health care system in this country and enabling people more easily to collect refunds as a result of that insurance. It is not about the nationalisation of medical practice. The tragedy of this situation is that at least 49 doctors-and there may be more-are willing to kick in and put in the Press an advertisement like this which is misleading and which is unnecessarily worrying to patients. They are also, as a result of that meeting, apparently willing to refuse to bulk bill and to see patients such as pensioners who would normally be bulk billed. They are, as I have said on another occasion in this place, willing to fight Medicare down to the last patient but they are not willing, apart from kicking in $20 each for an advertisement, which would be cigarette money to most of them if they smoked, to put at risk their considerable incomes.

I suggest that if these doctors are willing to ignore the existence of Medicare and treat only those patients who cannot insure either through Medicare or the voluntary health funds and those patients who are willing to pay the full cost of their medical services at the inflated prices they charge, they should do so. But they will not do so because if they did they would all go broke. That is the nub of the matter. They are willing to carry on in this way as long as their incomes are not affected. They are a disgrace to the medical profession. As I said once before, they are even a disgrace to the political profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some answers to questions that have been raised in this place. On 18 October Senator Primmer asked a question concerning the termination of the appointment of Sir Victor Garland as the High Commissioner in London, and seeking confirmation that Sir Victor's full salary is paid to him by the the Department of Foreign Affairs without the deduction of any tax. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers: Sir Victor Garland's appointment as the Australian High Commissioner in London will terminate on 20 December this year. The Commissioner of Taxation advises that the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the disclosing of details of the affairs of particular taxpayers.

—On 21 October 1983 Senator Missen asked a question of Senator Grimes, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs in my absence, concerning the establishment of an Arab League office in Australia. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following supplementary answer: The Government will ensure that no Palestine Liberation Organisation representatives will work in any Arab League office which may be established and will do so by making clear that this condition applies to the establishment of any Arab League representation. It can, of course, make use of the visa issuing power. As Senator Grimes indicated in his answer, the establishment of an Arab League office would also be conditional on assurances that an office would not be involved in promoting boycotts of Australian firms. The Prime Minister has said that the activities of any such office would be carefully monitored.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Chaney asked me whether the communication between New South Wales Minister Mr Jackson and Mr Harris, which has achieved subsequent notoriety, was about the prospective release of prisoners. I have asked for the transcript to be checked on this particular point and I can confirm that, as I indicated yesterday was probably the case, the answer is yes. I also mention for the record that the prisoners in question were from Broken Hill, not from Bathurst as I inadvertently said in my answer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1983 Senator Elstob asked a question concerning Australian action on disarmament issues at the United Nations General Assembly concerning a statement on Australia's role by the Minister for Foreign Affairs who has provided the following further answer: Australia is taking an active role at the United Nations General Assembly on disarmament questions. In conjunction with New Zealand, Australia is pursuing the question of a comprehensive nuclear test ban. Australia is also working to ensure that the preparations for the third nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty review conference in 1985 are launched successfully.
