The Government is striving to enhance the international effort to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and to reinforce support for the NPT.

QUESTION.PARA: Other disarmament issues that Australia will pursue include advancing international agreement to avoid the arms race entering outer space, reduction of military budgets, the curbing of the arms trade and the black market trade in arms and the outlawing of chemical weapons. The Minister for Foreign Affairs addressed the General Assembly on 4 October 1983 when he referred to a number of these issues in more detail. Copies of Mr Hayden's speech are available in the Parliamentary Library.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two matters which I want to raise, Mr Deputy President. The first is a point of order which relates to something which happened during Question Time.
—You should have taken the point of order at the time.
—I raised it then, and you told me to raise it at the end of Question Time. The second matter is a matter of personal explanation. Which would you like first?
—It is not normal to have an option. Make your personal explanation first, then make your request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Has she been misrepresented?
—I claim that my spouse has been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes, in his usual untruthful way and by innuendo, which he has already been pulled up for in Question Time, claimed that my spouse -certainly he was referring to me as he well knows-was a director of a health fund. That is not true. My husband happens to be an honourary member of a board of a voluntary health fund. He gives it a considerable amount of his time. He does not receive one penny in payment, nor has he any self-interest in it at all . It is quite beyond the grubby little mind of Senator Grimes-
—Order! Senator Walters, would you just make a personal explanation of where your husband has been misrepresented.

—I am trying to explain to you, Mr Deputy President, why Senator Grimes would not understand. He should not judge other people on his own low standards because there are people in this community who are willing to do things for others in their own time. I do not expect Senator Grimes to understand but I do expect other honourable senators to understand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement. I claim to have been misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for one thing. I believe that if Senator Walters reads the Hansard she will find that I described the person concerned as being formerly a director of the Medical Benefit Fund of Australia.
—He was never a director.
—I am sorry if 'director' is not the correct term. I should have said that he was a member of the board of a voluntary health fund which is for doctors and for members.
—Honorary.

—It depends on one's definition of 'honorary'. Perhaps some people consider that a fares-paid trip overseas for that member of the board and his spouse to attend a conference is considerable remuneration. The simple fact is that to be a member of the medical profession and to be on the board of a voluntary health fund at the same time is quite clearly a conflict of interest. I have no intention of going on with this nonsense in this way.
—It is a question of standards.
—It is a question of standards, yes.
—Do I have a right of reply, Mr Deputy President?
—Personal explanation must not develop into a debate.

—by leave-Earlier today in Question Time Senator Chaney asked that Senator Button table both the paper he was reading from as well as an agreement between Mr Grey, the Premier of Tasmania, and Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister, from which he quoted. Whilst Senator Button tabled the paper from which he was reading in his answer to Senator Tate's dorothy dixer, he did not table the agreement. I have before me the papers, but I have no agreement. I would like to see the agreement he was quoting from which he was asked to table.

—I should rule on this point because there is some area of confusion about this matter. Senator Chaney, as I understood him, asked for the document from which Senator Button was quoting to be tabled. Standing order 363 provides that a document relating to public affairs quoted from by a Minister of the Crown, unless it is confidential, may be tabled. The problem is that, over the years, there has been some variation in interpretation of what is meant by ' quoted from'. That matter has been considered recently by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. In its current report on this subject it recommended that the proper interpretation of those words should be that the documents quoted from are only those documents in the possession of the senator concerned in the chamber. Although this report has not been considered by the Senate yet I feel obliged to accept that view of the Committee. Therefore the Leader of the Government in the Senate cannot be required to table any documents other than those he had in the chamber at the time of answering the question. Whether he wishes to table any other matter is a matter for him.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The confusion and contradictions of the Government's taxation policy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition directs the Senate's attention to the confusion and contradictions of the Government's taxation policy. I believe that the taxation policy is both confusing and contradictory. It is confusing because the Australian Labor Party has reneged on so many of its election promises and is pursuing policies which it criticised so strongly when it was in opposition. Its policy is contradictory because of recent conflicting statements by Ministers, not the least being by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), on whether Australians will be subject to higher personal taxes or whether these taxes will be reduced. If we add to this mix the fear factor engendered by continuing speculation about capital gains or other wealth taxes and the ever present prospect of new death duties, it is little wonder that the Australian community views this eight-month old Government with a degree of suspicion and cynicism on its taxation policy. Taxation policies of another kind which apply to the resources development industry are equally clouded in confusion and uncertainty. The Government has said it intends introducing a resources rent tax on coal and oil in 1984-85.
—That is just not correct. You ought to know better than to say that.

—That is the statement being made. The Government is yet to reveal the details of the resources tax. Given the constitutional and political difficulties associated with changing the taxing arrangement for coal, we have to assume that oil looms as the preferred target for the Government's resources tax. There is mounting concern that such a move will have serious implications for the level of oil exploration in this country. This week, the Managing Director of the Australian Oil and Gas Corporation Ltd predicted that only the big oil companies would survive in a resourses rent tax era, resulting in a further reduction in Australian ownership and overall competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most serious aspect of the Government's confused and contradictory taxation policies has been in relation to aged persons and the proposals and decisions that have been taken by the Government in this area. A decision has been made to change the taxing arrangements for lump sum superannuation payments . This was announced in the May mini-Budget. This was a totally unexpected shock to thousands upon thousands of ordinary Australians who had been making prudent provision for their retirement. The worst feature of this change was not only that it was, in no way, forecast in any of Labor's pre-election statements, but also that it came so soon after denials of the change were made by the Prime Minister at the National Economic Summit Conference. Not content with hitting one group of older Australians in May, the Government chose to introduce what amounts to a selective capital gains tax with its August Budget decision to bring in an assets test for pensioners.

My colleague Senator Messner will deal with these matters in greater detail, but I simply mention them as aspects of the Government's taxing policy which have been contradictory in terms of earlier statements that were made by Government spokesmen and which are certainly confusing to those people who now have to rearranged their affairs. I think these are classic examples of ill- thought through policies which have been foisted upon an unsuspecting community, resulting in maximum confusion and concern because of the incomplete nature of the proposals. When proposals are announced and subsequently changed, there is a great deal of uncertainty and confusion among those who will be affected by them or who suspect they might become affected by them. The community as a whole has been confused and disappointed by the Government's election confidence trick of promising immediate personal income tax cuts for six million Australians. That was a quite specific policy promise in February.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

— It was a very definite policy promise and it is worth recalling the pledge of the Prime Minister from the stage of the Sydney Opera House on 16 February this year when, in talking about the Australian Labor Party's total income tax package, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Its key elements include immediate reductions in income tax for almost 6 million Australian taxpayers, with the greatest tax cuts going to those on the lowest incomes who have suffered most under Mr Fraser's policies. A taxpayer without dependants earning $225 a week, for example, will get a tax cut of $4.76 a week.

Enough has been written about that election campaign, and all of the promises that were made throughout it, for it now to be positively stated that this promise was a cynical attempt to buy votes and was included against the advice of more rational people at that time who knew that it could not be responsibly offered or achieved. No amount of post-election posturing and shock horror over the level of the inherited deficit can hide the fact that Mr Hawke and his advisers knew that this was an unkeepable promise at the time that it was made. So much for that warm rhetoric that we heard in February of this year. Mr Hawke said at that time: 'Labor's new tax scales will be introduced in its first budget'. But the cold reality of the August Budget produced a much different picture. Absolutely nothing was done in the Budget to restructure the tax scales along the lines of Mr Hawke's promised six new steps. If honourable senators opposite want to challenge that statement, as Senator Button did, I think it is fair enough to repeat the statements that were made by government members with regard to income tax cuts. In the economic plan that was outlined in February the government said:
The Labor Government will implement a new package of (tax) policies . . . This will include tax cuts for low and middle income earners . . .
I have already referred to the statement:
. . . new tax scales will be introduced in the first budget.
Mr Willis in March 1983, again before the election, said:
. . . under Labor's proposed tax scales average tax rates for all taxpayers with incomes below $60,000 will be less . . .

That is the sort of statement that was made. It was quite unequivocal. I believe that for us to have had introduced in August a Budget which ignored all of those certainly sustains our contention that there is a contradiction between what has been said and what has been done, and there is confusion for those who are affected by these changes. The tax relief was certainly not provided. The scales remain the same and the Government has set itself to benefit from the revenue windfall as people move into higher tax brackets with higher incomes. On top of this Australians were hit by a series of new indirect tax charges in this Budget , and this illustrates one of the truly great contradictions in Labor's policy. The Labor Party that criticised so much the inequalities of indirect taxes has now effectively embraced this means of boosting government revenue. It not only criticised the inequalities that it saw, but also actually voted against proposals of the former Government to move to a broader indirect tax although they were very modest changes that were proposed at the time. Through its choice in the areas it has hit, the Government has been guilty of imposing the type of regressive indirect impost about which it got so self-righteous when it was in Opposition.

I think there should be no doubt about where the Opposition stands on this matter. The former Treasurer has many times put the view that the tax base should be widened to move away from such a heavy reliance on personal income tax . When we tried to make a small start in this direction when we were in government we were greeted by howls of outrage and by parliamentary veto from members of the now Government and the Australian Democrats. The point that Mr Howard, as Treasurer, was making was that indirect taxation is not necessarily regressive, that is, it does not necessarily impose the same burden on all people regardless of ability to pay so long as the Government targets the tax properly. For instance, an often quoted example is a levy on restaurant services , a levy which would affect to a much greater degree the more affluent members of the community who more frequently use such facilities. A tax can become regressive when it is applied to the most widely used goods or services, and this of course is exactly what the Government has done in its first Budget. The new indexed excise charges on petrol, cigarettes and beer will impact on the widest cross-section of the community imaginable and make a mockery of Labor's previous piety on indirect taxation.

Let me turn briefly to personal income tax because it is here that we find a current situation of confusion and contradiction which is very relevant to this matter of public importance the Opposition is bringing before the Senate today. The Prime Minister, having failed to deliver his tax cuts for six million people , now seems determined to have a bit each way on personal taxation if he sees any political advantage in statements that he can make to a particular audience. Last Thursday week he launched one of his customary diatribes against the Opposition in the House of Representatives. This time his subject was the action by the Senate in rejecting the Government's iniquitous retrospective taxation legislation which would have imposed punitive new taxation obligations which had not previously existed. The Prime Minister threatened Australians with the possibility of higher personal income taxes as a result of the Senate's action. Not only that, but also he was hypocritical enough to put the revenue loss in terms of what it would mean to the personal taxation burden of the average wage earner. For someone with his record of failing to reduce taxes this was a little hard to accept, but less than a week later we saw Mr Hawke do one of his now famous U-turns on tax policy. While campaigning for the Moreton by-election in Queensland the Prime Minister appeared to have forgotten about the terrible revenue problems posed by the Senate's action in rejecting the retrospective legislation. On this occasion to a different audience the Prime Minister tried a different line, something that he has done frequently, in particular with regard to the continuing uranium debate. The line that will be taken depends on the audience. His attitude to levels of personal tax depends on the audience. In the campaign for the Moreton by-election he was making promises of personal tax cuts . On this occasion he held out the prospect of income tax cuts and said:

It is our hope that with the economic growth that's going to take place and consistent with our intention to try and reduce the Budget deficit, we would be able to accommodate some cut in personal taxation.

That is quite a change in tune in a matter of six days. We might well ask what happened to bring on such a positive approach from the Prime Minister with regard to levels of personal tax. Had there been some startling new and revised economic predictions or had there been some further personal advice from the President of the United States with regard to its economy? Of course not. The only new factor was the audience concerned and the perceived political advantage that he could gain from offering a personal tax reduction. A week earlier the Prime Minister thought he could lambast the Opposition by raising the spectre of personal tax increases. But when he got on the campaign trail, particularly after the people of Queensland had so decisively rejected the tactics tried by Federal Ministers and senators in the dying hours of the Queensland election campaign, he thought he had better try something different.

To top off the current confusion and contradictions in the personal income tax area, on the very same day that Mr Hawke was promising and forecasting tax relief in Brisbane, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) told a Canberra Press conference that the shortfall would have to be made up basically by the ordinary taxpayer who, he said, would have to pay what has not been paid by the people who benefited from the bottom of the harbour schemes. In fact, the Government's whole approach to its recoupment legislation reeks of a massive double standard. I say this because, by its own actions and miscalculations, the Government has given away more than it stood to gain from the recoupment legislation. In September, Senator Walsh told Senator Chaney that revenue loss from post-Budget changes such as the lower fuel oil excise and the retreat on fortified wines would amount to about $80m, an amount which he said could quite easily be made up from the expected improvement in levels of economic growth. I accept that the levels of economic growth would certainly be able to absorb a change of $80m but we must contrast that with the statements that have been made by the Prime Minister and by Senator Walsh himself with regard to the loss of expected revenue that came from the rejection of the retrospective tax Bills.

I move now to another subject that is particularly close to the heart of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. That is the question of capital gains tax. Everyone knows that Senator Button is an unashamed advocate of this form of taxation. In fact, he has gone out of his way to tell us of his determination to have it accepted. Senator Button told Senator Chaney on 21 September:

It is my view that there should be a capital-gains tax in Australia and I will continue to advocate it both publicly and within the Government . . . I will put it to the Government at every opportunity that I get, and I will continue to do so.

Only Senator Button knows how successful he has been since then. But it is confusing and contradictory for the people of Australia to hear the Government's third most senior Minister advocating a course of action which they were assured at election time would not be pursued. Let me recall another of those statements that were made by Mr Hawke. On 16 February, when he was addressing an audience, he said: 'There will be no new capital gains tax'. I think that that sort of statement, made in February of one year and pursued throughout this year by a number of Ministers, is something that would make us ask just what is the policy of the Government and what is the expectation with regard to a capital gains tax . I want to refer particularly to what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, had said with regard to a capital gains tax because I think this shows the cynical approach that I mentioned earlier with regard to taxation policies and where one looks for political advantage. Mr Keating had talked previously about indirect taxes. In an interview that was reported in the Age in September of this year, he conceded that his statements in the past had been strongly opposed to capital gains tax. He said:
The views I've put at Labor Party conferences were views I put with the aim of getting into government. The debate has moved on. We are now the government.

So the Government changes the policy. It has one policy to get into government and when it becomes the government it changes the policy. I think on a subject such as a capital gains tax to have a Treasurer speaking in those terms in September and to have Senator Button speaking in those terms, it must lead us to believe that it is a very active option within the range of taxes that will be introduced by the present Government. Obviously there are those who look at current circumstances, look at the audience and decide what the policy will be. But Senator Button agreed with an interviewer recently that in current circumstances the Hawke Government could fairly be seen as a government of pragmatism before ideology. He went on to say:
But I assure you that there are still a number of us ideologues lurking about there.
He went on to give an example of something which he, as a lurking idealogue, wants to have accepted by the Government. He said:
If I say anything about a capital gains tax publicly, which I happen to believe in, I am attacked because that is an issue which Australian society, or sections of it, don't want to talk about.

So overtly or covertly, Senator Button is beavering away to get agreement to something which would absolutely contradict what his leader said before the election and such statements on the subject that are made from time to time. But even the Prime Minister these days does not entirely rule out the possibility of a capital gains tax. His last opportunity to rule out a capital gains tax was in the House of Representatives the day after Senator Button's answer to Senator Chaney. When he was asked about his colleague's renewed support for the tax, he dodged the issue entirely and would not repeat his unequivocal campaign pledge. What is more, the Prime Minister himself has foreshadowed early Cabinet consideration of an inquiry into the distribution of wealth in Australia. We might well ask what he meant when he told a Press conference on the seventh of last month, following the first meeting of the Economic Planning and Advisory Council, that the matter had been raised in Caucus, presumably by ideologues not happy with the drift of economic policy, and would be coming before Cabinet before long. This call for a review on wealth generally leads me to another area of concern and confusion which is still prominent in the minds of many Australians. That is the possibility of the introduction of federal death duties .

So we have this whole range of matters that I have referred to and which other honourable senators will refer to in turn as we bring before the Senate this matter of public importance relating to the confusion and the contradiction in Labor's tax policies. I think the only assurance that we can see in any of the policies that this Government has is that it is a government that will impose taxes in whatever form it needs to to fund the programs that it has as its objectives. I believe the people of Australia can take no comfort from statements that are made at any particular time because it does not seem to take more than six days or a month to change a direct course from that which had been previously announced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether to commend the Opposition for leading with its chin on a subject such as this, or to castigate it for its cant and humbug. The fact is that the discredited former Government, for nearly seven years, presided, inert as a stuffed bull frog, over not only the decay of the Australian tax system but also the sustained criminal abuse of that system. The only positive action it took during that time was to shift regressively the burden of taxation, through a mixture of taxation changes, particularly changes in the personal income tax schedule, to the lower income groups, whilst simultaneously imposing the highest level of taxation in total as a proportion of gross domestic product which had ever been applied. The magnitude of its negligence in the administration of the taxation laws was finally flushed out by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, ironically, a Commission set up by the discredited former Prime Minister with the intention of quickly destroying the Ship Painters and Dockers Union and no doubt, he hoped, simultaneously sections of the Australian Labor Party, turned out to be a Commission which instead finished up bagging many Liberal scalps. What Mr Fraser thought was an expedient, though cynical, political move, finished up as a shot in the foot or, some might even say, in the head. What the Costigan Commission showed, among many other things, was that for five years a bottom of the harbour prosecution which ought to have been launched, gathered dust in the bottom draw of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Perth. Through that five years a succession of Liberal Party Attorneys-General, but most importantly the last Liberal Party Attorney-General and present shadow Attorney-General and Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Durack, did absolutely nothing about pushing that prosecution. Whether Senator Durack's inertia on that question had anything to do with the fact that approximately half of the members of the Liberal Party Finance Committee in Western Australia have subsequently been revealed as being up to their ears in bottom of the harbour operations themselves and whether it had anything to do with the fact that the Western Australian Liberal Party in the main, or the influential people in it, were up to their ears in bottom of the harbour operations and that they controlled pre-selections for senators in Western Australia, is a matter for speculation.

SPEECH.PARA: After the revelations of the Costigan Commission the discredited former Treasurer was ultimately forced to table what was aptly described as a telephone book of documents which showed, among other things, the sequence of increasingly desperate letters from the Commissioner of Taxation pleading with the Government to do something about taxation reform, to do something about closing loopholes and to do something about the way in which the High Court of Australia under the then Chief Justice Garfield Barwick was emasculating the taxation Act. There was a succession of increasingly desperate pleas to take action, pleas on which no action was taken. The representatives of that Government with that record who presided in a culpably negligent manner over that chaos for nearly seven years now have the audacity to criticise this Government for not fixing up completely, in a period of seven months, the chaos which it had inherited.

The revelations of the Costigan report, of course, prompted, very belatedly, the 1982 unpaid company tax legislation. A cynical, and I note with considerable satisfaction ultimately unsuccessful, attempt was made by the then Prime Minister and the then Government to rescue that Government from the political damage which the revelations of the Costigan Commission had done to it. That action was forced upon the Government by political circumstances and was a cynical act of political expediency. But the real predilections of the Liberal and National parties in this area show still. Indeed, they showed even at the time the previous Government amended the Bill which it originally introduced concerning unpaid company tax. The majority of the members of the Opposition parties accepted, back in 1982, a significant amendment to which I will return in a moment, and continue to protect tax evaders to this day.

The Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill was finally passed last year by the Parliament with the unanimous support of the Australian Labor Party, the partial support of the Australian Democrats, the partial support of the Liberal and National parties-the governing parties of the day-and surprisingly, in view of some of his subsequent actions, the support of Senator Harradine. The Bill which was originally introduced was amended by a second Bill which included clause 3 (12) which, as I have explained to the Senate previously, exempted from liability shareholders in companies which had been sunk to the bottom of the harbour if those companies had been put into an unsuccessful tax avoidance scheme following the initial transaction, that is, the sale from the directors who controlled the original companies and the first purchasers and directors in the line which ultimately led to the bottom of the harbour. On this very matter, the possible effects of that clause were set out in a letter from the Commissioner of Taxation dated 21 October 1982 to the then Treasurer in which he said, among other things:
The Bill has been changed, as you have requested--
That is the insertion of clause 3 (12)-
to exclude from its scope cases where there was a post-sale avoidance scheme which, though ultimately unsuccessful, was reasonably expected at the time to be effective.
The Commissioner said:

I hope that I am wrong, but observe that this change must open up the possibility that some promoters will, even through backdating of documents and the like, now seek to establish that after their purchase of the shares they did in fact put the company into one of the ''reasonably expected to be successful'' avoidance schemes. It may not matter that in execution they botch it up, what will be important is that they can show they tried.

That was the advice received by the then Treasurer from the Commissioner of Taxation. The then Treasurer and the then Government nevertheless, in the face of that advice, proceeded with the Bill including that obnoxious and illogical clause to which I have referred and which I have explained. Attempts to remove that obnoxious and illogical clause from the previous Government's Bill-attempts made by the then Opposition last year in an amendment moved by me-were rejected by the Senate, with, if I remember correctly, all members of the Liberal and National parties voting against that amendment.

Moreover, it has been common knowledge for five years or perhaps even longer that bogus superannuation funds are being used as a tax avoidance vehicle. Those funds in the private sector fall roughly into three classes. There are funds set up in the private sector, ostensibly for the benefit of employees. There are funds set up for the benefit of the self-employed and business or professional occupation funds. The scope for avoidance which the last two funds provided were closed off in 1980. The private employees' funds, however, have survived to this day. They may not survive for much longer but they survived the duration of the Fraser Government which begs the question: Why, when even the Fraser Government had been forced to take some action against the other two classes of funds which were being abused in a similar way for precisely the same ultimate reasons, were the loopholes closed for two types of funds and not closed for the third type? Leaving aside the possible interpretation, I suppose, of sheer incompetence, one can only speculate as to the reasons why the previous Government took that discriminatory action when it is a matter of public record that many influential figures in the Liberal Party, people who held leading offices in the Liberal Party, have been shown to have personally benefited, in at least one case to the extent of several million dollars, from tax evasion and avoidance schemes. It does however lead one to certain suspicions.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's speech consisted partly of a compendium of errors, several of which I will demonstrate, but concentrated, I suppose, on alleged inconsistencies between statements made by various Government Ministers when in opposition and in government and, in particular, by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke). She drew attention to what she claimed was an inconsistency between statements made by the Prime Minister in the Parliament I think two weeks ago, statements made by the Prime Minister last week and statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week concerning the effects of the Senate's rejection of the present Government's attempt to recover the personal tax evaded by people involved in wet Slutzkin or bottom of the harbour schemes. There is in fact no inconsistency. The basic proposition, which indeed is a tautology, is that if a government loses revenue of that magnitude-in this case the May Bill ultimately was estimated to recover $570m; but the principle applies regardless of the magnitude of the revenue-there are three ways in which that can be offset . The deficit in the relevant year or years can be increased, government expenditure can be commensurately reduced, or taxes paid by somebody will have to be increased. There can be a mixture of those three options. But other than embracing a combination of those options or one of those options, there is no way in which the loss of revenue of any magnitude can be offset.

All that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer had done was draw attention to that fact. The fact that $570m has been lost to revenue does not necessarily preclude a reduction in personal income tax rates or in taxation rates in general in the following year, but it means inevitably that, other things being equal, the magnitude of those taxation cuts must be less than it would otherwise have been. If the taxation route is chosen to correct the hole in the accounts left by the loss of revenue, inevitably some or all other taxpayers must pay more tax than they otherwise would have done. It is that central point which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been driving home.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's principal allegation-I think it was her first allegation-was that the Government had reneged on promises given when in opposition regarding personal income tax. It is correct that the Government was not able to make the adjustments to personal income tax which it had envisaged making and intended to make prior to the election. Senator Guilfoyle said that that pre-election undertaking was a cynical undertaking which the present Prime Minister must have known, at the time he gave it, was not achievable. The present Prime Minister did not know that at the time he gave that undertaking. Some people did know, perhaps, that it was not achievable-principally the discredited former Treasurer, who knew at that stage that a prospective deficit of about $9 billion, on a no policy change basis, was looming up for 1983-84, and who was told in the week before the election in March by the Treasury that the prospective deficit was $9.6 billion.

The Australian Labor Party and Mr Hawke, in opposition, did not know those facts. We did not have access to the bureaucracy's forecast at that stage. The figure for the prospective deficit being given by the discredited former Treasurer and the discredited former Prime Minister at the time was $6 billion, a figure which, if correct-which it was not-would have allowed for personal tax cuts of the magnitude forecast by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister and the Labor Party, when in opposition, along with the rest of the country, were misled by the former Government as to the true financial situation which was confronting the country. When the truth finally came through to the Labor Party after the federal election, it was realised that it was not possible to implement the tax changes which we had envisaged implementing before the election. After all that, when the record clearly shows that the former Government misled the Labor Party and everyone else about the true dimensions of the financial crisis facing the country, members of the former Government have the chutzpah to come into the Senate and castigate the present Government for allegedly reneging on promises, promises which were given honestly and in good faith but without the knowledge of the extent to which the then Government had misled the country at that time.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle also said-I was astounded by this-that the Government has said that there will be a resources rent tax on coal and oil next year. The Government has said no such thing. The Government and, principally, I have said that we intend to replace the existing levy on crude oil with a rent tax in the next financial year. On many occasions we have expressed-and again it is principally I who have expressed it-the Government's belief that where the present production-related taxes, principally on coal, are high, they ought to be replaced by a rent-type tax, and we have, if not invariably then almost invariably, added that the States have primary taxing rights over coal, on-shore resources such as coal, whereas oil is off-shore, and therefore any such change in the system will require the co-operation of the States. We are seeking that co-operation and we shall continue to do so.

Senator Guilfoyle also referred to what I presume was a report in yesterday's edition of the Australian Financial Review of a statement by Mr McGarry, the Managing Director of Australian Oil and Gas, in which he had claimed that the introduction of a resources rent tax will mean that only very large companies will be able to continue as oil explorers and potential producers. I do not know whether Mr McGarry was correctly reported but I know that if he said what he was reported to have said, he is wrong, because the plain fact is that in two very important respects, the proposed change will advantage small companies vis-a-vis large companies. First, it is proposed that the tax be levied on a cash flow basis; in other words, it would not be applicable until net earnings had exceeded total investment in the project. Secondly, we wish to incorporate in the rent tax which we plan to introduce next year-there may be technical difficulties which preclude us ultimately from doing this-some method of transferring the losses from exploration on barren fields, either through the tax system or in some other way. That is an additional measure which, far from doing what Mr McGarry apparently believes it would do, will assist the smaller companies relative to the large companies.
The objectives of this Government in taxation, which have been pursued and will continue to be pursued, are those of honesty, fairness and performance, objectives which time is needed to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for bringing to the Senate's attention this matter of public importance, which highlights:

SPEECH.PARA: The confusion and contradictions of the government's taxation policy.

If there were ever any doubt about that confusion, one is confirmed in the view that it exists having just listened to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, outlining his pathetic attempts to justify the lack of action on the part of the Government in honouring its promises in many areas when it was elected on 5 March and since. First, let us address ourselves to two or three matters that Senator Walsh mentioned. He spoke firstly of the bottom of the harbour scheme and said that the recent rejection of the recoupment Bill has resulted in the reduction of $570m in the Government's income. The point is that that sum is a mere $60m in this year's accounts, and of course, it is more than offset by the Government's blunders in its calculations of the amount of revenue to be received by way of excise, some $69m, in respect of fuel. If Senator Walsh is to mislead the Senate in the fashion that he does, he should at least address himself to some of the obvious errors that have occurred in the calculation and formulation of the Budget.

The second issue I mention is Senator Walsh's so-called pursuit of tax avoiders who use superannuation schemes. He said that many businesses which establish private superannuation schemes for the benefit of employees do so in order to rip off the taxpayer. He made the point that during the period of office of the Fraser Government, no action had been taken in order to stamp out certain tax avoidance practices with regard to superannuation funds. That is a nonsense, as he well knows. In fact, some three or four months before the election on 5 March , the Fraser Government implemented through the Commissioner of Taxation a whole set of new guidelines for the determination of entitlements of employees and entitlements for deductions by employers under revised arrangements. That was a very stringent set of guidelines which drew very strong objection from the part of the community generally that was interested in this matter and is clearly an indication of the efforts which the Fraser Government went to at that time to ensure that tax avoidance in that area was stamped out.

Let us turn to some of the other questions which this Government is seeking in some way to camouflage by the pathetic attempt on the part of Senator Walsh to address himself to these problems. Let us look at some of the promises that the Labor Government has broken in the last eight months since it came to office. It promised a $600m tax reduction for all income earners. It was claimed by the former Leader of the Opposition, now the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that that would in fact help some six million Australians. It is significant that in this week before the Moreton by-election we are in fact seeing the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, claiming that there will be tax reductions next year. That has been contradicted by his Treasurer (Mr Keating) to some extent, but the truth is that he is attempting once more to mislead the Australian people into believing that the Hawke Government believes in tax reductions. The Hawke Government promised the immediate raising of the tax threshold from some $4,500 to about $5,000. In fact, that did not occur.

The Hawke Government promised that there would be no tax on lump sum superannuation payments. In the May statement brought down by Treasurer Keating in fact a lump sum superannuation tax was introduced-a punitive tax, a very savage tax-which I will return to shortly. Before the election, the Australian Labor Party claimed that it would not abolish the health rebate, and that it would not abolish the housing interest tax rebate then available to families in Australia. Immediately upon coming to office, it abolished those rebates and imposed an extra $12 or $14 a week on the average family by way of extra taxation loading. It promised that it would not introduce an assets test or an income test on the over 70s. Immediately on coming to office it did so. In South Australia it promised, and its representatives paraded all over the State in the pre-election period promising, that there would be no tax on wine. In fact, in the Budget, it introduced a tax on wine. It promised that there would be no capital gains tax and yet we hear Senator Button in this place at every possible opportunity-he is the No. 3 member in the Hawke Cabinet-claim that he is in favour of a capital gains tax. Is it any wonder that people are confused about that issue? The Australian Labor Party promised that it would not reintroduce an estate duty; yet Senator Robert Ray is on the record in this place as having worked out a scheme for the reintroduction of estate duty by the Labor Party which is to be considered by the appropriate committee, he claims, before the Budget of 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very improving document.
—That is very interesting, but I believe that he was reported upon in the Business Review Weekly in the last few days on this matter. I hope he will make it available to all people.
—It is a Fabian Society leaflet. All you need is $1.50, but you are too stingy.

—That may be his way of squirming out of the issue. The fact is that he is on the public record as advocating an estate duty. He is clearly making his presence felt throughout the committees of the Labor Party, obviously with a view to forcing it on the Australian people. Clearly, he is a most influential senator from Victoria and one who has a lot of power in Caucus. It has been reported in various places that he is a member of the appropriate faction to do that, and clearly the intentions of that faction are to reintroduce an estate duty.

SPEECH.PARA: One or two other matters were claimed by the present Government before it came to office. It claimed that it would wage unrelenting war on tax avoidance. After seven months in office-or is it eight?-we have not seen one piece of legislation on tax avoidance, with the exception of the bottom of the harbour nonsense which it tried to bring in the other day. Where is the legislation and the Government' s unrelenting attack on tax avoiders which was to reduce the tax burden on the ordinary Australian by ensuring that it got into the tax avoidance industry and destroyed it? Where is the legislation? The Government has made no attempt to do anything. The only anti-avoidance legislation brought in was an attack on the aged. The Government has attacked lump sum superannuation for aged persons and retirees. It has attacked their assets by introducing the assets test on pensioners who looked forward to retirement. It has also introduced an income test for the over 70s. That is its policy. It has attacked the weakest in the community, not the strongest. It is for that reason that it stands condemned for not carrying out its promises.

One other very important aspect of the Labor Party's policy oft proclaimed in this place-in fact, helped by the Australian Democrats, defeated legislation in respect of the introduction of sales taxes when we were in power-

TALK.START.PARA: —On necessities.

—I am not worried about that, Senator Evans. The important point is that the Government, when in opposition, stated quite clearly that it was opposed to the imposition of higher indirect taxes and would rely more on direct taxes in the form of income tax. That is its principle. That is what it claimed in opposition. In government, in its first Budget, on page 271 of 'Budget Statements 1983-84, Budget Paper No. 1', one finds that there was an increase in set pay-as-you-earn tax revenues projected for this current financial year of 4. 7 per cent. What is the figure for indirect taxes which include sales taxes on ordinary goods? I remind the Senate of how those items were extended to cover such things as airconditioning, which Senator Evans might remember, sunscreens, retreaded tyres and matters of that kind. All of these things added to an increase of double that rate, of some 8.2 per cent increase in indirect taxes, about half of it attributable to direct taxes. The Labor Party has thrown its principles out the window. It does not believe in what it is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn to a particular area of concern, that is, the tax that has been imposed on lump sum superannuation payments. It is perhaps one of the most outrageous methods by which the Government has sought to break its promises. On the eve of the National Economic Summit Conference it promised specifically that there would be no tax on lump sum superannuation payments. Nevertheless, less than a month later came the announcement by Treasurer Keating that a tax would be introduced on lump sum superannuation payments. One may remember that it was a most punitive rate of tax. There was to be a rate on sums up to about $100,000 of 30 per cent, rising to about 60 per cent very quickly. There was also the question of how this tax discriminated against the self-employed. It worked to the advantage of some of the employed groups in the community, but there was no attempt to work out the equity principles between the employed group in the community and the self-employed. It introduced a de facto death tax by imposing tax on lump sums payable on death. It did not seek to relieve the armed forces in any way. In fact, people who are forced by virtue of their employment to retire at ages less than normal-for instance, an Army major must retire at the age of about 45 years-are required to pay this tax and thus have their opportunities to buy a house or a business considerably reduced.

No information has become available about how the Life Insurance Act will be amended to give us better rates of return on projected annuities. There have been no definitions of what contractual termination payments will be or of those items which are included under the definition of lump sums. There is no other information about whether life insurance was to be caught by this. Subsequently, the Government had to overturn all those statements and, indeed, in late July it came down with a totally modified statement about this as a result of pressure not only from the community but also, more particularly, from the trade union movement, in particular, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Government had tried to bluff its way through this problem and is still attempting to do that in the light of the Moreton by-election coming up on Saturday. The truth is that this is an issue of the greatest concern to Australians who look forward to the day when they can provide for their own welfare and their own futures in retirement. They wish to save enough through their efforts in their lifetimes to give themselves independence and security in their old age.

This particular policy is aimed at destroying the independence of Australians. It works against the interests of Australians. It treats as tax cheats people who want to accumulate capital for their futures. That is absolutely outrageous in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —They get tax deductions.

—Senator Ray will have his chance to try to convince us about this. The Government has always perceived the tax payable on lump sum superannuation as a tax avoidance device because of the way it has been treated in the past. It has never seen it in terms of an incentive to people to look after themselves. That is the way the Opposition sees it. It is an encouragement for people to provide for their own futures. That is the alternative for which the Opposition stands. There is a clear difference between the views of the Government and the Opposition in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: The assets test on pensions-I reiterate that it is an attack on the weakest group in the community-is only more evidence of broken promises on the part of the Government in the tax area. The Government has not faced up to its responsibilities and its claims that it would chase tax cheats and tax avoiders. It has taken the easy way out and attacked the pensioners, the weakest group in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that listeners would realise that the Senate is aware that today is broadcast day. It is a bit like television ratings time, except that the normal television ratings period brings better entertainment. I do not think there is too much entertainment value in the debate that we are having today, because we are simply dragging out again, the same tired old cliches and blaming each other for today's economic crisis and the taxation system. We are constantly looking backwards.

SPEECH.PARA: I am astounded that in a debate to consider the existing confusion and contradictions of the government's taxation policy-this, incidentally, is interesting phrasing because one might interpret it to mean not just the Government which happens to be sitting in government today, but any government over the years-participants should come up with only the criticisms of what is and what has been and not with constructive alternatives. I find it very disheartening because, if there is to be an alternative approach to the taxation system by this Parliament, it has to come out of this kind of debate. It has to come out of a constructive approach to the taxation system. It has to come out of a constructive consideration, a gathering together of ideas and a pulling together in a consensus of the objectives of an alternative taxation system.

Unfortunately, today we are not looking forward; we are looking backwards. In looking backwards one needs to consider, under this topic of the general confusion and contradictions of taxation policy, the tax system itself. Over the past 20 years it would have been possible at any time to claim that a government 's taxation policies were confusing and contradictory. I do not think that governments necessarily are to blame for that. When one looks at it objectively, one can see that the confusion comes about as a result of the complexity of administering a tax system for millions of individuals and hundreds of thousands of firms. It is a system which requires so many rules and regulations that in the event very few people can understand it. I think the evidence demonstrates that scarcely anybody in this country understands the tax system. One comes to that conclusion when one sees the different interpretations applied to the various tax laws. One comes to that conclusion when one realises that it took 10 years to get into the tax legislation the amendments which were necessary to catch up with the tax avoiders and tax evaders who were ripping off this country .

So the tax system is confusing. The motion is valid insofar as its accusation of confusion in the system is concerned. The system is also contradictory. Again , that is inevitable. It is inevitable because when we have a taxation policy that tries to meet a number of contradictory objectives of the various sectors of our community we will finish up with legislation which in itself is contradictory and the administration of which is contradictory.

Let us look at some of the alternative objectives and aims. The parties representing various sectors of the community go to an election in an attempt to win votes by promising that they will reform the tax system. They promise that they will improve the tax system; they will make life easier for their constituents. To meet the perceived political and economic goals of the community, those promises are maintained right up to election day. However, when the election is over the economic realities bring the parties back to earth with a thud, as we saw when this Government was elected.

I think it is fair to suggest that a tax system generally endeavours to be equitable with the wealthy paying a higher proportion of their incomes; that is the equity facet. On the other hand, in a fundamentally free enterprise system there is a need to build in or to leave in those incentives that motivate the economic endeavour which leads to the creation of greater wealth within a country. Taxation tries to reallocate resources between industries and gives incentives to some industries or organisations at the expense of others. That is a further contradiction. Those who benefit, of course, justify the existing position whilst those who lose out attack it. We saw that during the consideration of the sales tax amendments this year. We will always see it because vested interests are very concerned to protect their interests.

Confusion is caused not only by the world out there, but also by the maladministration of the taxation system itself. We had a classic illustration of this with the introduction of the prescribed payments tax, which was badly introduced. It was not satisfactorily administered as far as the people who had to cope with it in the market-place were concerned. There were a number of anomalies, some of which have subsequently been adjusted. I give credit to the Commissioner of Taxation and to the Minister responsible for the prescribed payments tax, the Treasurer (Mr Keating), for taking note of the Senate committee report which made a number of recommendations. But that does not get away from the fact that a tax is confusing when insufficient preparation, planning and communicating are done before a tax is introduced.

Another perfect illustration of maladministration was the way in which the means test for the over-70s was introduced. It caused a great deal of fear in a section of the community that should not be subjected to these sorts of anxieties. Certainly we had fed back to us that because of the improper or poor explanation some people were living in fear that they would lose all of their pensions when, in fact, that was not to be the case. I think, with the amount of publicity that has been received recently, it is reasonable to suggest that governments over the years are entitled to be criticised because of the avoidance of taxes through tax evasion schemes. I do not think that it does any government any credit when we look back over the last decade to see the growth of the tax avoidance industry. Nobody in this Parliament over that time could have missed the massive attack on the taxation system in this country that was built up by the tax avoidance and evasion industry. It spent literally hundreds of thousands-if not millions-of dollars to entice people and companies to join in the tax avoidance game. Governments procrastinated and prevaricated, as a result of which, when the final crunch came and that industry could no longer be ignored, legislation was pushed through this Parliament which caused chaos and confusion. It caused anomalies which we are now trying to redress because of poor planning and poor administration. The same thing could be said in regard to the assets test which has created great fears for elderly people. Giving credit to the Government, at least the assets test was planned legislation of which about 15 months notice was given to the community; so there was the opportunity to feed back into Government reactions, responses, proposals and suggestions on that assets test. That is heading in a better direction.

I have mentioned the confusion that came about as a result of the recent Budget but let me touch on the sales tax changes which created anomalies in industries such as the swimming pool industry. It created anomalies and precedents in the building industry where, for the first time ever, a building material is sales taxed but all other building materials are exempt. It does really create confusion in an industry when that happens. I think that those anomalies are matched by the anomalies that most governments seem to be afraid to pick up, such as capital gains taxes, the lack of which creates a massive anomaly in our taxation system because it is possible to make millions and millions of dollars in what are clearly taxable profits in any other country in the world except this one. In this country one can make these profits and not pay one red cent of tax on a capital gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you advocating that?

—Yes, indeed, and have been for some time. The Australian Democrats are not ashamed or afraid to come out and say that this is a tax avoidance industry in itself, which neither the Australian Labor Party nor the Liberal Party has yet been willing to pick up. When the Labor Party Government does pick it up, it will have our support.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some further problems but instead of looking at them in my final few minutes I will talk about the alternative new direction. The Australian Democrats have proposed that all parties should come together and discuss the tax system, looking not just at the need for long term, indicative planning procedures-I have a motion on notice before the Senate to do that-or at rolling budget systems but at a comprehensive long term plan to rationalise Australia's tax laws on an all-party basis. If we do not get to an all-party basis to reform the taxation system, then it is going to suffer the problems of the pendulum of changing governments over the years ahead.

The new tax system would need to be carefully explained. It would need to be thoroughly thought through, certainly a lot better thought through than some of the tax legislation we have seen over the last few years. It would need to be based on the consensus and common aims of the major parties-the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats-because with that consensus we could sell a reformed tax system to the people of Australia. Then it would need to be phased in so that people and firms could prepare for the anticipated changes that would come about as a result of a reformed tax system. As part of that reform we would need to look at some of the options that individual parties in government are quite understandably afraid to consider- options such as a wealth tax, the capital gains tax to which I referred, an expenditure tax or a value added tax. One of the options being considered by the Government at the moment is the resource rental tax which would be a much simpler tax not just to apply. As far as most of the people in the resource area are concerned, it would remove the proliferation of taxes and charges from which they currently suffer. We would need to look at the elimination of payroll tax, that inquitous tax which penalises firms for employing more people, and we would need to look again at the re-introduction of automatic tax indexation to keep governments honest. We would need to look at the whole industry of tax avoidance and tax evasion because although it was predicted in only 1982 that we could save up to $10 billion a year if we cleaned up the avoidance and tax evasion industry, in fact it appears that we will be lucky now to get $1 billion.

I think that the people of Australia are justifiably very much in support of this matter of public importance which refers to the confusion and contradiction of government-all governments-taxation policies because it is governments that suffer. They have suffered the loss over the last 10 years of $9 billion of that $10 billion which was lost in the tax avoidance and evasion industry. Some of those people are suffering now when governments, in an endeavour to catch up for that loss to government, are hitting people who do not deserve to be hit, who are being unjustly treated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the chamber is confronted by an impertinent debate brought on by Opposition senators who are quite breathtaking in their audacity, having made the accusation that this Government is confused and contradictory in its pursuit of taxation policy. If there has been any stumbling in this Government's proposals to raise revenue in order to fund the various projects, schemes and undertakings for which we have a mandate from the Australian people, it is due entirely to the frustrations and impediments put in the way of that raising of revenue by the honourable senators who sit oppose in this chamber. Tax avoidance legislation has been brought into this chamber twice in the few months that we have been in government and it has been repudiated by those honourable senators opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Governments do not raise taxes; they propose them. Under our democratic system those taxes need the concurrence of parliament before they are imposed on people . This chamber's failure to concur with Government proposals to deal with tax avoidance has been a major cause of the rearrangement in certain matters that we have had to undertake. Senator Messner, in his bluff and bluster, accused us of attacking the frail and elderly in the community. I ask those ordinary taxpayers in the community to consider how much more we could do for the frail and elderly if we had the hundreds of millions of dollars available to us which we proposed to raise by way of the tax avoidance legislation to do with bottom of the harbour schemes and their ramifications. A total of $570m was to be raised under the first proposal and $270m under the second proposal. That would have gone a long way towards alleviating the distress of the frail and elderly but, as I say , it was repudiated by those honourable senators who now have the audacity to bring this charge against the Government today.

Who in this chamber has concurred in the perverting of the best legal and accounting brains in our nation to serve the selfish ends of the tax avoiders? It is the honourable senators who sit opposite. I exclude Senator Jack Evans from these remarks; I found his contribution today, in the usual way, to demonstrate a moderate and sensible appreciation of this matter. In relation to Liberal and National Party members, one can only say that they have shown breathtaking audacity and hypocrisy. The ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers of this country have had to bear an increasing burden over the years those parties were in government and they are still burdened because of the failure of those opposite, when in government and now in opposition, to support a decent attack on tax avoidance. They have hidden behind all sorts of formulae to justify their refusal to concur in this attempt to construct a fairer and more equitable tax system, but everyone knows that they are simply protecting those who are closer to them in the political sense.

Where the whole attack of the Opposition today falls completely to the ground is in its accusation of confusion and contradiction. There has been a failure altogether to recognise and to give due credit to this Government's method of operation and acknowledge the fact that it is a good listener. Honourable senators opposite, I believe, are guilty of confusion. They confuse a willingness to negotiate, a willingness to listen. So long as a fair case is fairly presented-of course, we will not give way to blackmail as was attempted by the airline pilots in relation to a further modification of the superannuation taxation arrangements-this Government will modify the method of operation of a particular proposal. It will not change the principles. This Government will not be diverted from making hard decisions and achieving a certain goal, but in achieving that goal and the modifications that might be required to ensure the most fair operation of the method of raising the tax in relation to those matters, we are always willing to listen, consult and negotiate to try to do the best possible thing. In that way, rather than being guilty of confusion, I believe we are perhaps guilty of something that is new on the Australian political scene, that is, an ability to stand back from our first decision as to the method of going about a particular proposal and listening intently to those who have a fair case to make.

In relation to the taxation on lump sum superannuation payments, which was raised by Senator Messner, we say, and have said right from the beginning, that, unless those lump sum payments are invested in a way which yields an annual income so as to relieve the Australian Treasury of the payment of social security benefits to those people who could afford thereby to fund their own retirement, taxation must go ahead. We have made it very clear that ordinary taxpayers should not have to supplement the retirement income of those who, by an astute investment of their lump sum payment, could provide for their own retirement. I entirely agree with Senator Messner who said that lump sum payments are part of an Australian way of providing for retirement-that people can look forward to those years. I agree entirely, but there is no reason why the Australian taxpayer should supplement that provision by way of payment of social security benefits to those who, as I say, by an astute investment of the lump sum payment, could give themselves an annual income. We have modified the method of bringing about that goal. Is that not a good thing? Would the Australian people prefer a government which rigidly and without compromise refused to budge one inch from the method of bringing about some desired social goal? We do not operate that way. I hope that we never do.

I now turn to the cash economy of which I think Senator Jack Evans made some mention. We were the first government to identify the problem. The fact is that many people involved in the cash economy, particularly building construction firms, have been engaged in an environment in which the payment of tax has been nil or very minimal. In the first assault on that cash economy by any Australian government, we made some errors in the accumulation of paper work and in some of the details and procedures which perhaps ought to be followed. But our goal was absolutely certain and clear. It cannot be compromised. Our goal is that a person who is paid cash for undertaking particular work ought to make, in the same way as a PAYE taxpayer does, some contribution to the Treasury along the way in the course of the year. There was a lot of gnashing of teeth from honourable senators opposite concerning the application of this broad principle, which is a burden shared by most Australian taxpayers, to those persons, particularly those in the building industry. In fact, on examination the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations found that the proposal was well justified. The hearings of that Committee quelled many of the fears and allayed many of the misgivings of those involved in the industries affected. The Government responded very speedily and readily to some of the suggestions of the Committee to tidy up the paper work and to expedite the consideration of those who need to be subject to the particular provisions. There was nothing confused or contradictory in the goal and in the approach set by the government. It was merely a question of listening to a good case where it was made and making some small adjustments.

I can record my appreciation of the Government's ready response to my pleas on behalf of Tasmanian industries-I know they were shared by other honourable senators-in relation to the imposition of a 9c a litre tax on fuel oil and heating oil in the August Budget. Clearly, this would have added intolerable costs to the operations of many industries and firms. One thinks of all those industries which use fuel oil to raise steam, whether they be in the vegetable or milk processing fields, such as Edgells and United Milk Tasmania Ltd; raw material users, such as Tioxide Australia Pty Ltd, Comalco Ltd and TEMPO, the Tasmanian Electro Metallurgical Co. Pty Ltd; timber-based industries, such as Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd; and major public institutions, such as hospitals. This proposal had a very deleterious impact on all of these industries. Within 24 hours, the Government, having realised that there had been an error in the figuring of the Budget, remedied the situation. As I say, there was a very speedy response to a case properly made and fairly presented. Rather than being accused of confusion, I think the Government ought to be commended for its ability to respond so readily to these sorts of cases when they are properly made.

Senator Jack Evans, very properly I think, broadened the scope of this discussion to include, beyond personal attacks, the question of taxation of industries. He stressed the importance of achieving a fair and even-handed balance and also of achieving what social objectives we think are important for the creation of wealth and jobs via industry assistance through the taxation system. Once again, this Government has identified high technology and new industries as being extremely important to the future generation of such wealth and jobs within the Australian economy. Both the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, and the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, have taken a very leading role in devising a taxation system or regime which will allow the creation, for the first time in Australia, of a capital venture market for the encouragement of such high technology industries. As honourable senators will know, this flows from the report of Sir Frank Espie, the Chairman of the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences. He indicated what ought to be done. I give the former Government credit for commissioning the report. This Government has taken up the challenge, has implemented the report and has used the taxation system to help achieve that desirable social objective . We have agreed to forego $20m of revenue in order to generate some $40m for investment in some of those high risk industries.

I do not have time to outline the establishment of the management and investment company licensing board scheme which will underpin that taxation arrangement. Under that scheme licensed management and investment companies will be able to claim a 100 per cent tax deduction in the year of the subscription. In that way we believe all the skills, innovative ability and scientific expertise in the Australian community, which is very considerable, can be allied with the skills of our work force, which is well educated, and with the provision of that venture capital so that we can generate the production of wealth and the creation of jobs within the Australian manufacturing sector. In those ways I believe the taxation system is once again being used by this Government, not in a confused and contradictory way, but in a very clear-headed way with desirable social goals being set and the necessary steps being taken, even where it involves a foregoing of revenue in order to achieve that goal.

Finally, there would be nothing more contradictory or confusing than for a government to have the best laws in the world but to refuse to give to the administrators of those laws the sinews of war to do battle to ensure that those laws are observed. If anything could be said to be a major failing of the previous Government, and I believe a cause of its downfall, it was the fact that in both the tax administration area and in the administration of the Crown Solicitor's Office there was a failure either to provide the sinews of war or adequately to supervise the discharge of responsibilities by those who were responsible.

I know that at Estimates committee meetings senators on this side of the chamber pleaded year after year with the then Government to do away with the artificial staff ceilings and the apparent saving of salaries in order to give to the Commissioner of Taxation the soldiers he needed in the battle with the tax avoiders. Those soldiers were never provided. Again the work of senators on this side of the chamber, who are now part of the Government, at Estimates committee meetings exposed much of the maladministration in the Crown Solicitor' s Office which led to failure to prosecute instances of tax avoidance which would have been test cases and perhaps would have led to the nipping in the bud of the bottom of the harbour scheme which deprived the revenue of hundreds of millions of dollars.

Opposition senators who have the audacity to bring this debate before the chamber this afternoon presided, through their Ministers, over the most lax system of government administration which has ever been the misfortune of the Australian taxpayer, who then had to bear the burden of that failure. Indeed, of course, as we all know, the Perth Crown Solicitor's Office was being used by one figure to run an escort agency. While he was pursuing a folly of his own the taxation laws of this country were left wilting and were not being administered by that office with all the consequences which, as I said, the ordinary taxpayers have had to bear.

I conclude by saying that it thoroughly ill becomes the Opposition to make the charge that it has made today. Not only has there been a total failure to substantiate it but also it is so riddled with hypocrisy as not to merit the support of this chamber. I am sure that the Opposition's approach to taxation matters will never gain the support of the people of Australia as it did not on 5 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance raised by my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, namely, the confusion and contradictions of the Government's taxation policy. My colleague Senator Tate in his usual honest way acknowledged five minutes ago that the Government was indeed a good listener. The impression that I got was that it was prepared to be flexible and willing to change. Is not that an indictment from the Government side of the Government's confusion and uncertainty? This Government, which was prepared to make a whole list of election promises, came back after the Budget was presented and said: 'Well, maybe we have to look again . We have to listen to some other views in the community-the trade union movement and so on'. What an indictment!

SPEECH.PARA: Our honest Senator Tate gave an example which is very pertinent to the debate from our own Tasmanian situation. The Budget indirect tax increases applying to fuel would have had a horrendous effect on transport costs in Tasmania. We acknowledge that as a result of representations this policy was changed because an error had been made. The confusion and changes indicate that the Government's whole Budget policy was not thought through carefully. This sort of approach has been fairly costly to business because business requires certainty and confidence. However, unfortunately these requirements have been lacking.

I believe that a significant factor which contributed to Mr Hawke's win in the March election was his promises in the taxation field. I think it is acknowledged within the Australian community that the hip-pocket nerve is very sensitive in terms of where a person will place his vote at the next election. However, we have seen a host of broken promises. Mr Hawke said:
I offer no fistful of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

They were snatched back all right. He promised immediate reductions in income tax for almost six million Australians. These reductions did not eventuate. Time and again the Australian Labor Party emphasised that there would be no change to the tax on lump sum superannuation payments and other lump sum retirement payments. We have seen a whole host of changes and uncertainty. I do not believe that the situation is clear even at present. We had a promise that the interest rebate on home loans would be maintained. Again, this benefit was chopped off. The Labor Party promised that the health insurance rebate would be kept until the introduction of Medicare. What happened? The rebate was wiped out on 30 June . The Labor Party promised not to means test the pensions of the over-70-year olds. As my colleague Senator Messner said, these are the people who are least able to help themselves. It promised that it would not introduce an assets test.

The Labor Party promised that it would not impose a sales tax on retreaded tyres. But what happened? The Government imposed that tax.
