What it is effectively doing is exporting jobs from small Australian firms. This decision means that new tyres will be imported. The Labor Party promised to lift the tax threshold to $5,000 for ordinary citizens and $5,893 for pensioners. But what has happened? The Government has broken those promises.

Perhaps the only consistent line of policy in relation to taxation measures that one can deduce is that the Labor Party has rejected its pre-election promises. That is the only consistent line that I think anybody could see in relation to the whole area of Labor Party policy on taxation. The line that the Government continually gives as an excuse or as a reason for such rejection is that it inherited a deficit far greater than it expected. Initially I think that many members of the public believed that the deficit that the Labor Government inherited was the deficit for the current year 1982-83. In fact, one senator in this place propounded that theory for a while. Instead, we are talking about the 'projected' deficit for 1983-84. But let us get the facts straight. The Labor Party alleged that it inherited a deficit of $9.6 billion. However, this is the 'projected' deficit for the next year. That deficit assumed certain progressions and certain income levels which were quite unrealistic because they were taken from a very low base which was influenced by the international recession and the drought. I emphasise that very unreal levels were used to determine the growth factors. What can one expect if the expenditure side is overstated and growth factors are understated? Naturally, if one does that one will be left with a figure such as $9.6 billion. But that is an illusory figure.

If the Government's expressions of concern about its difficult fiscal position were genuine it would not have cut out expenditure by the previous Government of $1,271m and substituted its own expenditure program of $2,500m in accordance with the priorities of its own choosing. I think that is a very significant point. The Government has cut out many of the previous Government's proposals, many of which were essentially job creating, and has substituted in dollar terms more than twice that expenditure in its own proposals. No wonder the deficit will rise.

Let us look at some of the facts. During the seven years of the Fraser Government the increase in spending in real terms was about two per cent. Under the Labor Budget the increase will be about 7 1/2 per cent in real terms. There was a consistent increase of 2 per cent during the previous seven years of the Fraser Government, but in the first year of office of the Labor Government the increase amounted to 7 1/2 per cent in real terms. The Labor Government's housing policy transferred expenditure from the private sector to the public sector. This sort of expression of socialisation is again manifested in Medicare . An additional $1.7 billion has to be raised in taxes. This Government has a record of taking incentives away.

Perhaps nowhere is the confusion greater than in the proposal for the introduction of a Resources rental tax. The Minister for Energy and Resources, Senator Walsh, has pushed the virtues of this tax. Perhaps of all the ALP Ministers, Senator Walsh should be the last one to push such an idea. I would have expected a Minister for Energy and Resources to put forward policies that would encourage development in mining, oil exploration and so on. What is he doing? He is putting the kibosh on it all the time with threats of a resources rental tax which will, essentially, reduce incentives. The acceptance of the idea of a resources rental tax fails to acknowledge the high costs of exploration and the risks that are associated, not only with exploration, but also with the probability of failure. The costs of failure in most cases exceed the cost of return. There must be an inducement or reward in such an environment to explore for oil and develop mines not only for the investment but also for the risk taking. The Labor Party fails to acknowledge this essential ingredient.

If the Government goes ahead with the introduction of a resources rental tax which has been proposed by Senator Walsh, it would tend to recover from the companies involved in risk taking a further tax, essentially a super-profits tax . That is what it would amount to; that is the fear. What would be the effects of a resources rental tax? It has been alleged that it would tend to diminish Australian ownership in such ventures. Surely this is contrary to ALP policy which we are, from time to time, assured is designed to encourage Australian ownership. Its policy in this area is contrary to that philosophy. This tax would tend to reduce competitiveness. Under such an arrangement the States would be expected to forgo royalty income. An environment of distrust over the dams compensation to the Tasmanian Government or this Government's attitude towards the Queensland Government is not a good environment for those States to expect a fair slice of the resources rental tax in return for their giving up their royalty incomes.

What incentives would there be for the States to encourage mining and oil exploration? Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, continues, from time to time, to raise the probability of a Labor government introducing a capital gains tax. The electorate and certainly people on this side of the chamber are unsure whether those are personal statements or whether he is testing the waters of public opinion on behalf of the Government to get a public reaction. I think it is time for a definitive statement to clarify the uncertainty and confusion in this area.

The Labor Party is not content to float only the possibility of a capital gains tax but also some members are pushing for a wealth tax. This adds confusion to confusion. A wealth tax imposes a tax on assets, which assets do not always give rise to profits or increments in a cash form from which the tax is to be paid, thereby rendering the assets liable for disposal to pay that tax. The possibility of a reintroduction of death duties has also been raised. This again adds confusion to confusion.

One of the main features of Labor Party policy was to attack tax avoidance. What has it done? Its attack has been largely limited to a series of measures concerned with so-called bottom of the harbour schemes. What did it try to do? It sought to introduce new taxes and to impose those new taxes retrospectively on amounts which were not previously assessable. It based its series of Bills on reconstructing a set of non-commercial, hypothetical circumstances that could not normally have been followed by any business. So it sought to impose a new tax retrospectively. That is the extent of what it tried to do in stopping tax avoidance. The truth is that John Howard effectively stopped tax avoidance in his term as Treasurer. The Government's further confusion is illustrated by what it has done in relation to a wine tax. In the first place it said it would not introduce a wine tax. However, it was included in the Budget. The position has subsequently been changed. A further promise of personal tax cuts was made before the Budget, but no tax cuts were included in the Budget. However, along came the Moreton by-election and there were more promises of tax cuts. This puts the lie to what Senator Walsh and others have said that because of the rejection of the bottom of the harbour scheme legislation further taxes will have to be imposed. Who are we to believe?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —If any confusion and contradiction exist in regard to taxation policy they are certainly on the other side of the chamber. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle started her speech on this matter by saying that there was a degree of suspicion and cynicism about this Government's taxation policy. Honourable senators would agree that, in general, the community regards the question of politicians and taxation with a degree of cynicism. I suggest the origins of that go back to 1977 when the Liberal Party in government put through a Budget that it knew was fairly dodgy in most of its premises and then went to the electorate with the promise of taxation cuts for all. Newspapers came out with the headlines 'A fistful of dollars'. That was a most cynical exercise because on its return to government it did not have any intention of carrying out that policy of tax cuts. The cynicism in the community dates back to the policy of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle went on to say that the Australian Labor Party has reneged on its promises in such areas as the assets test and the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. It is interesting to note that the real confusion exists with those sitting opposite. Two points of view come forward from that side of the chamber. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and others have the view that we are inconsistent in regard to the assets test or that we have reneged on the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. We do nor hear from those people whether what we are now doing is right or wrong. We have no such problem with Senator Messner. He seems to be gullible enough to accept anything that the first carpetbagger brings to him. He is quite happy to go along opposing, in principle, the assets test and the tax on lump sum superannuation payments. He has absolutely no worry about whether the policy is right or wrong. He sees an opportunistic opening and darts in and puts the temporary Liberal line on it. I have no doubt, and everybody knows, that if by some accident or some horrific event in the future the Liberals come back to power in the next two to three years tax on superannuation will not be taken away and the assets test on pensions will not be removed. Senator Watson may be gullible enough to believe that the assets test will be removed but I can tell him now that it will not be, that the majority in his party probably supports both proposals and both attitudes. The only reason that the Opposition is coming forward with this matter of public importance is that it thinks it can make some opportunistic gains in the electorate.

Senator Messner made some fairly woolly statements. One of the first was that this Government had not taken one measure against tax avoidance in spite of its promises. Senator Messner must have been asleep during the whole debate on the deduction of source tax Bill, the reference from the Senate to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations and the report of the Committee. In fact, I remember participating in that debate, yet obviously he missed that point. I will later examine the attitude of the Opposition towards the bottom of the harbour legislation which we have twice brought into this place and which has been defeated.

Senator Jack Evans made the usual Australian Democrat contribution here. I call it the Pontius Pilate syndrome. He said: 'A curse on all houses'. He said that if only we were all nice, stopped fighting amongst ourselves and let natural policy come out everything would become some sort of modern day Camelot. He, of course, does have the best of all worlds, better than the Liberal Party or the Australian Labor Party. He will never have the experience of government, its conflicting demands, the problems of raising revenue or the problems of expenditure. I guess the one thing that Senator Watson and I would agree on is that the Australian Democrats will never have those problems.

I think the Liberal Party has put this case forward today just as a feel-out. We have had a lot of matters of public importance since we came back after the election. We have had about five on uranium and a few on wages policy. None of those have worked very well, so someone got a bright idea at 8 o'clock this morning and said: 'Let's have a try-out on tax policy'. Are the Liberals really concerned on this issue? There has hardly been a question on taxation policy since we came into Government. We have had questions on dams, on sex legislation and on this and that, but we have had virtually nothing on taxation. Honourable senators can look at the record of the Estimates committees. Members of the Opposition had the opportunity to ask questions of the people from the Taxation Office who appeared before those committees. They have hardly asked a question on taxation policy. Up until today the Opposition has not shown much interest in it.

The main thrust of what the Liberal Party has been saying in this chamber today is that the Labor Party has not been able to fulfil every election promise that it made. There has been no dispute on this side that we have not been able to fulfil every promise we made. We made those promises in good faith. There is no getting out of the fact that in the lead-up to the election the most the 1983-84 Budget deficit was going to be in the expectation of the people in the community was $6 billion. It was only on the Monday before the election that the figure of $9.6 billion was suggested to the then Government. Did Mr Howard release that information? He went and saw the then Prime Minister and said: 'Look, there is a $9.6 billion deficit. What should we do?' The bloke who was to break down on election night replied: 'Look, don't release it. It could influence the election '. Of course, it would have influenced the election.

When we came into office we were faced with finding another $3.6 billion, let alone trying to implement the rest of the policies. Therefore, being able to maintain a promise for income tax relief in that context was absolutely impossible. In a debate about contradictions and confusions, it is very interesting that no one from the National Party participated. These are the Opposition's allies in this chamber and across the hall. None of them participated in this debate and we know that is because of their rather quaint views on taxation. They are a bit like the Flat Earth Society. They support a flat rate taxation. No one opposite in the Liberal Party, I would suggest, supports that. But that is where the confusion is. What is the Opposition going to do when it next gets back into government? Will it kotow to the National Party line that suggests there will be a 20 or 25 per cent flat tax? I suggest that if the Opposition wants to clear up the confusion and contradiction it should first tackle that issue. I read Mr Peacock's statement on taxation of 30 September of this year. He has come up with hardly one original idea in relation to taxation. He has said only that there must be a move from direct taxation to indirect taxation but no upping of the overall level of taxation. That is all he has said. If that is his answer, I think the electorate will reject it absolutely. All he is really arguing for, as most Liberals do, is a redistribution of income from the poor to the rich.

The next question is when the Liberal Party is going to develop a tax policy. I am informed that at its recent Federal Council one third of the motions were on taxation, which again probably reflects the confusion that exists within the Liberal Party. It had many motions on all sorts of aspects of taxation. It is totally confused in its thinking. I think the Liberal Party is somewhat misguided in the way it is approaching politics at the moment.

It is obvious to anyone who read the Valder report that the Liberal Party, or a majority in the Liberal Party, believes that the Party get back into power by restructuring its organisation. It is concentrating on internal matters and it is not developing relevant policies for the Australian community. There seems to be no desire at all among those opposite and those in the Liberal Party generally to develop alternative and coherent policies to put to the electorate. Instead, the Liberal Party is obsessed with restructuring its branches, with changing its preselection systems. We had the classic case in Victoria in a conference a few months ago when one of the delegates got up and said: 'The problem with the Liberal Party is that it is putting morons into Parliament'. He described the people it is endorsing as wets, as wanks and as wimps. That is his description of people who were being endorsed from the Victorian branch of the Party. If honourable senators read the Valder report they will see it has those same obsessions.

I can give some advice to the Liberal Party from personal experience. The Labor Party, after its defeat in 1977, went through the same experience. When we lost that election we did not look at our policy and develop new policy; we looked at our internal organisation. I can tell honourable senators that nothing we did then to our internal organisation improved our chances of winning government one iota. Our chances of winning government started to improve when we actually started to develop alternative policies instead of giving in to the temptation of obsessive internal soul searching that the Liberal Party is apparently going through now. The advice is: Get out and develop some policy. Let us hear what the Opposition's tax policy is. Let us hear what its wages policy is. But we never do. All we hear are obtuse forms of matters of public importance like we have today.

I did promise to come back to one other point, and that is the matter of bottom of the harbour taxation. Another reason we have been unable to keep every promise is that one of the things we did promise was to legislate again in this area. We put everyone on notice last year about the sort of legislation we thought should be brought before these chambers. We fought on those issues at election time. We came into this House with a Bill passed by a massive majority in the House of Representatives, and what happened? The Opposition here, with a couple of allies from other parties, knocked out the Bill. It unreservedly knocked it out. Its record on this is just typical of the opportunism of the Liberal Party. What it says is this: 'There are certain imutable principles, one of which is retrospectivity. You can never indulge in retrospective tax legislation'. But of course there is always the let-out clause for the Liberal Party. Unless it is threatened with being thrown out of office, it will suddenly indulge in retrospectivity. That is what happened last spring. A majority in the party may have said that retrospectivity is an immutable principle but, with the threat of being thrown out of office, suddenly the legislation came in. Now there is no threat of the Liberal Party being thrown out of office-that has happened already-it reverts to its old principles. A very similar thing happened in Victoria some years ago with the question of pecuniary interest, if I may just draw an analogy. No Victorian Liberal in fact supported the disclosure of pecuniary interest of parliamentarians and a register thereof until the land deals came about. Suddenly the Liberal Government was under threat and suddenly it compromised its preferences.

As I said before, there is no point in this matter of public importance. I think the Government's tax policies have been quite consistent and quite justifiable in rational terms. Everyone is on notice that the next Budget will contain major taxation reforms. I should like to make one final point. It relates to capital gains tax and wealth tax. I want to comment on the question that has been raised by the Opposition in relation to death duties, wealth tax or capital gains tax. My name was mentioned by Senator Messner when he said that I was trying to run away from the issue. I do not run away from the issue at all . I believe that there should be death duties in this country. I believe also that the Commonwealth Government, sooner or later, will have to stand up to State governments which artificially give away revenue raising projects to attract more business or more people to their particular States at the expense of others. I hope honourable senators opposite realise the dimensions of that problem. We cannot keep reducing the tax base of States by having one State continually opt out in order to encourage all sorts of business to that one State thus giving it the competitive advantage. That is what happened with death duties in the mid and late 1970s. One State gave them up and that meant that they were not viable in other States. That does not mean that the basic tax was wrong. I have given reason that those particular taxes were dispensed with. Sooner or later the Opposition will have to face the fact, as we do, that we cannot afford to have one particular State government giving up certain taxes to attract businesses to it and then expecting the Federal Government to pick up the bill, to reimburse that State because it is losing revenue.

As I said earlier, the Opposition has not made out a case in this regard. It has not today proved in any way that the Labor Party Government policies are confused or contradictory. The one thing it has proved is that its own policies and attitudes are not only confusing and contradictory but also virtually non- existent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Oilseeds Research Committee report explains briefly the money that has come into government from levy collections from the industry. We pass such levy collection Bills regularly in this House. It is significant that there was a decrease in levy collections of $70,000 from the previous year, down to $229,270 mainly because of the bad drought conditions that prevailed over much of the continent. Nonetheless, the money is there, together with the contributions from the Commonwealth. It is being used in many and various ways towards the betterment of the industry. I think it is serving the purpose for which it was laid down. If one section of primary industry cannot recoup its costs it must become more efficient if those who are involved in it are to survive. Levies are one method by which the industry can contribute towards experimentation to become more efficient. If nobody else wishes to speak on this paper, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I commend the Department of Primary Industry on the report that it has produced. I accept it as being a good description of what has transpired. I am also pleased to see that its activities for the year did not rate a mention in the social pages of the Auditor-General's report. But I do believe that it would be prudent to make a few suggestions about the presentation of reports such as this from a department as large and as diverse as this. I believe that there is not enough information to help people at large-businesses, importers and exporters- make decisions for the future. I believe that suggestions by the Department on the operation of the markets and management of the country in the future would be most desirable. I believe, for instance, that matters to do with the international situation, matters relating to the recovery from the drought, the effects of the broad currency fluctuations that have arisen, the price of oil, the relativity of imports, the products that we meet on the world market and matters such as this need to be covered to some extent in the report before us.

Many of our industries are not looking forward with any great joy to the short to medium term future. We have only to look, for example, at the meat industry, the sugar industry, the fat lamb industry and some of the vegetable growers to see that we need to be giving them some guidance. If we cannot get it through the report of the Department of Primary Industry, there is really no other paper which will be of much use. Much of the information in the journal is now 15 to 18 months out of date, starting from July 1982. I see the report as a valuable document. I would again commend the Department on a good chronicle on what has transpired but I do make the suggestion that it should be more extensive. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would say that more than most primary industries the dairy industry is facing a very uncertain future because of the way it is currently going. For instance, I refer to the overproduction question. Overproduction looks like amounting to about 20 per cent this year and the problem will not go away of its own accord, nor will the matters which were raised by the Industries Assistance Commission in its recent report. Those matters, too, will have to be dealt with. I have said it before and I would like to repeat that more and more research needs to be done in the dairy industry to make sure that it becomes more efficient still. The fundamental matters of feeding and breeding are just as important now as they were 40 or 50 years ago and I think they still probably offer us about just as much chance of improvement even yet. There are many areas in which the Research Committee can still do a lot of valuable work. I touch specifically on a couple of those areas. Before I do, I must draw attention to the mountains of dairy produce that are still in the European Economic Community and the United States of America and the fact that those products are going to be disposed of. They are most likely to be disposed of in areas which we have considered to be our markets. They will not be our markets for much longer because these countries which are still subsidising their overproduction are going to dispose of that overproduction.

There are two things that I would like to mention: Firstly, the matter of education. The industry of the future will survive or fail on the competence, or lack of it, that the industry itself displays. I read the report from the Tasmanian training authority this week which now claims that more than 10 per cent of producers in the industry have undertaken various training courses. I would like to see this figure reach 50 per cent in the next three or four years before we go on to cope with the full 100 per cent. I believe that the two most important matters in the research area must be the training and dissemination of knowledge on the one hand and the merchandising and marketing of the product on the other hand. Without these two things the industry will not be able to survive in a world competitive situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the remarks made by Senator Archer. I made the point when speaking to the Oilseeds Research Committee annual report that we had imposed a levy on the industry. This is another matter in relation to which we have recently passed legislation to impose a levy so that industry contributes towards its future. As with all other primary industries, the dairy industry cannot recoup its costs in the market place as an ordinary manufacturer can. An ordinary manufacturer can add up his costs and include them in the price of his product. The industry has to operate in a competitive free market situation. The only way, of course, for this industry to survive is for it to improve. In my own State of Queensland in the last decade thousands of dairy farmers have left the industry yet those who have remained are able to meet the slowly increasing market. That is the only way that it can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry itself contributed $535,187. Of course, the Commonwealth Government also made a contribution. As Senator Archer said, that money was spent in many ways, not the least of which concerns educational programs. Factory workers are provided with study grants and travel grants. The money allocated is spread amongst the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, various departments of primary industries and universities. They all contribute in some way to making this industry more efficient, helping it to survive, helping us to meet our markets and, of course, in helping to eradicate some of the diseases which affect the industry. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
This is only a very slim report but it contains some very interesting facts and statistics. In the section that deals with the general elections that were held on 5 March 1983, it says:

The announcement was followed on 4 February by the issue of Writs for the election of 125 members of the House of Representatives and for the election 64 Senators. The electoral rolls closed at 6 p.m. on the same day.
I believe that is one of the great scandals of recent elections in this country. Further, under the heading 'Election Advertising', the report states:
As the rolls close at 6.00 p.m. on Friday, 4 February the day after the announcement of the election, it was not possible to place any enrolment advertisements in the media.

The result of that was that thousands of young voters throughout Australia were not able to get on the electoral roll. I think we will understand the then Government's reasons why those young voters did not get on the electoral roll if we look at a recent gallup poll in the Bulletin which showed that 63 per cent of voters between the ages of 18 and 24 intended to vote for the Australian Labor Party if an election had been held at the time the gallup poll was taken. I praise the Australian Electoral Office for the advertising that was arranged for each State to emphasise the casting of a formal vote for the Senate. Large newspaper advertisements using facsimiles of Senate ballot papers appeared in daily newspapers, supported by short radio announcements pointing to the appearance of these advertisements. In the section dealing with nominations the report goes on to say that 250 people contested the 64 Senate seats and that in New South Wales alone there were 62 candidates seeking election to the 10 Senate seats. We saw again the same old Tory tactics of trying to organise additional nominations to confuse the voters in New South Wales to try to get as many informal votes as possible to stop the Labor Party getting a majority in the Senate. The same tactics were used in 1974 and were successful. I am pleased to say that they were not successful this time. As a result of the electoral reforms that the Australian Labor Party will be bringing into this place shortly -people will be able to cast a formal vote much more easily for the Senate-this situation will not arise in the future. The report goes on to point out:
A total of 24,493 postal votes were cast at overseas locations. The largest single issuing point was London, where 7,088 votes were taken.
For the first time, Australian electors in Britain were able to vote outside London, the Australian Consulates in Edinburgh and Manchester being Postal Vote issuing points.

I believe that in fact all Australian diplomatic posts should be available for voting on election day. It has been my experience that in fact officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs are not particularly helpful in trying to assist people in voting. It is not their fault. Constituents have come to me and have said that they have asked officers at some of our foreign posts about the Labor Party ticket, about the Liberal Party ticket and about how they cast a formal vote in the Senate for a particular party. When confronted with a ballot paper with 62 squares the officers have not even been able to tell them what are the first three places on the Labor Party ticket or the first three places on the Liberal Party ticket. Again, if the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform are adopted, as I am sure they will be, in future the names of the political parties will be on the ballot papers. It will in fact encourage people to cast a formal vote.
In the section dealing with polling day, the report points out that 94.65 per cent of the enrolled electorate voted. That is a very good figure. The report also pointed out:
Votes of persons who signed declarations because their name had been struck off the roll or omitted (Section Votes) numbered 15,545 . . .

I put it to the Senate that in fact the true number would probably be more than 100,000 because I am sure all honourable senators are aware of the difficulty in getting people to fill out a declaration for a section vote. The average voter, when confronted with this situation, just does not bother to go through this procedure and claim his section vote. One of the things that arose out of the last election-complaints were made to me about this matter-was that apparently there had been an attempt to cleanse the rolls in some of the rural towns, particularly in New South Wales, in which universities of advanced education are situated. When the rolls are cleansed in these particular places it is very easy to get the students off the roll. A number of times during the year, of course, they are not there, they are back in the capital cities. After chasing up some of these queries it seems to me that in fact the same sort of cleansing procedures do not take place in relation to the rural properties. A lot of people have in fact left the rural properties. Younger people from rural properties happen to be away at university and live, for example, in Sydney. Their names may still appear on the electoral roll but, surprise, surprise, they still get a vote and still continue to vote in that particular rural electorate on voting day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Australian Electoral Office annual report for 1982-83 to express concern that there might be a lack of security in the printing of trade union ballot papers for elections . At page 12 of the report under the heading 'Other Electoral Activities' reference is made to industrial elections. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Registrar referred 416 industrial elections to the Australian Electoral Office under the provisions of section 170 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 during the year 1982/83.

That was the year under review. Further in appendix D of the report reference was made to the number of elections referred to the Australian Electoral Office. The number of elections referred to the Australian Electoral Office was 356 in 1978-79, 417 in 1981-82, and 416 in 1982-83. So there is a steady increase in the number of elections that have been referred to the Electoral Office.

Traditionally ballot papers in trade union elections have been printed in the various government printing offices, either the Australian Government Printing Office or the State government printing offices under tight security. In New South Wales, for example, there are secrecy provisions in the Crimes Act 1900, and there are Public Service regulations, particularly in section 159, which refer to secrecy. So there has been a tradition that the printing of ballot papers at the Government Printing Office is a matter on which there will be no controversy. They are very carefully checked and counter-checked so that all people can feel that the ballot is beyond reproach. In addition I have been informed that ballot papers can be printed within 24 hours and that they are done, as I have said, in the utmost secrecy.
Today I received a telegram from the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, in which he stated:

The New South Wales branch of the PKIU is presently having its annual ballots conducted by the Commonwealth Electoral Office and is receiving hundreds of complaints from its members in regard to the standard of the printed ballot paper and its lack of printer identification. Our inquiries have uncovered the horrifying evidence that the printer's ballot papers are produced from copy obtained from computer print out, forwarded to a leading computer manufacturer, Rank Xerox, who then print the ballot papers on government supplied paper. We object to this non-PKIU produced arrangement and question the matter of security of such arrangement. We request urgent review of these unsatisfactory practices.

The union is particularly outraged at the insensitivity of the Electoral Office because the National Secretary of the PKIU had received an assurance from the Special Minister of State, Mr Beazley, on 15 August that the facilities of the Government printing offices would be used unless there were real problems in those printeries in meeting the deadlines required by the Electoral Office.

The position is that the printers' union in New South Wales, using that as an example, asserts that the Government Printing Office is not working to full capacity, so that ballot papers could have been printed at the New South Wales Government Printing Office. This raises the important question, as far as the Electoral Office report is concerned, that ballot papers must not only be carefully accounted for but all things to do with trade union ballots must appear to be completely above board, and if ballot papers are to be produced in commercial printing houses there is a danger and at least there will be real concern that they will not be dealt with in the way in which they should be dealt with. So we cannot afford to have this looseness. The Electoral Office must look at the matter. I appreciate that in the past seven or eight years there has been a reduction in efficiency concerning ballots. That is something which must be addressed by a review of the Act; but it is a matter for another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report of the Australian Electoral Office mentions a range of items that come under its responsibility. It is interesting to note that in the last year the Electoral Office has been subjected to an overwhelming number of requests-to the order of six; two on access to personal records, two on access to instructions and guidelines, and two on other matters. In looking at freedom of information, it is also very useful to look back on what has happened and to note that the sorts of alarmist views expressed at the time have not come to fruition, and that the electors are much more responsible in their attitude to information collecting and usage than many parliamentarians gave them credit for.

An item on page 13 refers to electoral information, education and research. It is my hope that when the new Bill arrives-I understand that we shall be debating it shortly-the upgrading of this area will be a high priority. Within the limited resources the Electoral Office has had available to it, it has undertaken some very interesting and worthwhile projects. However, it has been severely limited in its educational role. The Electoral Office is well positioned and well suited to be the body which should involve itself in electoral information. The notion of political literacy is not one which is greatly lauded in this country. However, it is vital for democracy that political literacy be one of our aims.

People such as ourselves in democracies tend to take it for granted that democracies exist by their own effort; they do not. In every year in the last five years, the number of democracies in the world has decreased. That is an alarming prospect for those of us who value democracy so highly. We ought not to take for granted the continuation of democracy in Australia without a continuing effort on our part to make sure that the population knows of its worth and its ideals and subscribes to those ideals. When we get the next report from the new organisation which will take the place of the Australian Electoral Office, I hope that we shall be able to read a much larger section on political education and that it will have undertaken a much wider range of activities because the Government will have been able to provide it with additional resources and will have widened its legislative brief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 207th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. This report is the finance minute on report 192, which was a discussion paper on the collection and dissemination of statistics. The finance minute is the formal mechanism through which the Government responds to the Committee's recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Committee considers that timely and accurate statistics are an essential requirement for both public and private sector management. In particular, such information is required for monitoring the efficiency and effectiveness of policies and programs across the full range of governmental activities. Similarly comprehensive and up-to-date statistics are also required as a basis for advice on prospective new policies and programs. If comprehensive and relevant statistics are not available, then it is possible for Government policies and programs, formulated on the basis of incomplete information, to be directed away from the areas of greatest need. Even though the benefits that can flow from statistical information are great, so also are the costs of obtaining them. By any measure, the quantity of official statistics now collected is immense. Subject groups range over demography, education, health, welfare, national accounts, employment and prices, all industry groups, transportation and communications. The 1981-82 Budget appropriations for the Australian Bureau of Statistics total about $111m, of which $76m was for salaries of Bureau staff. Furthermore, the Confederation of Australian Industry claims that the cost of complying with Federal and State government regulations on the provision of statistical information was $3,700m in 1978-79.

SPEECH.PARA: Consequently, the Committee considered that it was important to produce a discussion paper covering such issues. This resulted in the 192nd report which discussed a number of problem areas associated with the collection and dissemination of statistics by the Commonwealth Government, and made suggestions aimed at effecting improvements in the quality of those statistics. It also considered more economical ways of carrying out the task, which, in turn, could have the added advantage of freeing resources for the collection of needed, but as yet unavailable, information.

The Committee's main recommendations were made in the following areas: The strengthening of the power of the ABS to co-ordinate statistical information; the establishment by the ABS of a central statistical register; the appropriate use of taxation data; that consistency be encouraged in standard data concepts, definitions and classifications; that the Census and Statistics Act be amended to allow for maximum utilisation of statistics; that overseas initiatives to reduce the paper burden imposed by governments on citizens be examined; the possibility of charging users for some statistical publications; and that an interdepartmental committee be established to advise governments on urgent matters relating to statistical programs and priorities.

As indicated in this finance minute, several of the Committee's recommendations have been accepted and consequently the Committee is generally satisfied with this response. The main policy revisions effected as a result of the Committee's recommendations are as follows: Firstly, the introduction of new measures designed to strengthen the co-ordination role of the Australian Bureau of Statistics; secondly, the amendment of the Census and Statistics Act to allow maximum use of available data; and, thirdly, the introduction of charges for a much higher proportion of ABS publications.

However, the Committee does have some reservations about this response to its 192nd report. In particular, the Committee considers that the Australian Bureau of Statistics should further explore the possibility of making better use of taxation data. The Committee will continue to pursue this area and several others which emerged from the 192nd report, with the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
I commend this report to honourable senators.
