The speeches read as follows-
Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Bill 1983

The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the 'no work as directed-no pay' provisions in the Public Service Act and certain statutory authority legislation . These provisions were introduced by the former government in 1980 in respect of the Public Service and six Commonwealth authorities: The Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Australian Postal Commission, the Australian Telecommunications Commission, the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Commonwealth Teaching Services and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission.

Introduction of these provisions followed a period of industrial disputation over pay and conditions and a decision by the New South Wales Supreme Court in Bennett's case, which overturned the accepted view that under common law provisions, Commonwealth employing authorities were able to withhold pay from staff refusing to carry out the full range of their duties. The Supreme Court held that the common law rights of employers to implement the no work as directed-no-pay principle had no operation in the Commonwealth employment area because the Public Service Act and regulations established a detailed and exclusive code of employment between the Commonwealth Government and its employees.

The Public Service and Statutory Authorities Amendment Act 1980 empowered the Public Service Board and specified authorities to declare that staff who fail to comply with an authorised direction relating to the performance of their duties are not to be paid salary. Such declaration remains in force until the board or authority is satisfied that the employee has complied with its directions. No appeal mechanism was provided in the legislation against management decisions and the Act specifically prohibited the making of awards or determination by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or the Public Service Arbitrator which were inconsistent with the provisions of the legislation. The justification for such legislation was to give the Commonwealth rights which, according to the then Minister, applied generally to employers in the private sector.

In reality, however, the legislation placed Commonwealth employers in a position different from private sector employers. The Common law rights of private employers to exercise no work as directed-no pay powers are not clear cut, particularly where employment is covered by an award of an industrial tribunal-for example in 1980-the same year as the decision in Bennett's case-the Full Bench of the Federal Court held in Gapes Case that this power was not available to a major banking company as it was not consistent with the award concerned. It is therefore clear that, in the private sector, the ability of employers to apply the no work as directed no pay principle is constrained by the terms of applicable awards.

In essence, then, this legislation created a situation where the then Government provided itself with sanctions against its own employees which were not necessarily available to all the private sector and, in addition, it put itself in the position where its powers could not be overridden by a decision of an industrial tribunal. This legislation was only one of a number of instances in which the former Government singled out its own employees for overly harsh treatment in the industrial arena. Prior to the 1980 legislation the Government had passed the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act allowing for the stand-down, suspension or dismissal of Commonwealth employees engaged in industrial action. In 1979 the Government attempted to sanction unions involved in disputes by withdrawing facilities for the payroll deduction of union dues. The former Government also prohibited recourse to arbitration in respect of management decisions under the Commonwealth Employees (Redevelopment and Retirement) Act.

This Government rejects such a confrontationist approach towards its own employees. The existence of legislation of this kind has acted against the development of improved industrial relations in the Commonwealth sector. Rather than encouraging a sound working relationship, such punitive legislation has actually led to a marked deterioration in employer-employee relations. The statement of accord between the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions commits the Government to a number of measures to meet its objective of improved industrial relations. In particular, the ALP undertook in the accord to adopt, and encourage other employers to adopt, a less confrontationist approach to industrial relations. Among other things this involved the encouragement of dispute settlement through conciliation without recourse to legislative or common law sanctions. More specifically, the ALP undertook to take steps to bring about a better industrial relations environment in the public sector.

This Bill is a first such step. In conjunction with the other Bills which I am introducing, the Government is now moving to repeal the confrontationist legislation enacted by the previous Government and to create a more rational industrial relations atmosphere in the public sector. Abolition of the legislative no work as directed-no pay provisions is consistent with the Government's objective that Australian Government employees should be treated in a manner consistent with employees in the private sector. These amendments do not mean that the Government does not have access to no work as directed-no pay if such action is necessary where unions institute bans and limitations. Rather we propose to remove the right of management to impose such action unilaterally. It is appropriate that Commonwealth employers who find it necessary to take staff off pay in dispute situations should have to seek authority to take such action within the context of an award or determination of the appropriate arbitral authority. This provides an opportunity for the views of all parties to be considered and is a far more acceptable process than the unilateral exercise by management of no work as directed-no pay provisions. It is highly desirable that exercise of such a power in an industrial dispute be sanctioned by an independent arbitral tribunal which has considered the full facts of the case.

I propose to indicate to the ACTU, and public sector unions, that this action is being taken by the Government in the interests of developing more harmonious relations in the Commonwealth employment sector. Consequently the Government would expect Commonwealth Employees and their unions to reciprocate by seeking to resolve their claims or grievances through the established machinery, including access to the arbitral authorities. I commend the Bill to the senate.
Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Amendment Bill 1983

The purpose of this Bill is to restore the pre-1981 jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator and the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and other relevant arbitral bodies to make determinations and awards in relation to the redeployment or termination of employment of Commonwealth staff to whom the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act applies.

Upon the election of the Fraser Government in 1975 the issues of redeployment and retrenchment of surplus staff increased in prominence. Previously existing guidelines for application to redundancy situations in Commonwealth employment generally were formalised by the making of Determination 509 of 1977 by the Public Service Abritrator. That determination applies to the greater part of Commonwealth employment and provides for advice to be provided to staff organisations where a redundancy situation is likely to occur, for appropriate notice periods to be given of impending redundancy, and of transfer or termination of employment. The determination also provides for income maintenance, depending on age and length of service of the employee involved. Further to these provisions, the former Government saw a need to extend the redeployment and retirement provisions of the Public Service Act and other Commonwealth legislation. Consequently the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Bill was introduced into parliament in 1979. It was proclaimed to come into effect in February 1981.

The CE(RR) Act provides a framework for the redeployment and retirement of Commonwealth employees on the grounds of excess numbers, physical or mental incapacity, inefficiency or loss of essential qualifications. Apart from the compulsory retirement provisions the Act also provides for the voluntary retirement of staff from age 55 and imposes a maximum retirement age of 65. The Act applies to the Australian Public Service and is administered by the Public Service Board. Statutory authorities not staffed under the Public Service Act can come under the CE(RR) provisions on request.

Staff organisations strongly opposed provisions of the legislation particularly those which they saw as giving the Government unprecedented rights to sack its employees. Following extensive industrial disputation, during which they were exhorted by the Prime Minister and other Ministers to take their case to arbitration, the staff organisations lodged an application with the Public Service Arbitrator. This application sought a determination providing for, among other things, procedures for consultation with staff organisations and minimum time to be observed before staff could be declared as eligible for redeployment.

In December 1979, a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission decided that a determination should be made which preserved the main features of Determination 509 of 1977. This decision had the effect of first, defining the nature of consultations with staff organisations before declarations were made under the Act; secondly, delaying by three months the declaration of staff for redeployment; thirdly, removing the scope for varying the times between the issue of notice and acting to transfer to a lower level or to terminate employment; and fourthly, giving preference in retention to staff organisations. A determination to reflect this decision as subsequently made by the Arbitrator- Determination No. 503 of 1980.

The then Government considered that this Determination altered the intention of the parliament in passing the CE (RR) Act-notwithstanding that section 24 of the Act quite expressly provided for the arbitration tribunals to make determinations inconsistent with the Act. The Determination was disallowed in parliament on 11 March 1981 and on 14 April-even though the unions had been urged in the first place to take their grievances to arbitration-amendments were made to exclude redeployment and termination of employment matters from the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is those amendments that we now propose to reverse. The restoration of the pre-1981 jurisdiction would be consistent with our objectives of improved industrial relations in the Commonwealth sector. The matters which would be restored to the jurisdiction of the tribunals are entirely appropriate for determination by them.

With the repeal, disputes over these issues will be capable of being fully dealt with by an independent industrial tribunal. The opportunity will, of course, be available for the Board and other relevant bodies to argue that the tribunal should refrain from exercising its jurisdiction in appropriate cases. Restoration of arbitral jurisdiction will not, however, complete the Government' s consideration of possible changes to the CE (RR) Act. As well as providing for redeployment and retirement action in the case of excess numbers and for physical or mental incapacity, the Act also provides for regulations to be made prescribing other reasons for redeployment and retirement. Following the consultations required by the Act a regulation was made in November 1982 prescribing inefficiency and loss of an essential qualification as reasons for redeployment and retirement.

It is the Government's view that the retention of an effective, but fair, system for dealing with staff who are surplus, inefficient or incapacitated or who have lost essential qualifications is critical to the effective operation of the Service. However, the provisions contained in this regulation are extensive and go considerably further than previous such provisions. Staff organisations have been especially critical of this regulation. Consequently, a review will be held into those areas of the Act which deal with management-initiated early retirement. This review will be conducted by a working group comprising representatives of the Public Service Board, the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the ACTU and the Council of Professional Associations.

At the conclusion of the review, which I envisage being early 1984, I will receive a report from the working party concerning possible amendments to the Act. Pending this review, the Public Service Board had, at the Government's request, advised that it will not take action to implement the provisions of the regulation. I must stress, however, the Government's commitment to an effective, but fair, system for dealing with staff who are surplus, inefficient or incapacitated or who have lost an essential qualification. It is the Government' s intention that the review should be conducted in this light and should be directed at the best means of establishing such a system. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Repeal Bill 1983

This Bill deals with an important aspect of the Government's industrial relations platform in relation to Australian Government employees. It seeks the repeal of the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act 1977. The CE(EP ) Act was introduced in haste by the Fraser Government in 1977 but was not brought into operation until 1979 as a response to a dispute between Telecom Australia and the Australian Telecommunications Employees Assocation. Basically, the Act provides, subject to ministerial direction, for the direct suspension or dismissal of Commonwealth employees engaged in industrial action, or the direct standing down of Commonwealth Employees affected by the Industrial action, without reference by the employing authority to any industrial tribunal.

The direct powers conferred on Commonwealth employing authorities by the CE(EP) Act are not only provocative but also unneccessary. It has always been open to these bodies to apply to the Public Service Arbitrator under the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920 or to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for the right to suspend or stand down employees engaging in, or affected by, industrial action.

The Government believes this approach to be the best way for Commonwealth employing authorities to be empowered to stand down staff in dispute situations. An application to an industrial tribunal provides an opportunity for the views of all parties to be considered and is a far more acceptable process than the unilateral exercise by management of the CE(EP) Act provisions which provide no right of appeal nor avenue of redress other than under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, which effectively only allows a review on matters of law and not on the merits of the decision.

The Government does not consider it appropriate that as an employer it should have statutory powers of the type found in the CE(EP) Act which are not available to employers in the private sector. The Government's belief is that in industrial disputes employers who wish to have the power to suspend or stand down employees engaging in or affected by industrial action should not object to making out a case before an independent tribunal. In this respect, honourable senators might note what the Committee on Freedom of Association of the International Labour Organisation had to say about the CE(EP) Act in its 187th report of November 1978. That Committee criticised the fact that the legislation could be invoked at the Government's discretion without the exhaustion of dispute settlement procedures, and expressed concern that there was no effective review of action taken against the employees. The Committee also stated that it was not convinced that legislation imposing punitive sanctions on public employees on account of their involvement in various forms of industrial action was either necessary or desirable.

The Act has been used on nine occasions and on each occasion there was widespread opposition from Australian government employees. Clearly the existence of legislation of this type acts against improved employer and employee relationships. In this respect I might indicate to the Senate that there is still a large number of actions before the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act brought by Commonwealth employees challenging the validity of their suspensions under the CE(EP) Act during the Department of Social Security staffing dispute in 1981. These actions were based on claims of denial of natural justice. Negotiations between the Public Service Board and the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association are still continuing on these actions. The rights of the individuals concerned will not be affected by the repeal of the CE(EP) Act. The National Labour Consultative Council has been consulted about the repeal of the CE(EP) Act and does not oppose that action. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to presenting the tabling statement on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, I pay tribute to the staff of the Committee, the Secretary to the Committee and the research staff, for the way in which they maintained their services to the Committee and helped us to present this very worthwhile report. I also pay tribute to the former Deputy Chairman of the Committee, former Senator Tony Mulvihill, who had an extreme and very deep interest in the preservation of the Abbott's booby. I believe that Tony would have been very pleased to see the presentation of this report today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee's inquiry into the preservation of the endangered Abbott's booby on Christmas Island arose out of its consideration of the annual report for 1980 -81 for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Under current arrangements, the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment each year receives 40 annual reports from Government departments and authorities , and statutory corporations. The question of how most appropriately to deal with this flood of information, in accordance with the resolution of the Senate enabling committees to inquire into annual reports, has posed difficulties since it became a regular practice of the Senate in 1976.

This Committee, under my predecessor as Chairman, Senator Jessop, has been most diligent in attempting to meet the intentions of the Senate under the terms of the resolution on annual reports. The Committee reported on annual reports in March 1978, in June 1978, in March 1979, and in May 1982. The report I tabled today is the latest in this series. Over the period covered by this series, the Committee has attempted to develop a method of carrying out its duty of scrutinising annual reports in the most appropriate way.

In earlier years, a common approach by standing committees was to examine briefly all the annual reports referred to them. These examinations tended to concentrate on the style, format and contents of the reports under review. Sometimes a summary of the problems raised by the reporting bodies was included. In its May 1982 report, the Committee criticised this approach as being shallow and superficial, and as not contributing substantially to the oversight by Parliament of the operations of the Executive. Limitations of time and staff impose severe constraints on the standing committees in attempting to use the review of annual reports as a means of overseeing the activities of the Executive. In the inquiry leading to its May 1982 report, the Committee tried to circumvent those constraints by selecting particular aspects of two of the 45 annual reports referred to it for examination that year.

During that inquiry, the Department and authority concerned-the Department of Science and Environment, and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Organisation-were invited to make written submissions on the five areas selected by the Committee for investigation. Representatives were then questioned at a public hearing. Subsequently, the Committee invited comment on some aspects of the evidence from interested persons and organisations. The approach adopted by the Committee on that occasion proved deficient in two respects. First, the examination of some issues was incomplete because the Committee heard evidence only from representatives of the department or authority whose annual report was under investigation. Second, the inquiry was delayed and some of the issues were out of date or overtaken by events.

Following its May 1982 report, the Committee resolved that it would continue the approach of limiting its detailed examination of annual reports to particular matters mentioned in a small number of selected reports. It was hoped that the Committee would be able to complete its inquiries into matters arising from its scrutiny of annual reports within a period of four months. Experience in the case of the Abbott's booby inquiry has proven this to have been an unrealistic aspiration. The annual report for 1980-81 for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service was tabled in the Senate on 15 October 1981 and referred to the Committee on 20 October 1981.

A resolution of the Committee of 19 May 1982 authorised the Chairman to consider the annual reports which had been referred to the Committee, with a view to selecting particular matters arising from them for inquiry. The Chairman recommended investigation of current plans for the preservation of the Abbott's booby on Christmas Island, and this was agreed to at a meeting of the Committee on 23 September 1982. Submissions were invited from interested organisations and individuals, and public hearings were arranged for 9 and 16 November 1982. Fifteen witnesses were heard during those two days, and 346 pages of evidence taken.

A field visit to Christmas Island was arranged for early February 1983, but was cancelled by the dissolution of Parliament. Following the convening of the present Parliament and the reconstitution of the Committee, I announced to the Senate on 19 May 1983 the resumption of the inquiry. The Committee visited Christmas Island and, on the way there, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, from 8 to 12 July last, and undertook an extensive inspection of the phosphate mining operations there and their effect on the natural environment of the island, with particular attention to the Abbott's booby. We also had discussions with representatives of the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas island, the Union of Christmas Island Workers, the Administration of Chrismas Island, and local community organisations, which covered a wide range of matters relating to the island's economic and social welfare.

I table the report on the preservation of the Abbott's booby today, a year after the Committee decided to take up the matter for investigation and two years after the annual report from which the inquiry arose was tabled in the Senate.

We have exceeded the aim we set ourselves in our May 1982 report, of reporting on the selected annual report within four months of its tabling in the Senate, by a considerable margin. I feel no need to make any apology for this. The general election and change of government earlier this years probably added three months to the period of the inquiry. Before and after the general election , the Committee conducted its inquiry expeditiously and without unnecessary delays. My main point is that the worthwhile conduct of an inquiry will occupy a certain, virtually irreducible, period of time-generally a minimum of about six months.

In view of this, I feel it is advisable that matters chosen from annual reports for further investigation should, in most cases, be of relatively long term interest. The inquiry we have conducted into the preservation of the Abbott's booby on Christmas Island did cover a matter of long term interest. The question of the Abbott's booby is very closely tied to consideration of the future economic and social welfare of Christmas Island. Christmas Island is now at a most interesting stage in its history. The island has reliably supplied Australia and New Zealand with phosphate for all of this century. The importance of Christmas Island phosphate to Australian agriculture led to acquisition of the island from Great Britain in 1958.

The time has now come when the end of phosphate mining as the sole industry on the island can be envisaged. The Government recognised this when it commissioned Mr W. W. Sweetland to inquire into the long term future of Christmas Island in 1981. Mr Sweetland presented his report to the Government in February 1982, and the Committee looks forward to seeing the Government's response to that report. Phosphate mining has had an adverse effect on the Abbott's booby by causing the destruction of large areas of the forest in which it nests. The bird was once more widely distributed throughout the tropical islands of the Indian Ocean. When those islands were settled, with the exception of Christmas Island, their forests were destroyed and the bird became extinct. Human settlement began on Christmas Island only in 1888, and up to now has had less effect on that island than on the other tropical islands of the Indian Ocean.

Christmas Island still preserves, over much of its area, the natural environment which existed before human settlement began. The Abbott's booby is one of the most distinctive of the animal species inhabiting the Christmas Island forest. The forest also contains other interesting animal species-for example, the fourteen different kinds of land crab. The red land crab can be seen in great numbers after rain falls on the island. A survey in 1978 by the Western Australian Museum discovered 16 new species of fish inhabiting the Christmas Island coral reef. The island forms a unique ecosystem, which is of great value for scientific research into population dynamics, genetics and evolution.

There has tended to be a conflict in the past between the need to conserve the island's forest and the need to recover phosphate. The Committee found that the plans and procedures for future phosphate mining agreed between the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, in March 1982 and May 1983, provided a satisfactory framework within which recovery of most of the remaining phosphate deposits could proceed in a profitable way, without having an unduly detrimental effect on the viability of the Abbott's booby population.

The satisfactory way in which the new procedures are operating was illustrated by the answer which my colleague, Senator Townley, received to a question which he put during the sitting of Estimates Committee F on 15 September last. The answer made it clear that when the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island wanted earlier this year to clear forest in field 25, it had to provide a satisfactory justification to the Government Conservator, who is an officer of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. It was only after this requirement had been complied with that the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) agreed to clearing going ahead in preparation for mining.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The clearing will proceed in accordance with an agreement reached on 21 May 1983, which is described in the Committee's report.

The Committee was concerned that there has been no appreciable re-afforestation of the total area cleared since mining operations first began. There is doubt over the legal liability of the Phosphate Mining Company on Christmas Island Ltd for re-afforestation of areas cleared before it was formed in June 1981 to succeed the British Phosphate Commission.

Another obstacle to re-afforestation has been the possibility of recovering the large amount of high-grade phosphate left in the ground by the current method of mining by 'clam-shall' excavator. A method of recovering this phosphate using a pneumatic suction machine is currently being tested. It is important that large- scale re-afforestation commence soon, and this is something which the Union of Christmas Island Workers supports. Both the Union of Christmas Island Workers and the management of the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd have a very positive attitude towards nature conservation. In particular the work of the company's Conservation Officer, Mr David Powell, MBE, deserves commendation.

It cannot be denied that the phosphate mining industry on Christmas Island is currently going through a difficult period from the point of view of profitability. Given effective management and the co-operation of the workforce, it can survive this period to continue for another decade to provide a significant proportion of the phosphate requirements of Australia and New Zealand. Alternative industries to phosphate mining must be developed if Christmas Island is to be able to continue to support a healthy community. The Committee has made some suggestions in this regard. The value of the Christmas Island forest and its unique animal and plant species could be quite significant for the economic future of the Island.

The 1972 UNESCO Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and National Heritage, to which Australia is signatory, states that each State which is party to the Convention should take all possible steps to ensure the transmission of the natural heritage situated in its territory to future generations. Christmas Island is the only example of a South East Asian type of ecosystem over which Australia exercises territorial jurisdiction. Australia has a clear obligation to preserve the Abbott's booby, under the terms of the 1974 Australia/Japan Agreement for the Protection of Migratory Birds and Birds in Danger of Extinction and their Environment. This obligation is implemented through the Territory of Christmas Island Migratory Birds Ordinance 1980, which lists the Abbott's booby in Schedule 2 as 'a bird of a species in danger of extinction.' Mr President, I commend the Committee's report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this report as one of the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. It could be asked why a Senate committee should devote its time to the welfare and future continuance in this world of a breed of seabird. I can only say that the fate of the Abbott's booby bird has been a source of concern to people around the world and I am glad the Committee has investigated the issue and concluded that for the present this species is likely to survive and that earlier fears for it are now mitigated. The total disappearance of a life form from the planet ought to be a source of concern to all its human inhabitants, and I think that, increasingly, thoughtful human beings share that view.

SPEECH.PARA: Behind this issue of the Abbott's booby, and at the same time closely involved with the bird's future, as the Chairman of the Committee has just said, is the overall future of Christmas Island itself. In other words, if the Abbott's booby is to survive in the unique circumstances necessary for its survival, its environment must be preserved and, in my view, this will happen only if Christmas Island itself, which is an Australian territory recently acquired, maintains a viable and prosperous future. Certainly I believe that there should be an extension of the present national park on the island, at least to the extend of the recommendations made by the Committee. As Senator Jones said, the island has depended on phosphate mining for its income for a long time. Indeed, before phosphate mining it was not inhabitated at all and the Abbott's booby and other species there were undisturbed for many centuries. That is one of the reasons the island preserves now such a remarkably interesting environment. How it will survive after phosphate mining is no longer viable, as seems only too likely the next few years, is a matter for consideration. How can its population , largely made up of Chinese and Malay people, be sustained? Should they be repatriated to their homes in Malaysia or Singapore, or to Australia? Should other industries be established there and, if so, what industries? These things will have an important bearing on the future ecology of the island and I think ecological considerations like the ones which the Committee considered there must have a bearing on any future decision made by the Australian Government on behalf of the islanders.

We have acquired a considerable responsibility with this remote island well out into the Indian Ocean. Is its future and that of the Abbott's booby best served by it continuing to be an Australian territory? That is a point that has to be raised because a line of arguments that ought to be taken into account says that this place might at some time become the Australian equivalent of the Falkland Islands-a defence obligation which could become dangerous. Fortunately, for a number of reasons Christmas Island is not considered to be in a critically important defence zone. I believe that for many reasons, including that one but also because of its environment, we should not try to make it a defence base in any sense at all. One reason is that unless it were massively armed, at enormous cost, it would not be possible to defend it. In other words, if we put in a bigger airfield and a reasonable amount of defence material these probably would be quite readily captured and used against us by a determined adversary. Such are the facts of the island's geography. We should get our thoughts clear on that issue and try not to see Christmas Island as a future defence base for Australia.

What should be done with it? Certainly the curious feudal system now prevailing there must be changed. It must be totally obnoxious to all Australians that here is a piece of Australian territory which nobody can visit except on sufferance from the monopoly company which controls the island-that is, the phosphate interest. It is high time some changes were made to make Christmas Island more like the rest of Australia and more capable of looking after its own affairs, including the future of the Abbott's booby. People should have the right to own or lease land, which is not possible now, to set up independent businesses and control their own affairs through a duly elected public authority-in other words , a local council. On the other hand, residents of the island should pay for services such as water and electricity which are now paid for by the phosphate enterprise.

A number of possibilities exist for Christmas Island. It is argued that its remoteness from Australia would make a major tourist industry there difficult but I do believe, having seen the place, that there is scope for some such industry because of the great natural beauty of the island and its diverse and quite remarkable life forms. I think it has potential as a visiting place for cruise ships and persons returning to Western Australia from South East Asia. This is one area that could be looked at in the general light of the future of the Abbott's booby and its habitat. The island could also be used for a variety of marine research including, because of the great depth of sea around it, the ocean thermal effect method of generating electric power which could be tested on a small scale and used to provide power for the island. Fisheries research in the region on which a fishing industry could be bases would be useful. After all , if we can import fish profitably from Europe and Japan to this country we should certainly be able to do so from Christmas Island.

Basically, I think the moral and lesson of all of this is that there has been an opportunity, because a number of honourable senators have visited the island and can make these points known, for the Government to see that Australia has an obligation to this place. A careful study should now be made of the most viable practical future which Christmas Island can have so that we appear to the world, and this is important, to be fully responsive to the interests not only of Abbott's booby but also the other life forms, including human, of a very diverse and beautiful environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the report that has been presented by Senator Jones, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. I think this represents another example of how useful committee work can be if occasionally we select an annual report of a department, statutory authority or another area of interest to a particular committee and subject not only the officers of the department to scrutiny and public hearings but also invite submissions relating to the report from the general public. I think that in that way we can elicit quite a lot of useful information from these reports. Unfortunately, in the past reports have been accepted without any real scrutiny by the Parliament. The departments go through the motions of presenting some detail of their annual activities but very infrequently do we find that departments project into the future some of their intentions and objectives within departmental activities. I believe the Committee has presented a very useful document dealing with the Abbott's booby bird, or Sula abbotti, which is the ornithological name. The bird is very interesting. Chapter 1 of the Committee's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Sula abbotti, judging from its physical features and feeding habits, is a long- distance flier, ranging many hundreds of miles from its only home, Christmas Island. One of the species of fauna endemic to the Island, it always returns to the same forested area, preferably to the same nesting site, to breed. It requires a long breeding time to produce surviving offspring. Whereas some other boobies produce four chicks, the Abbott's Booby produces at best one chick every two years. It therefore has a low reproduction rate. Its population is hard to replenish if decimated by a catastrophe. There appears to be no pressure on the species arising from lack of food, as the seas within range have pentiful supplies of fish and squid. Current research indicates that, in order to maintain its numbers, the bird is long-lived: on average, one pair requires 26 years to replace itself by producing two breeding offspring. Egglaying occurs between April and August and breeding and caring for young occupies about 15 months . . . Therefore it is possible for the bird to have only one breeding cycle in two successive years. It produces a larger and heavier egg than any other species in the Sulid genus. The chicks grow remarkably slowly and take 20 weeks or more . . . to reach a fledging stage. The young are then dependent on their parents for food for at least another 30-40 weeks . . . After achieving independence a further four to five years is required to reach maturity.

It is no wonder that the bird can be endangered. Some of the clearing that has occurred as a result of phosphate mining on Christmas Island has somewhat restricted the habitat and the breeding areas of the bird. If honourable senators read this document carefully they will find that it is most interesting . It also mentions other endangered species. There are several of them which are of great interest. They are illustrated on page 29 of the report. The report mentions birds such as the Christmas Island Frigatebird and the Golden Bosunbird , which are very beautiful birds. Many people in Australia and throughout the world happen to be very interested in the survival of these endangered species. I was glad to note that Senator Jones mentioned the former Deputy Chairman of the Committee, former Senator Tony Mulvihill. He was very interested in bird and animal life. As a matter of fact, I wonder whether we could name some sort of species after Tony Mulvihill as a tribute to the work that he has done on the Committee. We will have to talk to the museums of Australia to find out whether that is a possibility. I think he would be very thrilled if a possum, a bird or something like that could be named after him.

TALK.START.PARA: —A wombat.

—Senator Baume mentioned a wombat. Strangely enough, he does not know how close to the bone he happens to be, because former Senator Mulvihill is a member of the organisation in South Australia which is seeking to protect the hairy-nosed wombat. I am sure that Senator Mulvihill would be pleased if we could do something like that for him.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention also Mr Peter Roberts who was a former Secretary of the Committee. He organised the original visit which was, as the Chairman said, aborted by the untimely election which changed the course of events. Peter Roberts did a lot of preparatory work. He is an amateur ornithologist and bird watcher. I am sure he would have enjoyed the opportunity to see at first hand the habitat of this most interesting bird. I think it would be appropriate also to acknowledge the co- operation that we received from the Phosphate Mining Co. of Christmas Island Ltd . The company went out of its way to provide us with transport. It provided hospitality for us on that occasion. I mention also the Union of Christmas Island Workers whose members were very kind. The Secretary organised a function for us so that we could talk informally to the people who worked there. We found that was a very useful exercise to undertake. I think we ought to pay a tribute to everyone who assisted the Committee on that occasion, including the Administrator, Bill Yates, who looked after the Chairman and me on that occasion at his home. I wish to put that on record.

I believe the report does stick fairly closely to the purpose for which the Committee went to Christmas Island. The Committee was concerned that some areas may be looked at by the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission with respect to further mining operations. I think Senator Mason mentioned that we would like to think that the Government and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service will look at the question of extending the national park area so that no further encroachment is made on the habitat of this bird. The company is very concerned about it also. The evidence that I gathered from talking to the officers of the company indicated that they were co-operating to the best of their ability. The Committee said there was no problem with respect to continuing operations of the mine providing regard was paid to the matters that we, I thought effectively, drew their attention to.

The Committee was anxious to examine the Government's response to the report of the Sweetland Commission of Inquiry into the Long Term Future of Christmas Island. The Sweetland report went further than our terms of reference enabled us to do. Senator Mason referred to future development in the area and foreshadowed his concern about that. I do not think that at this stage the Committee is in a position to make any positive recommendations about that because it did range a bit outside the terms of reference. However, as the Chairman said, we were anxious to examine the Government's response to the Sweetland report. I think the report does indicate a number of industries that could perhaps follow once the mining operations on the island cease. I commend the report to the Senate. I thank Mr Robert King and the rest of the staff for the work they have done in order that we could present this document to the Senate today. I support the Chairman's remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last time this Committee met-it seems, I must say, an interminable time ago-the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, asked me whether the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations engaged in regular forecasting of unemployment on a month to month basis for the year ahead. He asked a number of other questions, I think in pursuit of trying to obtain a picture of the method of forecasting and assessment of various government departments. However, particularly the question was directed in my case at the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Senator Grimes has made some general comments which I think may have had relevance to the Leader of the Opposition's comments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury is the department which carries the responsibility of macro- economic policy advice. It is the department which sets the figures on which the Budget is based. In doing that, it has some input from other departments. But I think, if I might be not regarded as unkind, it is a fairly desultory process. However, throughout the year there are consultations and continuing contacts between the Treasury and other departments for the general purpose of informing the Budget program. I am advised that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations does not prepare forecasts of unemployment rates and the number of unemployed or benefit recipients on a month by month basis. It is considered that the uncertainties would be too great to allow any confidence in using such specific forecasts for the purpose of labour market analysis. The Government's view of the labour market was set out, in terms of the best available estimates, clearly in the Budget statements.

The recent increase in employment is, of course, encouraging to the Government and the Opposition, as Senator Chaney put it, and is consistent with the view taken at Budget time. I must say that the Government is not unduly sanguine as a result of those recent figures and Senator Chaney himself drew attention to the fairly wild fluctuations in the figures that have occurred in the last couple of months. I remind the Committee that on both occasions in respect of both months the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has been very cautious in attributing any particular pattern to the figures which have emerged in the course of the last two months. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to intervene in front of Senator Baume who is seeking the call. However, to continue on this point, I thank the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) for the advice he has offered on behalf of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. SPEECH.PARA: I might forecast that I and perhaps other honourable senators will be raising this matter when we subsequently deal with the Department of Social Security and the Treasury in groups B and C. In the manufacturing industries overall there has been a drop of 59 per cent in employment in the 12 months from August to August. The drop in employment in the metal products industry has been 19.6 per cent and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it shocking what you did?

—Actually, I am interested in what the trend has been in the last few months because what those figures do not tell us is what has been happening the last few months. The aggregate figures show that the unemployment figure has not been improving and has been worsening. I would like the Minister to attempt to reconcile the two sets of figures about which Senator Chaney and I have been talking.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quite deliberately made the point when I intervened in the previous debate that we have several sets of figures. The first set of figures and the set to which I referred related to the number of people receiving unemployment benefit. That is an absolute figure. We count the numbers. It is not an estimate, it is not a survey; it is an absolute figure. The simple fact is that the number of people receiving unemployment benefits has dropped to-I do not have the figures in front of me because I am getting them for the next set of estimates-I think 601, 400 or 604,100 or about that level. I am talking about the number of people receiving unemployment benefit. I made the point at the time that quite clearly that figure was different from the figures which result from Australian Bureau of Statistics surveys which are about the number of people in the work force and the number of people seeking employment. I think we have to remember that, in unemployment surveys by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, anyone who works for more than an hour a week is considered not to be unemployed. That figure is quite different from the number of people who are on unemployment benefit. The unemployment benefit figure also excludes those wives of people who are employed and who would be in the work force normally.

SPEECH.PARA: I made the point that, whereas last year the number of people on unemployment benefit rose dramatically from 325,000 in May to 540,000 by the end of the year, this year the number of people actually receiving benefit actually levelled out and then dropped. How any of us reconcile those figures is a matter for discussion. Whether it means that in this case a number of people are, for all sorts of reasons-perhaps they have more confidence in the economy-now registering for unemployment benefit and putting themselves forward as being available for work and therefore the number of people on the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures rises artificially, I do not know. It is for that reason that I have not, in this place or outside this place, claimed that, because there is a drop in the number of uemployment beneficiaries, there is a dramatic improvement in the economy. I am saying that at least it is a hopeful sign that we have gone back to the trend of previous years, with the exception of last year, when the number of beneficiaries dropped over the months of July, August, September and October. I am also well aware of the fact that come the end of the year there will be a large number of school leavers on the market and the figure will go up again. I make the point that they will have to go up fairly considerably to reach the average level of 680,000 that Senator Chaney quite correctly mentioned is in the Budget figures. Those are Treasury estimates. Treasury, undoubtedly, makes those estimates with regard to economic forecasts and with regard to information from other departments. The Department of Social Security receives the applications and pays the money. It is not in the business of economic forecasting, nor has it ever pretended to be. The point I was making was that last year the figures were patently wrong on Budget night. No one in the Opposition suggested this time that the figures were patently wrong on Budget night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ascertain the amount that has been earmarked in the vote for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations for the review of the Australian industrial relations system which was established by this Government. I received a response from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) to a question that I asked on 14 September relating to the decision of the High Court of Australia. The implications of the decision will also be of direct interest to the Committee of Review of Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems that has been established by this Government. To situate this matter properly, let me refer to the question I asked Senator Button on 14 September. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister will have noted the broad interpretation of section 51 (xx) of the Constitution by Justices Murphy, Mason and Deane in the Tasmanian dam case. I ask whether the attention of the Minister has been drawn to these comments made by Mr Justice Murphy in Canberra on 5 September 1983 in a seminar on 'Changing Industrial Laws':
The future course of federal industrial law will, I think, show a much greater reliance on the corporations and commerce powers than hitherto.
Is this the view of the Government and, if so, how would award workers be protected from interference by this or future parliaments in matters concerning their wages and working conditions?

My attention has been drawn to an article which actually predated my question of 14 September and the articles in the Australian of 6 September by Paul Ellercamp . In referring to a statement made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, Paul Ellercamp quoted Mr Willis as saying that he had ordered his Department to examine them-that is to say, the Tasmanian dams case and the community youth support scheme case-to see how the Government powers could be expanded. Frankly, I am at a loss to know, and I have not been told, what the Government's attitude is to Mr Justice Murphy's statement. Mr Justice Murphy is entering into political debate more and more. It is something that he has to be challenged about, and I am challenging him about it. The only way in which I can do that is through the Government, because if what he says is correct-that is to say, if the future course of Federal industrial law shows much greater reliance on the corporations and commerce power than hitherto-that will be detrimental to the workers of Australia. I note that the Minister, Mr Willis, in his statement as reported by Paul Ellercamp emphasised the importance as he saw it of the other decision, that is to say the CYSS decision, with respect to its implications for the broadening of the powers that were considered to be available under section 51 (xxxv) of the Constitution. Is there a separate inquiry in the Department into these particular cases? If so, when will the results of that inquiry be tabled in the Parliament or reported by the Minister? How is the committee reviewing Australian industrial relations law and systems going to deal with this issue in the absence of any submission or information supplied by the Minister? In short, I would like to know what the Minister's views are in relation to Mr Justice Murphy's comments?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do not wish to be accused of immodesty but, with respect, one needs a far less brilliant mind than mine to understand that question, as Sir Max Beerbohm once said. It is a very complex issue, as Senator Harradine points out. First, let me say that Mr Justice Murphy, as I understand it, was speaking at an industrial relations seminar at which he expressed a particular view about the application of the corporations and commerce powers following the two decisions to which Senator Harradine referred. I take it that it is implicit in Senator Harradine's question that he challenges the right of Mr Justice Murphy to make such comments . I could simply avoid the question, I suppose, by saying that I do not propose to give a legal opinion about Mr Justice Murphy's view expressed at the seminar. But I think it is implicit in the honourable senator's question that in some way the Government should persuade Mr Justice Murphy, if that is not too gentle a word, that he should not make such comments. I do not know whether that is the honourable senator's view.

SPEECH.PARA: I am then asked how the comment of Mr Justice Murphy will benefit those workers who are paid under various industrial awards. I am not able to express an opinion on that and I do not believe the Government has one. But the fact of the matter is that, as the honourable senator indicated, Mr Willis, the Minister, asked his Department to refer the implications of the two cases to the inquiry by the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. That inquiry, as far as the Government is concerned, is an independent one and it will report to the Government in due course. When it does so, the Government will presumably act or fail to act on the recommendations of that report. At that stage I suppose, if the inquiry has anything to say about the application of the corporations and commerce powers to the industrial relations power, that matter will be an issue for public discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will that report be tabled?

—I believe it will. That is the Government's intention, as I understand it. I believe it will be a public document. What I am really saying is that I cannot answer the question now but I am explaining why. I think the question the honourable senator is seeking to raise will be in the arena of public debate when that Committee publishes its report.

—Does the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations agree with the Minister for Industry and Commerce in his comments about the impact of wage on-costs and the importance of conducting a form of review of the impact and the seriousness of those wage on-costs? I have no disagreement whatsoever with the Minister for Industry and Commerce in relation to his comments about the seriousness. A recently published Australian Industries Development Association survey shows that there has been a growth from 39.4 to 43.9 per cent in the past year-a significant growth. There are a number of problem areas which perhaps the Minister would like to comment about. For instance, will something be done by this Government to endeavour to get one of the very significant areas of labour on-costs, that is State payroll tax, removed by negotiation with the State Premiers for some substitute provision by the Commonwealth to enable the payroll tax handed over to the States in the early 1970s now to come back to the Commonwealth and be removed as a start to reducing this tax on employment? I think everyone agrees that there is a problem , first, that it constitutes a tax on employment and, secondly, that the States need some substitute form of revenue, or at least claim that they do, if they are to remove it, because it is one of the significant parts of the tax base available to the State governments. There are some further matters to which I would like to make reference a little later, but I just ask those two questions of the Minister at this stage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked whether the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations agrees with me in respect of what I am supposed to have said. I would like to establish right at the beginning what I did say in relation to this matter. I have not got the reference in front of me but I am quite happy to supply it to Senator Rae if he wants it. It was in a speech to the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia on Monday of last week.
—I have seen the speech but I presume there was some add-on to warrant the reporting it was given.

—Just let me answer the question and see how we go from there. The point that I made was that a number of factors relating to industry competitiveness in Australia had to be considered. I made the point that add-on costs were in Australia. I mentioned long service leave as an example as something which we have in Australia but which does not exist in other countries . I said that on-costs in Australia are estimated to be roughly 45 per cent. I then made the point that if our add-on costs were at a level of 45 per cent they would be broadly consistent with the average for the Organisation of Economic Co -operation and Development countries for on-costs and that in the discussions about this issue it was not sufficient for Australian industry to rely on that figure when one looked at the comparative figures overseas. I then said that these were matters which, in my view, had to be addressed. By way of background I might say that I discussed this figure with a German industrialist, a very large employer in Germany, only six or seven weeks ago. I said that the add-on wage costs in Australia were fairly high. He made the point that in Germany they were in the order of 70 per cent. In Germany, companies pay the social security benefits as well as everything else. That is the contribution in Germany.
—Company tax is a bit different, though, is it not?

—All sorts of things are different-inflation is different, company tax is different-and the figures are very difficult to compare. I have certainly had a discussion with the Minister about what I said. I have also said other things, but they are broadly consistent with that view that I have just put to the chamber. I gave the Minister a statement of what I said. I suppose the best way to find out whether he agrees with what I said is for someone in the House of Representatives to ask him. I am not trying to avoid the question by saying that. But he clearly understands what I am talking about and I think we are in susbtantial agreement on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator asking the question then went on to talk about payroll tax as one example of on-wage costs which is said to be detrimental to employment-it certainly is a tax on employment-and what could be done about that in terms of the Commonwealth and State governments. These questions, of course, can be asked in a broad variety of context-'Why does not the Government do this? Why does not the Government do that'. I am not trying to detract from the importance of the question. I would just say that governments often do not do these things as the previous Government did not do them over seven years and the one before that over three years and the one before that over 27 years because they have other priorities which seem at the time to be more important in terms of the Budget allocations. Nonetheless, I think it is an important question which we, as a government, have to look at in conjunction with the State governments, just as we have to look at the enormous increase in workers compensation premiums which is probably the most significant portion of the increase in one-wage costs in the last few years. There has been an enormous escalation in workers compensation premiums. Perhaps in 1975, if we had gone a little further, and I am not speaking in a partisan sense, with the development of a national compensation scheme, we might have made a contribution towards containing some of those costs. The question of how the principles of that scheme can be re-addressed is one which is occupying government attention at the moment and, indeed, was before the election. I understand that the honourable senator has more questions that he wants to ask.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, has referred to in relation to workers compensation insurance relates to industry and employment. It seems to me to be of very serious consequence, something which the Minister has just acknowledged. I quote from the Australian Industries Development Association survey Bulletin No. 353 of August 1983. In relation to workers compensation insurance it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over 1982 and in the years since 1974, workers insurance costs have been the fastest growing components of labour costs. In 1974, workers compensation costs contributed some 4 cents per hour to total labour costs. Six years later, this had grown ten fold to 40 cents per hour. Far from slowing, in 1982, the rate of growth in workers compensation costs rose by a massive 45 per cent.
I acknowledge that the Minister did say that it had been a significantly growing component.

The employment aspect to which I wish to refer is this: Are there indications, coming particularly from manufacturing industry, that we are creating in Australia a group of employment untouchables, comprising people who have either made a workers compensation claim and, if they are honest when they are applying for a job, are rejected, because they have a claims record? Alternatively, I refer to the other component of the employment untouchables, the people who fail the medical tests which seem to be becoming a far more signifcant part of any test that is given to people before they are taken on for employment. This medical test is done in preference to a skills test because, again, employers are concerned about what is happening with regard to workers compensation. In the light of the Minister's own view and in the Minister's knowledge are there any plans in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations or elsewhere within the Government, for a review of some sort to see what can be done in relation to the adverse impact on employment which workers compensation appears to be constituting, to the stage where many employers claim to be engaging in automation and robotics to avoid employment, not because it is cheaper than employment? This move is having, possibly, an extremely adverse effect on employment opportunities for Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae is addressing the question of what he calls employment untouchables which he has identified in this case as being people who have been, perhaps on more than one occasion, claimants in respect of workers compensation as the result of injury or alleged injury or illness received at work, and, secondly, those who do not comply with the requirements of medical examinations conducted by certain employers at the time these people are employed. Frankly, I cannot answer that question. I do not know. I have really heard of no specific complaints about that problem. However, of course, the disabilities which attract particular people in relation to employment are a much more widespread problem. All sorts of forms of discrimination exist in employment which are, in a sense, not unrelated to the sorts of matters which Senator Peter Rae has mentioned. Certainly there is a degree of discrimination in employment on the basis of age, I think, and matters of that kind. I am instructed that there is no current inquiry by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations to investigate whether the sort of problem which Senator Rae puts before us in a theoretical manner is a real one. But I think that sort of inquiry and its ramifications are enormous in terms of the numbers of matters which might be taken into account in discriminating against people in respect of employment.
—He should read the Woodhouse report.
—Rightly, I think the honourable senator draws attention to the great demarcation dispute which is looming and that is not between different categories of people. It is between people and machines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst Senator Button was answering that question, there was an interjection which suggested that perhaps I should have a look at the Woodhouse report. I would simply point to the fact that the Woodhouse report is now fairly ancient and the changes to which I referred--
—And so are you, Senator.

—Yes, I am prepared to accept that some of us are not getting any closer to our youth. At least I hope we are not. I simply refer to the fact that the figures I quoted from the AIDA report referred to the extreme change that has taken place between the period of that report and now. I want to ask the Minister about another aspect of employment. I refer to an article in the Canberra Times of 17 August. I do not necessarily expect the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) to recall the article immediately when I refer to it. It was entitled 'Thousands sew at home for a pittance'. It sets out what is happening in relation to the home sweatshop-type conditions which are being imposed on a lot of people in the rag trade. It is claimed that an estimated 53,000 clothing-industry outworkers making up a pool of sweatshop labour now produce about 70 per cent of all clothes manufactured in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister: Does the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations have any information which might either confirm or refute that sort of claim? Can the Minister broaden his answer from that article to which I specifically referred to the general situation of the growth of outworkers on a piece work basis doing work which is not subject to award rates and not subject to employment conditions and the on-costs which have loaded the Australian manufacturing industry with what is seen by many of them as costs which make them uncompetitive. I am talking about the general situation. Is there a large growth in outwork being done? Is this something which is done where the people involved have virtual sweatshop conditions imposed by the nature of their contracts? Can the Minister elaborate at all on that situation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are all sorts of things which make Australian industry uncompetitive. Although on- costs might be one area which decreases the competitiveness of Australian industry there are many other areas. I must say that--
—Like bad management.

—Yes, like bad management, as an honourable senator interjects. As Minister for Industry and Commerce it is very refereshing to visit companies such as one which I went to last week. It is a metal trades establishment which employs some 700 people and which exports to most countries, including Taiwan, and it has no assistance.
—There are some good stories like that around Australia.

—There are plenty of good stories like that around Australia. The more we hear about them the better it is for the interests of industry in this country. I come back to the question of outworkers. I have not read the article in the Canberra Times but I must say that in discussions at the Textile and Apparel Industry Advisory Council two or three months ago the view was expressed by representatives of the Clothing Trades Union at that meeting that they regarded outworking in the clothing industry at lower rates of pay as a much greater threat to employment in their industry in Australia than imports. There was some disagreement, but not serious disagreement, between the employers and the Clothing Trades Union about that question at that meeting. Of course, each of us has his own impression.

SPEECH.PARA: A relative of mine visited a Vietnamese family in Melbourne last weekend. The front room of the house had four sewing machines in it which were all being worked on a Sunday afternoon. I am sure that sort of thing happens a great deal. Arising from that meeting of the relevant industry council, I understand that officials of my Department were to have further discussions with the industry about that matter. There was a genuine willingness, I believe on behalf of the manufacturers represented at that council to see what they could do to contribute to any investigation which was conducted. I can add nothing further than that. It is a serious problem and it is particularly important in that one industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I invite the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) to bear in mind that he might extend any inquiries he makes beyond the clothing industry, the rag trade, to some of the other sectors of manufacturing industry, including electrical and a number of sections where work can be done at home in the same way as the work he was just describing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask a further question in relation to employment arising out of the Government's steel industry plan and to note that part of the reason for the introduction of the steel industry plan was to safeguard the employment and, if possible, to increase the employment opportunities in the steel cities and towns of Australia and to stop the downward trend that is taking place. I refer the Minister to his statement of 11 August in relation to the steel industry plan when he said:
Contributions from the New South Wales and South Australian State Governments were also expected now that agreement had been reached between the Commonwealth and the industry.

Has there been any further agreement with the States? Have the States, as anticipated, agreed to participate in the plan in any way in holding back costs at least by not increasing charges even if they are not prepared to decrease some of the charges which I think most people accept have been loaded on to sections of the steel industry in recent years. Can the Minister indicate what stage negotiations have reached? What are the employment prospects? The Minister will note that earlier today unfortunately I was at another meeting when the appropriations for the Department of Industry and Commerce were before the Committee. I am trying to ask now the questions which I wanted to ask earlier in relation to employment because that is what we are dealing with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite prepared for Senator Peter Rae to come through the front door with his questions if he wants to. He does not have to go around the back door all the time. I was asked first of all about the question of employment under the steel industry plan. One of the purposes of the steel industry plan was to provide secure long term employment in the steel industry. I believe that, subject to qualifications which were incorporated in the plan right from the beginning, that has been done . The level of acceptance of the plan amongst the work force is very high. I visited each of the three steel centres in recent weeks and, as I said, the level of acceptance is high. The level of performance is high. The results are good, particularly in terms of the performance of the companies concerned and the aggression that they have been showing in marketing and in the levels of production.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asked specifically about the question of State charges and how they bear on employment. I point out that approaches made by the Commonwealth to both the New South Wales and South Australian governments in respect of contributions to the plan have not produced results at this stage, but negotiations are proceeding. I am advised by the New South Wales Minister that a submission will be put to the New South Wales Cabinet on the issue shortly. I cannot recall the current state of play in relation to South Australia. What was sought from the State Government in relation to charges on the steel industry were not decreases in charges but rather an element of predictability during the life of the plan and, particularly, an element of predictability which would ensure that charges were not raised above the level of inflation in any defined period. I still hope to get contributions from the State governments on those questions. In all other respects, the plan is working very satisfactorily and I believe will continue to do so. But if the implication of the senator's question is that the best laid plans of mice and men and of even the Federal Government can be upset by State governments or any other government which imposes heavy charges on an industry, yes, I agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the Minister's generous offer, and I ask him a question in relation to the Department of Industry and Commerce. The Department has been asked to develop procedures to prevent the speculative transfer of tender quotas. Is it a fact that the Minister has made no announcement as to what has happened with the development of these procedures? Is the Minister able to inform the chamber what progress has been made and what stage of development has been reached? This is a matter to which a question on notice was addressed some months ago. That may help the Minister's recollection, if he has seen it. As I understand it, the request for information was made by the former Minister for Industry and Commerce in December 1982.
—Like the size of the deficit in March of this year, that is something about which the former Government did not tell me.
—Or the Department?

—Or the Department. I was not told about an inquiry made in 1982. In the course of this year, probably in June, I certainly asked the Department to look at this matter quite separately of any previous government action in the matter. But I did not do so with a view to producing a result before next year. It was not in any sense a formal request. It is a matter upon which advice has been sought.

—The next question that I address to the Minister is in relation to industry advisory councils and the Australian Manufacturing Council review. What stage has been reached in that review of the Opposition's participation? Is the furphy correct that it will be announced next week that there will be no parliamentary participation on any of those councils?
—No, on this matter nothing will be announced next week.
—Can you answer the other part of the question?

—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. Progress has been made on the structure and terms of reference of the Australian Manufacturing Council and the industry councils, and consideration is now being given to the final question of composition. The other question to which the Government had to address itself was that of an independent secretariat for those councils. That matter is also well advanced. It is anticipated that the revised councils will be in operation early next year.

—What progress has been achieved in relation to the steel industry plan which promised fast track anti-dumping procedures? When does the Minister anticipate that the new procedures will be able to be announced and implemented?

—There is no intention to announce the new fast track anti-dumping procedures in relation to the steel industry. They will be activated by the steel industry authority, when it is appointed, when the steel industry plan comes into existence on 1 January 1984. It is not anticipated that the mechanism will be needed in the foreseeable future because of the general situation of the industry but, if it is needed, those procedures will be activated on the recommendation of that body. I have no intention of making any announcement about the matter prior to the establishment of the steel industry authority.

—Again I ask a question in relation to steel. The proposed steel mini-mill in Brisbane involves a mill which had been put into production for a relatively short period in Toulon in France just before the steel industry world-wide crash. It has been proposed that it should be purchased by an Australian who apparently has an option and has been putting together a consortium to construct it in Queensland. If that goes ahead, what impact is it likely to have on employment in the existing steel industry cities and towns, and what impact is it likely to have on the steel industry plan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, if the honourable senator is asking me for my view on that matter, I have to say that I do not have a wild degree of enthusiasm about it because I think that the days have gone by when Australia can support any industry that wants to come here in competition with other industries.
