But there is a more general observation that does not relate in detail to the particular question which has been addressed to me. I understand that discussions and negotiations are taking place between the proposers of that venture and the Queensland Government, and that there has also been some shopping for financial assistance for the venture. I am not sure how successful that has been.

SPEECH.PARA: I regard the future of that proposal as being by no means assured at this stage . Naturally, as it was mooted, I have taken the opportunity to discuss it with others already involved in the steel industry in Australia, and they take the view that their improved performance and their competitiveness are now such-and will be improving into the foreseeable future-that the venture to which Senator Peter Rae has referred would not be viable and that it would have no substantial effect at all on their operations as the prime integrated steel industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister, finally, about the developing country preferences review which was announced by the previous Government and was still proceeding, I think, when I last raised the matter with the Minister in May. It was then anticipated that it would be completed by May, but, if not, definitely in June. What is the state of progress in relation to that? When might it be completed? What has been the cause of any delay that may have arisen in relation to it?

—I do not have the same degree of confidence as I apparently had in May, for very obvious reasons, about a solution to that matter. I believe that there will be one in the next two or three weeks. I would not wish to foreshadow what it is likely to be. But, needless to say, a variety of very different views impinge on a solution to that problem, particularly in relation to trading relationships with particular countries which have been, perhaps, the greatest beneficiaries of developing country preferences into Australia. I do not think there is any harm in saying that it was a matter that was to be discussed with the Korean delegation which was coming here recently and which was the victim of the bomb explosion in Rangoon. Factors such as that, amongst other things have been partly responsible for the delay; I am not saying that that was the sole factor. A resolution of that matter has to be reached fairly soon and I am hopeful that it will be in the next two or three weeks.

—Perhaps I can just clarify that by asking: Does the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) still support the concept that we should accept without question the United Nations list of developing countries and then provide the preference to the countries which manage to gain listing there as opposed to our being a little more circumspect and having regard to the development of those countries and our trade relations with the various countries?

—No, I do not accept the United Nations listing as having any particular validity for Australia. I think one has to look at the two impacts of developing country preferences-the effects on the economies from which imports are coming and the effects on the economy of Australia. Insofar as the effects on the economies from which imports are coming are concerned, I do not think I have to remind Senator Rae that some of the countres which are now beneficiaries of the Australian system of tariff preference when that system was in place had economies which were then equivalent to the poorest economies of the underdeveloped countries now.

—I wonder whether the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) could give me the total increase in staff, permanent, part time and temporary, for each department. What is the estimated increase in staff in each department by the end of the financial year?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the specifications of the question involved the total of part time and temporary staff. I cannot answer those questions off the top of my head.
—Are there officers present?

—Yes, there are officers present, but Senator Walters should listen for once to what somebody says. I said that I cannot answer those questions off the top of my head, and I do not have a whole lot of officers from all departments sitting on the top of my head, thank goodness. I will certainly obtain those answers for the honourable senator and, if she wishes, I will obtain them in writing. I can inform her that the estimates of increases in staff are very slight. Senator Watson is flagging me down for some reason.
—I am telling you to calm down.
—He's not ruffled.
—A Tasmanian debate is going on over there as to whether I am ruffled. I will obtain the information for Senator Walters as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of Communications
Proposed expenditure, $376,673,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address some questions relating to division 220, Sub-division 1, item 01, Salaries and allowances. It might be most appropriate if I turn to Budget Paper No. 5 where some figures are set out at page 220. There has been concern within the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, particularly amongst those who are associated with the news services, that there may be some move to truncate the news services and to take on contract syndicated news services in their place. Attention has been drawn to the table on page 220 headed 'Australian Broadcasting Corporation Operational Expenditure' and containing certain salary items. The salary items for the radio news service show, for example, that whereas in 1982-83 the expenditure was $8. 484m, only $8.274m has been appropriated for 1983-84. Similarly, if one looks down the list to the television news service, one finds that the appropriation in 1982-83 was $5.733m and for 1983-84 it is only $5.512m. In dollar amounts that is less for 1983-84 than for last year. Whatever the rate of inflation is or is anticipated to be, one would expect a salary increase.

SPEECH.PARA: The question has been put to us: What is the explanation for the diminution in the appropriation? There is one obvious possibility. I wonder whether the Minister could tell us how many pay days there were in each of the two financial years. In the event that the answer relates to the number of pay days, if I divide the figures by 26 or 27, does that in fact make up the difference? Can the Minister tell us why the appropriation for salaries is at that level? He might even be able to tell us the expected employment level in these news services for each of the two years.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me say that the battle about the future of the news services was sort of raised when the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill was in the House. The Bill, in its ultimate form, was drafted in a manner which satisfied the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Staff Association, amongst others, that there was no intention to reduce the news services as a result of the capacity to take outside news services such as AAP for motor accident cases and things of that kind. I cannot answer the question that Senator Baume has specifically directed to me about the very small decline-I think even in real terms it is not a significant decline-
—I think it is; I am not trying to score points.

—Anyway, I cannot answer the question tonight because there are no officers here from the ABC who might be able to answer that question. If Senator Baume is content for me to take that question on notice, I will obtain an urgent answer for him from the ABC.

—Yes. If we take the appropriation for 1982-83 of $8.48m for the radio news service and do a rough division by 26, assuming there were 26 or 27 pay days, that comes out at about $0.32m. If one adds that $0.32m to the appropriation for 1983-84 it brings it to $8.59m and that in real terms would not be the same appropriation for salaries this year as there was last year. We certainly did not go searching through Budget Paper No. 5 and alight upon this at page 20. It is an expression of concern from some people that these figures may in fact indicate something that has not been made public. I would be grateful if the Minister could explain to us why the figures vary like this, what the levels of employment are and whether there is some simple explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) cannot have 101 advisers in the place to cover the various aspects of communications, but I would like just to express some concern as to where the outback now stands with the Aussat satellite system . There have been many reports in the media, correct or incorrect, supposedly of statements being made by one Minister or another. There is a lot of concern among the people of the outback about what they can expect from the satellite system. The Minister would be aware of the Isolated Children's Parents Association, that organisation that looks after the interests of isolated children, particularly those in the outback.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent Press statements have implied that the Government will make decisions on the allocation of the Aussat 30-watt high power transponders and that they will be networking nationally. As I understand it, if they are networking on the eastern coast of Australia, it will have a deleterious effect on reception in the outback. Not only that; there will also be no specialising in programs such as local news, local community programs, adult vocational education programs, Aboriginal programs, educational programs and the like. I ask the Minister whether he is in a position at present to indicate to the Isolate Children's Parents Association and the people of the outback the present position. Are matters still in a state of flux? Is Cabinet, or is the Government, still considering the situation? If it is still considering the situation, when is it expected that some definite information and news will be available for the people who are most concerned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody can expect anything from the Aussat satellite until the latter half of 1985, when it actually goes up. In terms of the proposed use of the satellite, the Government is very conscious of the concerns of outback and remote communities. Those two categories of communities were perhaps confused-not intentionally, but in some way-in the honourable senator's question. First, there are the concerns of regional television stations which are likely to be affected in the longer term, at least, by any use of the satellite. Secondly, there are the interests of even more remote communities to which regional television does not reach.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kilgariff referred to the Isolated Children's Parents Association as being one body which is probably more particularly concerned with the interests of the furthest remote areas. That, in a sense, has been represented in part by a body known as TV Australia, which has made representations to the Government about a method of using the satellite for services to remote communities. The Government is examining all these proposals. A final decision has not been made but, as I understand it, it will be made this year. The people will have a year or 18 months to think about it before the satellite goes up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for giving at least some information on the situation. I now turn to the actual ownership of the Aussat satellite. Is it the Government's intention that Telecom Australia should be the responsible authority for the administration and operation of the satellite, or does the Government still lean to its being owned by Aussat Pty Ltd? That would mean that the Government would completely own the shares. A possibility which has been discussed in some areas is that private enterprise would purchase some 49 per cent of the shares. Is the Minister in a position to indicate what the Government is thinking at the moment?

—The Government has not made a decision on this matter. Again, it is a matter which comes up in the same context as the use to which the satellite will be put, which Senator Kilgariff asked me about in his last question. I think it is probably fair to say that Aussat Pty Ltd will own and manage the satellite. The question is: Who will own Aussat? That is a question which has not been finally determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one further matter which is of some concern. I take the Minister back quite a few years. Actually, I take him back to the days of Cyclone Tracey, when Radio Australia was blown apart on Cox Peninsula in the Darwin area. At that time the authorities were considering transmitters to beam high fidelity radio signals throughout the outback. The people of the outback would have been able to receive Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs originating in Darwin. This beaming from the Cox Peninsula would have covered the whole of the outback. For various technical reasons, as I understand it, that proposal has changed considerably. It has been thought in the last two years that these outback transmitters should be based in places such as Katherine, Tennant Creek and Alice Springs. These outback transmitters would act as an umbrella to cover the whole of the outback. They would provide a very good reception to people no matter where they were in the outback.

SPEECH.PARA: Plans had been progressing quite well, I had thought, judging from various media and Government reports that this form of communication would be available next year. But at the moment there appears to be nothing forthcoming as to what is happening in bringing about this type of communication. Is the Minister in a position to indicate the situation in regard to these inland transmitters providing some umbrella type of coverage that would bring to the mining fields and the Aboriginal settlements and into the houses of people working in the outback ABC programs with a quality of reception as good as that experienced in towns and cities?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understood it, the Cox Peninsula project was related to Radio Australia.
—This was an aspect of it that I was speaking to.

—I understand that that was implicit in Senator Kilgariff's question. Although that facility was originally considered as being useful for the Territory in providing an umbrella, as Senator Kilgariff terms it, it was subsequently decided to provide a series of smaller umbrellas. I think it is no secret that the planning division of the Department of Communications has had a heavy backlog of work. I recall asking Mr Sinclair, when he was the appropriate Minister, how far the backlog extended. He replied that there was a 10-year backlog. That was about 18 months ago. Since then there has been some progress and additional funding was made available in the Budget to the Department for speeding up the planning process. In this Budget $600,000 has been appropriated for the specific purpose of the inland service stations to which Senator Kilgariff referred. I do not know how far that takes it down the line, but work is in progress on that and a definite start has been made in terms of commitment of funds.

—I ask a question concerning the extension of television services on Eyre Peninsula, particularly with respect to the provision of assistance to the private operator on the peninsula. For some time now he has been trying to extend the commercial television service to Leigh Creek and Woomera as well as to other parts of that more remote area of South Australia which do not enjoy benefits of regular commercial television broadcast . I just want to know what progress is being made through the Department of Communications with respect to that area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to inform the honourable senator at this moment of what precise progress has been made. I am told that the honourable senator has been asking this question since 1975--
—Earlier than that; 1969.

—Senator Jessop has been asking this question since 1969 and in that whole period it does not seem that much progress has been made. I am unable to account for the last seven months out of the total period to which he refers but I think his patience has been such that if he would allow me the indulgence of providing him with an answer on the progress which has or has not been made, I will do that.

—That is a reasonable response. I would like also to ask whether, in the context of the satellite service that is contemplated for Australia-I noticed Senator Kilgariff followed that line of questioning with respect to Aussat-some provision will be made to provide commercial television services with access to that facility and whether the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications can assure the Senate that consideration will be given to the smaller operators in the regional areas of Australia that are providing local services which are of great value to the people living there.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, consideration is being given to them, and has to be given to them. They have provided a very valuable and important service over many years and their interests must not be ignored in the use of the satellite.

—I draw the attention of the Committee to the provision of ethnic television in Adelaide. As many honourable senators would know, the former Government promised the introduction of ethnic television in Adelaide in this financial year. I understand that the Government has given a commitment to introduce ethnic television in that city in the next financial year, 1984-85, and I am seeking an assurance from the Government at this point of time that that is definitely going to occur and that planning is being undertaken by the Special Broadcasting Service along those lines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware, from my own knowledge, that the Special Broadcasting Service has been planning the extension of the Channel 0-28 television facility to Adelaide. I understand that whatever is necessary has been committed for next year in relation to the extension of that service.
—I would just like to ask the Minister whether it is certain that the service will be established in the next financial year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing in this life is certain, but I believe so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question I wish to ask the Minister. I refer to the radio telephone system which operates throughout the outback but which is now in a most chaotic state. This has been brought about by the development that has taken place in the outback. There are now more settlements and mining fields. The population of the area is increasing with the result, as I have said, that radio telephone system now is absolutely chaotic. People on the radio telephone actually have to wait for hours to get a call through. Of course, one can well imagine that it could be very dangerous in emergencies if communication cannot be made with the various centres which can provide relief to the people making those emergency calls.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that some work has been done to remedy this situation. Perhaps a new type of radio telephone could be installed. There have been many media reports about a wonderful new system that will be brought to the people of the outback which will make their lives plain sailing. This has been going on for quite a long time, despite the complaints of the people in the outback, despite the chaotic situation and the fact that emergency systems are required. There has been no real answer to their problems. Is the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications in a position now to indicate what is happening within Telecom Australia? There have been many promises. Can Telecom indicate when the people of the outback are likely to get this new digital transmission system? There has been much talk about it but no results. Can the Minister give any indication of when Telecom will honour its promise by endeavouring to improve this rather chaotic situation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to answer that question at the moment. My recollection is that Telecom Australia, in parts of Queensland, has installed at least on an experimental basis, the digital transmission to which Senator Kilgariff referred. I am unable to say anything about the outback radio telephone services but perhaps I can make an inquiry about that on behalf of the honourable senator and let him know. I hope I have clear the implication in his question. It was not that the Government had been talking a great deal about this. I think the honourable senator was referring to Press speculation and I think that is correct-there has been Press speculation about it based on what has happened in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
GROUP B
Department of Social Security
Proposed expenditure, $653,298,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, before we start to consider the estimates for the Department of Social Security, I wish to raise a matter concerning the Department of Health. It was not until this afternoon that I received the answers to the questions that I had been promised during the sittings of Estimates committees. I do not think other committee members received them, either. A number of questions are still not answered. Seeing as I did not receive the answers until so late and have not had time to peruse them, could we put of consideration of the estimates for the Department of Health until tomorrow when we have had time to look at the information? I do not know whether Senator Elstob received these answers any earlier.
—It was late this afternoon.
—We have not had time to read the answers provided by the Department to us; so could we put off the Department until tomorrow?

—Senator Walters, you are talking about the Department of Health. I called the Department of Social Security. Of course, it is possible that we will not get to our consideration of the Department of Health tonight; so could we wait until we are closer to considering the estimates of that department and then the Committee can make a decision as to whether it wants to proceed or bypass them.

—The reason I suggested this course of action was that if we agree to the consideration being postponed there is no point in keeping officers from the Department of Health for perhaps another one and a half hours. It seems to me illogical to keep the gentlemen from the Department waiting if we can make the decision right now.

—I intend to proceed with the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Social Security, unless the Committee considers otherwise. The question now before the Chair is that the votes for the Department of Social Security be passed without request.

—If the Clerks help us to prepare the appropriate procedural motion, may we move it in a couple of moments when it is ready? Senators Walters , Elstob and Messner have indicated that they did not receive answers to questions until today. All they want is some time overnight to examine the answers. Mr Temporary Chairman, if you say that you want a procedural motion I am perfectly happy to move one. It seems to me that it would be easier if we could deal with the matter by way of an agreement.
—The Chair is happy if an agreement is made. The Chair cannot proceed without some procedural motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In an attempt to do the right thing, I seek leave to make a statement on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no reason to disadvantage Senator Walters or anyone else who has not had the opportunity to read the answers from the Department of Health. I merely make the comment that it never seemed to concern her when the Opposition was in government that we did not get the answers until late in the afternoon when the appropriations were being considered. However, if Senator Walters needs time, I have no concern about deferring the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Health. I assume that Senator Walters is willing to go on with the consideration of the other departments after the Department of Social Security, the answers from which I assume, she has had time to read, if she has any interest in them at all.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Baume said, the Opposition would have liked time in which to prepare a procedural motion. If Senator Walters and her colleagues received the answers to the questions this afternoon I would have thought they would have had time to approach me as the Minister or the Government and would have had plenty of time to prepare a procedural motion. If members of the Opposition cannot get their act together I am still willing to concede that they need time to read the answers to the questions. Therefore, I am perfectly happy to delay the consideration of the Department of Health until tomorrow, the next day or whenever it comes up. I just point out that it is interesting that when we were in Opposition this never seemed to be of any concern to Government senators at the time. Because of their new found concern we are willing to concede that they need time to consider the answers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for his forebearance. I simply make the point that a significant number of questions, were unanswered at the Estimates Committee hearing.
—There is every year.

—That may be so. I understand that the answers have been received by one or two honourable senators. I certainly have not seen answers to my questions. I have not had the opportunity of going through them. Consequently , I would like the opportunity of doing so before the Committee proceeds further in its consideration. A great deal of work has yet to be done. I thank the Minister for his action. I hope that he will move the appropriate motion when the time comes.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Peter Baume) agreed to:

That after the consideration of the votes relating to the departments of Social Security, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Housing and Construction the consideration of the votes relating to the Department of Health be postponed until the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first issue that I would like to raise in this Committee relates to a matter raised by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Robertson in connection with the valuation of shares for the purposes of the assets test. Honourable senators will recall that the Minister made a point in connection with the effect upon person's assets, that is those assets being taken into account to determine a person's entitlement to a pension. He was commenting upon a rumour which indicated that shares could not be sold in the period following the Budget when the announcement was made that all subsequent valuations would be taken into account in determining people's entitlements. The Minister sought to make the point that, as a result of that decision in the Budget, that did not preclude people from selling shares and, thereby, taking part in any commercial activity which would otherwise have been taken into account in determining eligibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the Minister's comments, it seems to me that he has made the point during the course of his remarks that consideration would be given to the sale of shares. I ask the question: By virtue of his statement yesterday is that consideration to be exempted and not taken into account in the calculation of entitlement for the assets test, whereas if it had been left in the form of shares it would have been taken into account?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I get the gist of the honourable senator's question. The question I answered for Senator Robertson was a question which arose from rumours which had been put around that , if someone had shares-I interposed or any other property-and they sold them, by selling those shares for a consideration that would be considered deprivation and the person would have been deemed to have still possessed the shares. Quite clearly that is not so and never has been so. For instance, if I may go through it in a few stages, if someone has $10,000, $20,000, or whatever you like, under the assets test which was in existence before, that was deemed to have been yielding 10 per cent. But if someone spent $5,000 of that on a trip around the world that person would receive due consideration for that $5,000. There is no question that that person would still be considered to possess that $5,000. But if that person gave that money away for the purpose of qualifying for the income test at the moment, or the means test if it were in existence, he would still be considered to have that asset.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of shares or any other property, if people sell them and receive a consideration for them tn they are not deemed to have deprived themselves of that amount of money for the purposes of the income test at the moment, or the assets test in the future. If they receive $10,000, $20,000 or $50,000 for those shares then that amount of money is on assets which they have and it will be counted in the assets test. But it will not be considered to be deprivation if they have sold those shares for a consideration. It may well be considered in the assets test. I would expect that, although we have no assets test at the moment-a fact which is known to everyone in this chamber but apparently is not known to Mr Sinclair in another place-if they give those shares away for the purpose of qualifying for the assets test they would be deemed to be still in possession of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for his answer. Could he also tell honourable senators what value of the shares would be taken into account in any financial year as it is quite possible that pensioners will have difficulty in trying to assess whether or not they should sell their shares and take advantage of the opportunities that the Minister has just outlined? Could the Minister tell us whether that entitlement ought to be taken into account on 30 June in any particular year, or in any other part of the year, or perhaps on a day to day basis? Could he please give us some indication of how that might be calculated?

—I would have expected that past practice would have been utilised in this area and that would be that the share value is the market valuation at the time of determination of the income and assets. First of all, provision is available for appeal under the social security system to a person who is subjected to that valuation. People did not have that right before. Secondly, if there is a drastic change in the value of shares they can seek a revaluation. That is the way we are thinking at the moment. But I point out to the honourable senator that, as everyone else here knows, we have been in consultation with various groups in the community and within government and the bureaucracy to determine the details of the assets test which will shortly be put before the Parliament. I think that then, rather than now, is the time to discuss this matter because in fact the assets test, apart from the cost of the staffing provisions which is contained in the estimates, is not the subject of the Appropriation Bills.

—The other question I have concerns the various reports that we have been asking the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) to present to the Parliament in connection with the decision making process which led to the Government making its decision on the assets test. As I understand it, a working group of officials was set up on 30 March 1983, some 25 days after the election of the present Government, to consider all retirement income policies. In fact, I understand that that group made a report to the Government on 1 May 1983 which covered issues relating to occupational superannuation and the age pension system. It included the reintroduction of an assets test. It was obvious that the May mini-Budget decisions resulted from the report of that group. But it is significant to note that the assets test was not included in the mini-Budget of 19 May. I ask the Minister: What recommendations were made in that report about assets testing? Can he confirm or otherwise that the report recommended in favour of assets testing? Can he outline to us the reasons why the Government did not accept those recommendations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested to see that Senator Messner continues his fishing exercise. The Government, as I have said in this place, set up a working party of officials on or about 30 March 1983 to examine retirement policy. That working party consisted of officers from the Treasury, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance and the Department of Social Security. I think that the Australian Taxation Office and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat were also included. That group's report, as the honourable senator said, was submitted on 1 May 1983 and covered all sorts of issues such as occupational superannuation, as I remember, and the age pension system. Certainly, any comprehensive report like that would have had to include the reintroduction of the assets test. That report was considered before the May economic statement- the mini-Budget, as Senator Messner calls it. But it was not the sole determinant of what should be considered in that May Budget. My recollection is that it broadly canvassed all the options. As a result, another working group was set up on 27 July consisting of the Department of Social Security, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of Veterans' Affairs specifically to examine the assets test issue alone. It reported some time before the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: After assuming government in March we were faced in April and May with a very difficult economic situation. As a result of this working party, of the expenditure review committee of Cabinet, of the many consultations between various departments, and of the Economic Summit we made certain decisions in May . As a continuation of that-and we said at the time that the May economic statement should be considered as part of the whole budgetary process-we went on to consider the Budget. In the Budget we announced that we intended to reintroduce an assets test and to discuss that assets test in the post-Budget period. Those reports came down, as Senator Messner knows that such reports do, with a whole series of options. The choise of those options is left to the Government and the Cabinet. Those reports were documents commissioned by the Cabinet to help the Government make its policy decisions. For that reason I said , as previous Ministers for Social Security and Treasurers have said, that they would remain Cabinet documents. They considered not only the assets test but also the superannuation system, the occupational superannuation system, the pension system generally and the whole area of retirement incomes. They came down with a series of options. It is not my recollection that they made one recommendation over another. That was left to the social policy committee of the Cabinet and to the Cabinet itself. I merely say, as other members of the Cabinet have said, that the Cabinet viewed the facts and the results of that working party and made its decision. It is now up to the Parliament and the community to decide whether those decisions were right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. Can he tell us why the Government took a different decision as a result of the later report on 27 July 1983 from the second group he mentioned in his reply comprising officers of the departments of Social Security, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Veterans' Affairs, which report was received on 11 August this year, about 12 days before the Budget?

—That is a clever question but not a question that particularly worries me. The assumption by Senator Messner is that the first committee recommended differently from the second committee. I made it perfectly clear in my first answer that the first committee, which sat from about 30 March to 1 May, considered the areas of retirement policy and occupational superannuation and came down with a description of what was happening in those areas and, in some cases, with certain options which may be performed in those areas. Following meetings of the expenditure review committee of Cabinet, it was the Cabinet which made the decisions and which is responsible for the decisions. I remind the good senator that we came into government in early March and that the economic statement was at the end of May. We first considered the whole retirement policy at that time and further considered it after that time in the lead up to the Budget decisions . In all that time the social policy committee of Cabinet and the Cabinet itself considered the various options for decisions to be made in the Budget which, I point out again, should be seen in the context of the Budget and the May statement. Those decisions were made as a result of the deliberations of the Cabinet. It was assisted by working parties of the various departments, working parties from within my Department and working parties from within Senator Messner's old department, the Department of Veterans' Affairs. To suggest, as Senator Messner did, that the first working party came down with one recommendation and the second working party came down with another is wrong. To suggest that we made a decision in May not to introduce an assets test and that we made a decision in August to introduce an assets test is quite misleading. It was a consideration over all the time from March to August as, I point out, it was a consideration of the previous Government for several years.

—The Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) has not addressed himself to the question. My question is: Why did the Government make the decision along the lines that it did in such a short time immediately preceding the Budget? I point out again that it was only 12 days from the time in which the second report was received until the Budget was handed down in the Parliament on 23 August.
—If Senator Messner believes that the Government's decision was made on, I think he said 11 August, without any previous consideration, he is wrong.
—You have told us that the report was received that day.

—Just a minute, senator. I have also told the honourable senator that we considered the various decisions from the time we came into government, from the end of March when we had organised our departments and set up the various working parties until the Budget. To suggest that we suddenly upped on 11, 12 or 13 August, or whatever date is suggested, and said 'Whacko, we will introduce an assets test because someone has suggested it' is quite wrong. It was under consideration by the expenditure review committee and Cabinet for a considerable time before that. I cannot tell the honourable senator for how many weeks it was considered, but it was certainly always an option from the time the first committee was set up on 30 March. To imply that there is some temporal relationship between that report being made on 11 September and the decision being made just as a result of that report is nonsense. That is not the way that government works, and Senator Messner knows that is not the way that government works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am greatly concerned about this matter. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has told us that he had the matter in mind as early as the mini-Budget in May. In fact, having rejected one report from the special committee set up to investigate this matter the Government did, in fact, have in mind all along that it would introduce as assets test and did not take the people into its confidence. In fact, I recall that the Government went through a softening-up process in the public arena during June and July in order to get people used to the idea that an assets test would be introduced. I recall very clearly the statements made by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) at various Returned Services League conferences when he spoke of millionair service pensioners and people of that kind who were apparently ripping off the system. We do not have to go into the argument about how misinformed that information was because, in fact, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs claimed that he would name those people. He would not come into this Parliament and name them. Why, I do not know. He claimed that he had all the courage of his convictions, but he failed to name them.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister for Social Security has further information about this matter I believe that the only way he can possibly clear it up is for him to provide this Parliament with the reports which I have asked him for continually and which I have sought under the Freedom of Information Act from the head of his Department . The head of his Department has refused to give them to me, no doubt under the direction of the Minister. I ask him now to table those reports so that we can get a clear impression of exactly what the Government's intention was when it considered its retirement income policy.

I make this point because I believe that it is terribly important for Australians to understand that, at no stage in the evidence brought forward to this Parliament or in the public arena has this Government given us a comprehensive policy statement about retirement income. The only way it can clear that doubt in people's minds is to bring forward those reports and make them public. The Minister has refused to do that. He has also now given us the most disturbing information that in fact the Government contemplated the introduction of an assets test as early as possibly March or April of this financial year and, for its own reasons, sought not to do so in the 19 May statement. It seems to me that the Government has not taken the people into its confidence. It has gone through this process of softening us up, of trying to determine where the weak points in this issue lie before it brought in the legislation. This is a totally cynical political exercise on the part of the Minister no doubt in order to achieve the end of an assets test. I want to know why. What official advice was given to the Minister? Why did his Government refuse to introduce the legislation in May and seek to do it at a later time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to answer some of the most outrageous statements I have heard in what are usually very placid affairs; that is, the Estimates in this place. First of all, for Senator Messner to suggest that the Director-General of the Department of Social Security refused his ridiculous request for Cabinet documents under the Freedom of Information Act under my direction is outrageous and he knows it is outrageous. He does not know and he should know as a former Minister of the Crown in this place that that is the function of the Director-General. I did not direct the Director-General to do so. He did what was quite clearly properly his duty as Director-General of the Department of Social Security. If Senator Messner wants to cast reflections on the Director-General of Social Security or me, I do not care, but he should not do it in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, he says that the Minister and I have admitted that we rejected one report and then accepted another. I have clearly pointed out that we did not reject one report. Always, in any comprehensive survey of retirement policy in this country an assets test is an option. I ask Senator Chaney, the former Minister for Social Security, whether he will not admit that when he was a Minister an assets test was always an option and was an option considered by his Government and by his Cabinet. It always is an option and it is always one of the options that one will consider. If we do not make a comprehensive review of the possibilities and if we do not examine all the possibilities, we are in fact not doing our duty as a government or as Ministers.

I find the most extraordinary statement is that of the shadow Minister, Senator Messner, who came in here and said that this Government has not put before this Parliament a comprehensive retirement policy. I think that is an extraordinary statement from someone who is now shadow Minister for Social Security in a party which has just been in government for seven years. He got up in this place and said: 'We have no comprehensive retirement policy. We are developing a comprehensive retirement policy'. He then comes in here and gets the Senate to set up a committee to develop that policy for him. The problem is that we have a comprehensive retirement policy. We did consider all the options. Amongst those options obviously was an assets test. If the honourable senator is saying that the previous Government did not consider it at all, ever, I suggest he never made a comprehensive examination of the retirement policy in this country. But all I can say is that in my time as shadow Minister I was approached by members of the then Government as to whether it would not be an idea to reintroduce an assets test. I would be very surprised if any of those senators would get up in this place now and say that it was never considered by the previous Government or the previous Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Committee that it is considering divisions 560 and 561 of the Department of Social Security. We have drifted into a debate on policy past and present. I ask that any honourable senators who wish to participate in the debate to tie their comments to the matter under discussion; that is, those divisions under Social Security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I will of course abide by your ruling. It does in fact fit in with the matters I wish to raise. I wish to respond in part to the invitation issued by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). I want to do so in the context of some inquiry of the Minister about the actual financial results of the measures taken by the Government to date to have a more needs based welfare system. One aspect of that change of policy by the Government is of course the intiial move which was made to restrict the income test-free pension for the over-70s. That was done by means of the Government introducing a new and separate income test for the over-70s. It is an income test which is of course more generous in its provisions than the income test which applies generally.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some discussion in the Senate itself about the effect of the new forms which have been sent out by the Department asking those people who are in receipt of the income test-free pension to advise the Department of their income position. It is my understanding from the Minister that one effect of those forms has been to show up a group of recipients of the over-70s income test-free pension who in fact are entitled to a larger pension than they have been receiving. In other words, their actual income has been at a level which meant that they have received a higher income tested pension than the income test-free pension they had been receiving. If that is the case, I ask the Minister to indicate to the Committee whether he can tell us what additional annual expenditure is involved in the payment of the increased pensions which are payable because of the change which the Government has introduced.

To avoid the Minister having to repeat the comments which he made at an earlier time when we were sitting as the Senate I am not for a moment suggesting that those pensioners who receive an increased income should not have received it. Of course they should if their income was low. But the fact of the matter is that the Minister has told us that it is not a matter of total savings through introducing this new scheme. It has uncovered a group of people whose entitlements are in fact larger. I would be interested to know whether the Minister or his Department are yet in a position to tell us what the additional order of expenditure is because of those increases. I would also be interested to know whether the Minister or his advisers can tell us what is the additional cost which has been incurred by the imposition of the income test in these circumstances. Can the Minister give us any more up to date figures of the cost of administration of the new means test which is being introduced under the August Budget? Once again, Mr Temporary Chairman, it is not a matter of there being total net savings. There are some administrative costs. It is very expensive in manpower. It is quite complicated and of course one of the disadvantages of the means test which is being introduced is that it is administratively cumbersome and intrusive, as all means and income tests are, and it will involve the aged people concerned in a greater amount of paper work in many cases and in the disclosure of more of their affairs.

That brings me to the point that the Minister raised in his comments. Of course , when I was Minister for Social Security, I obtained advice not once but many times on the possible areas for savings. Clearly, if one is trying to administer a fixed Budget, one wishes to see what is the most effective way to expend those moneys. As I recall the advice which was consistently given to me by the Department, it was possible to make savings of, I think-this is the figure which sticks in my mind-something like $170m by reverting to something like the 1976 means test. But it is also my recollection that the Department was never in favour of that. It never advised that I should make that recommendation to the Government because of the administrative difficulties and for the sorts of reasons, I guess, which led to the switch from the means to the income test in 1976.

While Senator Grimes will know of my broad and general sympathy, which I have often stated, for needs-based welfare with a view to looking after the needy better, I have to say in response to his question that I never put to the Government the proposition that we should go back to the means test. On the balance of the views which were put to me it seemed to me that it involved more negatives than positives and that, unless it was part of a broader reorganisation of the social security, superannuation and so on system, it simply was not a step to be taken. I simply say that during my term of office no proposition was put to the Cabinet that I can recall-I am sure that I would recall putting such a proposition if I did so-suggesting that the Government should reimpose a means test, hence it was not before the Government for consideration during that period. So Senator Grimes is incorrect in his reference to that matter.

There is a significant question to be raised here which I think is important in terms of our ability to judge the advantage to be gained by imposing additional administrative burdens not just on the Department which, after all, simply has to employ more staff to carry that burden, but on the aged of Australia. I think it is important that we get as clear as possible an idea of the net benefits to revenue because, of course, those net benefits are the reason for imposing the test and are the advantage which is supposed to cancel out the disadvantages which of necessity flow from the imposition of any form of direct mechanism.

I wish to raise a related matter during the Committee consideration of these estimates. As I understand it the Department sent out to persons who were receiving the income test free pension a quite detailed form asking them to advise of their income and assets. I looked fairly quickly at one form. It seemed to me that the forms, as so many of our forms are-I concede that this was the case under our Administration also-were quite complicated. They required people to get together much information and were potentially confusing for people who were not used to filling in a number of forms. I do not know the exact wording of the form but it was made a bit simpler in that people whose income was such that they would not get a pension were required just to send it back with a line through it, which would tell the Department that they could be taken off the roll. I think that was a sensible administrative arrangement and I do not quarrel with it. I am a bit curious, though, about the form of letter which went out to those pensioners who either just ran a line through the form or did not fill in the form at all. Of course, some would have seen that as a solution to their problem. I think the correspondence from the Department indicated that people might do that, but obviously a person who did so would be likely to lose his pension.

I do not know whether the Minister has those forms with him. If he does not, I think it would be helpful to the Parliament and to the Committee if we could see -first the initial form which asked for the statement of income and assets and then the form-I assume that the same forms would have been used throughout Australia-which was subsequently sent to people who until recently were in receipt of the income test free pension, which is no longer available.

I have raised a series of matters. I hope that the Minister, either now or shortly, can give us the best available figures on the cost of introducing these new arrangements and hence the net benefit which at this stage it is thought will accrue from this year on an annual basis from the changes which the Government has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chaney for his intervention. I think it was a useful one because it put the matter into perspective. Quite clearly, amongst the option that he considered as a Minister for Social Security, even if it did not get to the Cabinet stage, was the reintroduction of an assets test. I agree with that. Any Minister for Social Security or anyone looking at the retirement system in this country would be obliged to consider the reintroduction of that assets test if considering a reorganisation of the system. This is particularly so in view of the fact that when the assets test was removed in 1976, it was considered to be a no-cost option and ended up in the first year costing something like $70m.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney is also correct when he says one would probably be unwise to consider the reintroduction of the assets test unless it were done as part of a broader reorganisation of the retirement systems and retirement incomes in this country. I think these were his words. That is exactly what the present Government is doing. We looked at the systems. We looked first of all at the fact that we have an increasingly aging population. We looked at the fact that in future the number of taxpayers to support the number of people on benefits and pensions in general would be decreasing. We looked at the fact that since 1976, when the assets test was removed, there was a great burgeoning of contrivance schemes to get around the income test and that was aggravated further by the abolition of probate and gift duty. We looked at the fact that on the Treasury estimates some $2,600m was removed from the system as part of the revenue forgone for concessions made available to those in the superannuation system and in particular those in a lump sum superannuation system. We looked at the fact that the number of people receiving the age pension had risen from 71 per cent of the age population to, I think, 87 per cent of the relevant age population. I cannot be held to those figures exactly. From 1971 to 1981 the number of persons receiving the age pension had increased from 71 per cent to 87 per cent.

Quite clearly, what was facing us, and what was facing the previous Government, was the fact that we were going to have this increasing number of people on age pensions and pensions generally because also, at the same time, single pensions were going up and for a while invalid pensions were going up. We had an increasing number of people on unemployment benefit. We were facing the fact that those people on those pensions and benefits who had no extra income, no extra assets, no extra capacity to supplement their income, were suffering, because no government, be it Labor or Liberal, was in a position to increase the base rate of pensions to those people if we had this continual drain on the Budget and this continual difficulty in funding these income support payments over that time.

So we did take a broad look at the situation and that is why we initially changed the taxation arrangements for lump sum superannuation. That is why we also, in the May statement, reintroduced an income test. However, it was a more generous income test for those on the over-70 frozen rate pension. That is why we later on came to the conclusion that we needed an assets test. That is why we will need a review of the various superannuation schemes in this country-so that we can produce a system whereby we have a national contributory superannuation scheme under which we can encourage in the private system the payment of weekly superannuation payments or annuities rather than the increasing concentration on lump sums with their special tax concessions. That is why we did this in the context of all those other changes. It is quite wrong to take the reintroduction of the assets test as a matter in isolation. I think that is recognised by all people who think about the system.

Of course we considered the assets test as Senator Chaney and any Minister for Social Security must have considered the assets test. Probably the tragedy was that the Government and the Cabinet at the time when Senator Chaney was Minister did not consider it in the context of all the other changes. To suggest that in considering it we should have made a public announcement on 30 March that we were going to consider the assets test and all the other things we considered is nonsense, and Senator Messner knows it is nonsense. In this game one does not walk around the place thinking aloud, and we never have, although I would have thought that the speech I made at the National Economic Summit Conference was pretty close to that and, as it happened, certain things arose out of it.

Senator Chaney talked about the administrative costs of the assets test and the net benefits. I believe it was estimated that initially, in the first year while we established the assets test, we would need some $20m. In later years, once the system is established and the early assessments are checked, I think the figure will come down to something like $3m. But, again, I will see whether I can get that information from the Department in the near future. I thought we answered all those questions at the Estimates committee hearing. The estimates of the amount of money gained in the Department of Social Security are not easy to determine. Since 1976, when the assets test was removed, we have not had exact information on the assets holdings of pensioners. But we do know that there has been a great burgeoning of schemes. Anyone who reads the Australian Financial Review, the National Times, Prime Time, the Australian Pensioner or any of the other pensioner organisation papers will know how such schemes have burgeoned in this country. Those people do not put in those advertisements for nothing. I think the estimate for the Department of Social Security-I stand to be corrected-is in the range of $150m to $200m, but I am not sure. My advisers can check on that.

In the area of service pensions, Senator Gietzelt's Department of Veterans' Affairs, because of the relative affluence of that group of pensioners compared with others-I am not saying they are affluent-the estimate is in fact relatively considerably higher. Senator Gietzelt would have to get the figures. We are talking of a figure in the range of $100m to $200m initially. But the simple fact of the matter is that if we continue with the present system and allow people to take lump sums at such great concessions, and continue to allow the various contrivance schemes to increase, the burden on the taxpayer will increase more and more. Someone had to bit the bullet and we have done so.

In relation to the re-introduction of the income test for those over 70, the estimated saving, again from recollection, is $170m. The first pay day which involves the reintroduction of that income test is tomorrow so we have no exact figures. I believe that in answer to a question I remarked that one of the things that had happened in the Department since it has been doing the review of the over 70s pension is that it found a group of people-one receives sporadic reports from all over the country-who have been receiving less than their entitlement. I have asked the Department to tell me exactly how many people there are and the cost involved. But because the test has only just been introduced and, as I have said, the first pay day is not until tomorrow, I do not have the exact figure. The staffing increase involved in introducing the over 70s income test is estimated to be 55 persons in 1983-84. That cost, considering most salary levels, will be approximately $1m in a full year. I suggest that that is not a very high cost. I suggest that in that area, as in other areas, the Department of Social Security is demonstrating that its administrative costs, when compared with the amount of money it handles, are very low. I, like Senator Chaney, certainly am keen to find out just how many people are in that unusual position of receiving less than their entitlement and to see how that will affect the revenue, but I do not think the effect will be great.

The review forms were sent out. People were told, very sensibly, that if their income was so high that clearly they were not able to receive a pension they could send back the form with the line through it, as Senator Chaney said. I am not sure whether that method was used but that was the idea, as I recall it. Of course, some people do not send back the forms and other people cannot be contacted. For all sorts of reasons people do not send back their forms. They may have moved and some people may even be dead. In recent weeks the Department in all the States has concentrated on trying to contact those people who did not send the forms back. As well as wanting to apply the over-70s income test we want to make sure that there are not large numbers of people who in fact are not receiving their entitlement. The results of that campaign to make sure that people are getting their entitlements, to make sure that people do get their forms back, will be available in a few weeks. I hope to be in a position to let the Senate know the results. I remind the honourable senators that the test has only just been introduced.

I share Senator Chaney's concern-it is the concern of anyone involved in social security-that of course any means test or any income test involves asking people about their income, their assets and involves people filling out forms. But the only alternative is a universal system of payment. Any universal system of payment of this type of necessity involves those payments being taxable. If the Department of Social Security did not seek information through forms and did not seek information from people to determine a means test the Taxation Office would do so. It is six of one and half a dozen of the other as to which way it should be done. As it happens, since 1908 this country has gone down the path of means tested payments in the case of age pensions, widows pensions and invalid pensions. I do not believe, in comparing that system with those operating overseas, that it is in fact a bad path to follow. Those countries that have a universal system and pay a means test free pension inevitably have stuck on top of the pension supplementary pensions or supplementary assistance with a means test harsher and more intrusive than any means test that has ever been introduced in this country. Also, those countries which have a means test free pension in fact have as a base rate of pension a pension which is lower than the sort of rates of pension that we are able to pay in this country.

Finally, it seems to me that the best compromise is in fact the introduction of a contributory scheme, a national superannuation scheme or a pension plan as it is called in Canada. It is in that direction I believe we are moving and it is in that direction that I believe both of the larger political parties in this country have wanted to move for a long time. The simple fact of the matter is that we cannot go down that path unless we do something about the privileged position of those who are getting lump sum superannuation payments and those who are in the privileged position of having access to superannuation in the first place. We cannot go down that path while we have a means test which is as inequitable as the means test in place now. It is for that reason that this Government has bitten the bullet and introduced the sorts of changes it has made to the retirement scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) for the additional information he has given and for the promise of further information soon when the new scheme has been in operation for a while. I note that he said that further information will be provided to the Senate. I gather it will be provided during this session , that is, before the end of this year.
—If I get it.

—I understand it will be provided if those figures are available. I think it would be of great interest to the Senate and indeed to the Australian public to know just how these figures fall out as against the estimates which, I agree, are difficult to make because of the lack of information we have about the asset position of many Australians. I think that the Minister has been a little kind to himself in his summary. I want to make some comment on the Minister's remarks about the introduction of these three new imposts or tests into the system-the restriction of the over-70s income test free pension, the new means test on pensions and the 30 per cent tax on superannuation. The Minister referred to them as part of an overall plan. He claimed to be living up to the sort of suggestion that I was making in my comments. I think he is patting himself on the back a little unnecessarily. I think there is a degree of illogicality in that combination of measures.
—No one else will pat me on the back.

—I note that the Minister said that no one else will; I agree with that. The fact is that there is a lack of coherence in those measures which does cause the Opposition and, I think, a lot of people who are worried about retirement incomes some concern. I go back to the May package to which the Minister referred-I think I can properly describe it as the contentious measure- namely, the introduction of a much higher level of tax on lump sum payments. I understood at that time that this was because the Government was concerned with a problem which is broadly described as double dipping. The Government was saying: 'You are getting a tax assisted advantage through your lump sum and you are able to invest that in a way which does not attract the operation of the income test. It is really important that, in order to stop people getting two bites at the cherry, two serves from the taxpayer, we should introduce this tax on lump sum superannuation payments'. Of course the imposition of a means test does cover that point. If one does it in a logical, coherent, thought out way, it does seem rather difficult to see why on the one hand one would introduce a tax on lump sum superannuation, which is meant to avoid double dipping, and then some months later introduce a means test which means that any lump sum would be taken into account in determining whether or not one would receive a pension and , if so, how much.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the Minister I want to say that part of the concern of the Opposition is that there is not a sense of coherence in those three measures, each one of which can perhaps be justified in an argument about its standing by itself on the basis that the Minister has put before the Committee tonight. Yet when one puts them together one finds a lack of logic in the way they fit. I have to say-I think I speak very much on behalf of all Opposition members on this matter-that we would want to see a much more successful attempt than the Government has made so far to introduce a logical and coherent approach in this area.

If one looks at what the Government said when it was in opposition as against what it is saying now, and if one even looks at what Senator Button is saying now against what the Government is doing, one sees that the means test has been introduced for the aged. That effectively is a form of tax. We have all agreed that the question of tax and the withdrawal of grants from social security through the income test are things which need to be considered together. The fact is that the Government has seen fit to introduce a means test on the aged. It has not seen fit to introduce a capital gains tax on the non-aged. Again I think this suggests that the Government lacks a logical and coherent approach in these areas. I do not believe that it is appropriate for the Minister to respond to my general comment that all of this needs to be dealt with in a full way by saying: 'Look what we have done. We have taken these three measures'. I think that even Senator Button, within the privacy of Caucus and the Cabinet and in the near privacy that we enjoy in this chamber, which seems to attract less attention than the other chamber, would argue that a capital gains tax represents a logical part of any package where one is looking to the capital assets of the aged and where one is looking to the general income security situation of the whole community.

TALK.START.PARA: —No worries about that.

—I am glad to hear the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, saying 'No worries about that'. It is consistent with what he said to us at Question Time. I think it does point up the lack of a coherent and logical approach by this Government in that it is prepared to look at the capital of the aged but not at the capital of the rest of the community. I am also very concerned about something that the Minister, Senator Grimes, said. He said that one does not go around talking about these things. One of the things that this Government talked about a great deal before the last election was that it would consult more in formulating and implementing its policies. Let us look at what the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, is doing. He is being terribly careful before he imposes a new tax on the mining industry. He is issuing discussion papers-he has even made them available to the Opposition-and he is talking to the mining industry. He said publicly in this place that he feels that it would be a good thing if everybody had a chance to contribute to a successful outcome. I say to the Minister for Social Security: 'If it is good enough to have a new resources tax for the mining industry I would have thought it is good enough to have the same sort of consultation with the aged of Australia through their many representative organisations'.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a case of the Government simply not living up to its rhetoric concerning the aged. It is certainly not consulting before it chooses to move, whereas in other areas, including other areas of taxation, it seems to see its way clear to do so. I add a couple of questions to those that I have asked already about the actual financial benefits which supposedly will flow from these measures. What procedures has the Minister maintained, if any, within his Department to comply with what I understand to be the general policy of the Government to have a high degree of consultation with those people who are affected? I do not know whether he has maintained the State and Commonwealth consultative mechanisms, and it would be helpful if he were to tell the Committee what formal consultative arrangements he maintains to ensure that people in the community, particularly those who are affected, have an opportunity to contribute to policy making in this very important area.

I would be interested also to know specifically the extent to which the Minister has involved himself directly in that consultation process. I am sure that the present Minister, like any Minister for Social Security, has endless requests for meetings and I am sure that he attends many meetings; but he would know, I think, that I am interested in the formal consultative arrangements which enable the representatives of the aged, in particular, to ensure that their views are well known to him and to the Department before important decisions of the sort which the Government has been taking, decisions which seem to have shaken at least part of the aged community in Australia, are made. I suppose that we would all like to know to what extent the aged have been enabled to consult with his Government through their organisations and through the mechanisms which were in place previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall deal first with what Senator Chaney described as the logic of the situation. He described the introduction of the changes to lump sum superannuation and the assets test for the over-70s as apparently illogical. In passing, I refer to the Opposition's attitude. The first thing that happened was that in May we announced our intention of introducing the changed treatment of the lump sum superannuation payment. What was the Opposition's attitude? The Opposition immediately opposed it. It said it was 'an outrageous imposition' on those who were at that time getting tax concessions of some $2,600m from the public taxpayers. It also said: 'Under no circumstances should this ever be introduced and on returning to government--
—You are over-acting.

—No. I am talking about Senator Messner and his leader. The Opposition said that on returning to government it would immediately repeal the legislation, legislation which at that stage it had never seen.

SPEECH.PARA: The next thing that happened was that we introduced an over-70s means test, an income test which is much more generous than the income test for those aged between 65 and 70. The previous Government's approach was immediately to freeze the over-70s pension and to impose a means test on increases without any consultation with any pensioner groups. Despite the fact that the Opposition said that it would not do this, when in government it introduced that measure in a Budget. We introduced such a measure in May, and immediately the Opposition's reply was: 'This is outrageous. This should never have been done. It is a terrible thing to do. We will not have a bar of it. We will oppose it'. When it came to the Parliament, the Opposition opposed it. Along came the intention to introduce an assets test, the Opposition's attitude was: 'We will oppose it and, on returning to government, we shall repeal it'.

Senator Chaney talked about logic. One has great difficulty in finding any logic in the Opposition's attitude apart from the logic which states: 'We are in opposition; therefore we must oppose everything that the Government does'. The superannuation changes were introduced in May because, as was well known in this community, 40 per cent of the work force had access to superannuation, and of those 40 per cent, 60 per cent received lump sum superannuation payments, and the percentage was increasing. Taxation was applicable to only 5 per cent of that lump sum superannuation. That was clearly an unfair taxation system when one considered that the people concerned could then put that lump sum into a contrived scheme and so manipulate it as to get the full pension and full fringe benefits, whereas those who were receiving weekly superannuation payments, the other 40 per cent of those who had access to superannuation, had those payments included in the income test and therefore they were completely taxable. That was clearly an unfair situation. That group of people had a great advantage over the rest of the community. As part of that advantage they were able to double dip, as Senator Chaney says.

Of course, the people who had the capacity to double dip were not only those receiving lump sum superannuation payments. They were people who through all sorts of other methods had large asset holdings which they were able to manipulate in contrived schemes to avoid the income test. Advertisements appeared from Australian Fixed Trusts Ltd and so on saying: 'Put your assets into our trust. Even though you are a millionaire you will be able to get a full pension and a full fringe benefit'. The advertisements were as blatant as that. Quite clearly we knew that at the time and we said that this was a correction of an unfair taxation system and that as a side effect it eliminated the advantage of some people double dipping. However, to stop double dipping completely we had to introduce an assets test. In introducing the more generous income test for the over-70s we were facing up to the reality that large numbers of people-$170m -worth of people-were receiving some $51.40 a week which could well have gone elsewhere.

That is a comprehensive policy, and it is part of a comprehensive policy which will continue. What is not logical is for the Opposition to come into this chamber and every time something is announced say, without giving any alternative: 'We will oppose it; we will repeal it'. There is no logic in that sort of situation and there was no logic in it. As for the consultation methods, I will try to remember them all for Senator Chaney. As Senator Chaney knows, there are various State consultative committees on social security. They are retained. The re-appointments and the new appointments will be announced in the next few weeks. We will retain the National Consultative Committee on Social Welfare. It will have a different composition from the one which Senator Chaney appointed, but it will remain and it will be broadly representative of people in the community.
