We have the Disability Advisory Council of Australia, which replaced the National Advisory Council for the Handicapped, the difference being that it is now largely composed of disabled people. It has met regularly; it is working very efficiently. We have had a series of consultations, one with the various consultative committees on the best method of setting up communications between them and the Department, and one on children's services. Specifically in regard to the assets test, I have met with State pensioner organisations in, I think, every State except Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Budget?

—Yes. I have met with the Australian Pensioners Federation. I have met with the retired superannuees. I have met with the Australian Council on the Ageing, both the national body and the New South Wales body, and have had regular consultations with them. The Australian Council for the Ageing, which in fact is in favour of the introduction of the assets test, has established a committee which will look at what it considers to be anomalies in the assets test and will consult with government, both before and after the legislation is introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Budget we announced our intention to introduce the assets test and we announced that we were going to consult with the pensioner organisations between that time and the time the legislation was introduced. We also informed people, and this is obvious to everyone, that for a year after the assets test is introduced there will be a further period for consultation. I believe that the consultations and discussions we have had, including a meeting I had in the Sydney Town Hall which followed the one Senator Chaney had the year before and the one Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle had a couple of years before that, are important in formulating-

TALK.START.PARA: —Show us your scars.

—Oh, it is good stuff. They are important in formulating policy and in being able to discuss policy. In fact, we have had discussions with these various organisations and will continue to enter into such discussions for the next 12 months after the legislation comes in. We have done so since the Budget. I do not know of any occasion when the previous Government proceeded along that path.
—We did not do what you have done.

—The difficulty, senator, is that if we did what the Fraser Government did and marched into the Parliament and said 'Boom! We are introducing this' we would get continuous complaints about the fact that we had not consulted and that no one knew it was going to happen, et cetera. If we did what we did and announced that we intended to do this but intended to refine it in consultation with the various groups, we would get complaints from the Opposition that we were causing confusion and spending too much time talking. I know that we cannot win in this situation, but at least I know that, in discussing with the various pensioner organisations and with the various ex- servicemen's organisations-Senator Messner will be surprised when he sees some of the responses we got from them-we reached a situation of mutual understanding .

SPEECH.PARA: I said in this place: 'We are willing to discuss with anyone, political parties or anyone else, the sorts of difficulties and problems that may arise and the anomalies that they think may arise. We intend to introduce an assets test, but we are willing to discuss the details and difficulties that may arise'. As far as I am concerned, the only two groups that have not been willing to make a contribution, apart from narking and nitpicking, have been the Liberal Party of Australian and the National Party of Australia. I think that is a great pity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to the last remarks of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes). He said that there had been no contribution from the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia. That is obvious nonsense. There has been a great deal of consultation in this place, in the place where these debates should be held and where the issues can be exposed for public view. It is pretty obvious that the Minister has no intention of letting these issues come out in public. For the very reason that I enunciated before, he will not release important documents that were the basis of his decision. The reason is clearly that they are contradictory. They do not show clearly to him or to the rest of the people of Australia what this Government's intention was when it first sat down to talk about retirement policy back in May. He knows that those reports will not support the actions taken since 19 May, or before for that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one point in respect of that matter because the Minister made some play of the fact that indeed it is not for a government to go around and parade itself and talk aloud in the public arena about what it intends to do. That seems to be remarkably contradictory of previous discussions. He also made the point that probably back in March, or as early as a few days after the date on which the Government was elected, the Australian Labor Party Government had been discussing this issue. He said that it has been accepting things; rejecting things and trying to make up its mind what it would do. What it ended up doing was causing enormous confusion to the people of Australia.

The point about this matter is that he said it was nonsense that the issue should have been considered in those early days and that the Government should have had time to consider all these things. He said: 'Well, you know, we as ordinary Australians ought not to concern ourselves so long as the Government does not say something'. The people of Australia on 14 April were led to believe by a firm statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that there would be no tax on lump sum superannuation payments. That was on 14 April, a few days before the National Economic Summit Conference. Yet on 19 May the mini-Budget came down.

TALK.START.PARA: —What line are you on?

—If Senator Georges wants to see the headlines, I will bring them in so that he can see them. The point about this matter is quite clearly that the word of the Government cannot be relied upon. We need this basic information so that we can clear up once and for all the matter of the Government's intentions. The real point is this: Throughout all the nonsense that has been going on in this area since the middle of May, we have yet to find out what the Government's real long term purposes are. It talks about a national superannuation scheme as being its objective. When has the Minister informed us in this place about the Government's intentions in that regard? Does it intend to introduce a national superannuation scheme next year? Can we have an answer to that question? Does it intend to introduce such a measure in a mini-Budget half-way through the current financial year? Can we have an answer to that question? When does it intend to introduce a national superannuation scheme?

SPEECH.PARA: I make that point because it is important to recognise that this Government has sought in its own mind to make plain to the people of Australia that such measures are part of some grand plan for the introduction of an all-encompassing superannuation scheme. Yet as my colleague Senator Chaney has pointed out, the moves that have been made so far are full of contradictions. We instanced the introduction of the tax on lump sums, followed by an assets test which is achieving the same purpose, which is designed to cut out double dipping, which the Minister claimed was the objective of that legislation. It obviously created more anomalies in the process.

I ask the Minister whether he really sits down in the quiet of his own room at night-preferably with the light off, so that he does not need to look in a mirror-and thinks about this matter, thinks about the confusion that he is creating in Australia amongst the people who are really concerned about pensions . It is pretty clear that the Minister is one of those people who really do not have control of the situation. He claims that he is on the way to achieving a long term goal with regard to national superannuation. I want to see what that goal is, and so do the rest of the people of Australia. We want to know when it will be introduced and what the Government's long term policy is in that regard.

Let us look at one or two other points. The Minister made great play of the fact that the former Government had considered, in the course of its period in office, the introduction of an assets test. My colleague Senator Chaney, the former Minister, made the point quite clear that the former Government had never considered in Cabinet the introduction of an assets test. That surely makes the point. The reason is, of course, that all of the issues that have been raised through the departmental and advisory processes within the Department and outside of it, clearly did not hold water. The matter reached short of ministerial level, and remained without the imprimatur of the Government. Why is it that this Government sees some virtue in something that would not have gained the support of the Department of Social Security under the former Government? We need to know the answer to that question.

Again, I draw the Minister's attention to the point that he could really put our minds at rest about this question by releasing the information that I asked for earlier, releasing the reports on superannuation, which he absolutely and steadfastly refuses to do-for what reason, one cannot say. He told us that the papers are full of options that the Government may or may not have considered. If that is the case, why can he not bring us into his confidence? Why cannot the Parliament be made aware of these issues? He knows that a Senate committee has been established to examine these very important issues. Is he waiting-I give him the benefit of the doubt on this point-so that he can surprise us all be giving these reports to the Committee so that we can undertake an examination of them, or is he just determined on his course of being steadfastly opposed to releasing any information at all? It does not sit well that the Minister who, when in opposition, sought to make his position clear about freedom of information, refuses to release this kind of information. I ask the Minister once again whether he will do so.

Several other points need to be brought out in the course of this debate. Several issues in this area have not yet been touched upon. I ask again how the Government intends to address itself to the assets test when it is applied to various assets that vary in value from time to time. The Minister sought to reply to us earlier in respect of the value of shares that are held at some particular time. He told us how they were to be valued, but he failed to tell us what effect they would have on the assets and the capital of pensioners if they had an average yield of 3 or 4 per cent but a return of the order of 10 per cent , the figure to be taken into account for the purposes of the assets test. Why is this? What impact will this have on people receiving pensions? Will they be entitled to receive more income by way of a pension, rather than less, as would be the Minister's intention? In fact, will it not also have the reverse effect if people have money invested at, for example, 15 per cent on mortgage, something far in excess of the 10 per cent notional rate? As a result of the Minister's assets test those people would in fact be drawing more in pension.

Do not both those examples indicate that there would be an increased drawing of pensions as the result of the application of the assets test? How can the Minister tell us that the assets test is aimed at assisting the most needy when it will obviously assist those who have their assets invested in such a way as, in the second case, to maximise their return and, in the first case, to maximise their potential for hedging against inflation affecting their future retirement income? I ask that question in the light of the answer of the Minister to other questions that have been addressed to him on this matter. How can he demonstrate to us that there will be a saving to revenue as a result of the imposition of the assets test? Surely those factors mean that there will be an increase in the outlays for pensions for people in those categories. I fail to see how the net effect will reduce outlays and ensure, in such a way as the Minister deems important, that the maximum amount of funds reaches the hands of the most needy, which is claimed to be the objective of this Government. If that is so, I would like to hear the Minister's response. I would like to hear a quantification of the amount of money that is expected to be saved in pension payments as a result of the implementation of this measure. Indeed, I would like to hear how it will be used to assist the most needy in the community.

I return to the original point, that is, that the Minister can put our minds at rest by releasing the documents to which he has referred-those documents dealing with this particular decision-making process of the Government, a most convoluted process, as the Minister will acknowledge. The decision was obviously taken in the heat of the moment without full consideration of all the issues. It was taken in such a way as to clearly indicate the Government's real intention in this area. Finally, I ask the Minister when he proposes to introduce his national superannuation scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Tasmania-Minister for Social Security) (10.55)-I have answered some of these questions many times, but I will answer them again. I was shadow Minister for Social Security from 1976. In that time initially I had a staff of one and in the last couple of years, because I was also Deputy Leader of the Opposition, I had a staff of three. In that time we worked very hard to draw up a comprehensive policy on social security. We worked very hard to get to know the social security system. In that time I would have loved to have had made available to me Cabinet documents which were made available to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Chaney. I even would have liked to have had made available to me the reports put out by committees such as those of Mr Spender- although I must admit I did get his report in the end when it fell off the back of a truck-Mr Sainsbury and Mr Hodges. All these committees were not Cabinet committees; they were committees set up by Senator Chaney to assist him in his policy development. I dare say that when Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was the Minister for Social Security there would have been departmental committees and Cabinet committees and all sorts of people who assisted the Government in the development of policy and who gave advice to the Government when it sought information in regard to various matters. In this time I suppose I occasionally did say in Question Time and in Estimates committees hearings: 'How about letting us have these committee reports?' The answer was always no, that they were Cabinet documents or they were working documents for the Minister. Now poor Senator Messner comes along as the shadow Minister for Social Security, having been a supporter of the previous Government for many years and a Minister for a couple of years, knowing how the whole system works, having reaped all this vast knowledge that was available to him from the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which is quite related to the Department of Social Security, having had sitting next to him and sitting in front of him former experienced and well known Ministers for Social Security. He comes into this place and says first of all: ' We have no comprehensive retirement policy. We are going to develop one over the next few months'. Then he comes in and says: 'Look, to assist me to develop this policy I want all your Cabinet documents, I want all your working documents and I want all the advice that you as a Government and the Cabinet have received'. All I can say is that I admire the honourable senator's cheek. I am willing to answer questions in this place. I am willing to debate the matter here and in public. I am willing to go to the Sydney Town Hall and to everywhere else to have it out with various groups. But, for heaven's sake, for Senator Messner to come in here and say: 'We want to develop a good policy which we could not develop over the previous seven years and you have to help us by giving us all these documents and everything else which you have used in your Cabinet discussions', is just a bit too cheeky even for honourable senators on that side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing I wish to say is that we have been discussing for I do not know how long the Appropriation Bills and the estimates examined by Estimates Committee B. Senator Walters has been sitting up there, alternatively champing at the bit and falling asleep, waiting to ask all those questions she has wanted to ask. Essentially, all we have discussed is my refusal to give up Cabinet documents. We have had a bit of philosophical discussion between Senator Chaney and me on where social security should go in the future. The rest of the debate has involved Senator Messner on the assets test, on which we have announced our intent. No legislation has come before the Parliament. The only thing in relation to these tests in these Appropriation Bills is an estimate of the number of people who may be needed if we can get the legislation through to administer the test. Yet Senator Messner gets up here and wants to know details of a test which we have been happily discussing with various pensioner groups. We have been sitting down and formulating policy with all those advisory groups that Senator Messner would like to talk to, groups whose documents Senator Messner would like to get his hands on. We have been discussing the matter with the intention of bringing legislation into this Parliament to apply that assets test so that we can have a full and proper debate. Not only that, I have often to listen to the views of the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not got any.

—The Opposition does not have any positive views. The only view it has is: We are against the asset test and when we get into government in the far distant future we will repeal the legislation that this Governmen brings in, whatever it is. Is it not about time that we got on to dealing with this year's Budget? Is it not about time that we got on to dealing with appropriations which are covered in these documents? Is it not about time that we got away from the narking, the nitpicking and the nonsense Senator Messner is going on about? Is it not about time that Senator Messner went away and became a shadow Minister for Social Security, that he started to dream up some policies and started to get some idea of where his Party in the near future, whenever it is, may go? I inform Senator Messner that we intend to introduce a national superannuation scheme. I have had discussions, as I should, not only in government but also in opposition, with the insurance industry. This community by and large agrees with the introduction of the assets test and the changes to the superannuation and taxation system. I have been discussing with various pensioner groups, I have been discussing with various superannuation groups the introduction of a superannuation scheme, as has my colleague the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), and as have others. When we have finished our discussions we will introduce the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter that I raised on 21 October. It relates to the women's meeting to be held on 7 November. On the occasion I raised the matter previously I put down a number of questions relating to this conference and at the time the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) incorporated a list of participating organisations , which I have now had an opportunity to look at. I included some other questions which have not yet been answered and I have written to Senator Button about them. I think they are matters that really ought to be answered if this meeting that women's organisations are to attend is to be of significance. If it is to be the forerunner of something that replaces the National Women's Advisory Council, I think that more publicity ought to be given to it and women generally ought to have the opportunity to know about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked on that occasion how many delegates would be allowed from each of these groups, how many observers would be allowed and where they might come from, whether or not the list was thought to be representative of women's organisations, whether women affiliated with political parties were to be included, and I asked particularly about the agenda-has it been made public, can it be made public tonight and who has had an opportunity to contribute to the items which will be included on the agenda? I am surprised on reading through the list of participating organisations to see that it includes the National Women's Advisory Council, which in fact was abolished by the Government The reason given for holding this conference of 30 women's organisations in November was that it would replace the National Women's Advisory Council. That, in itself , seems very strange as far as I am concerned and it makes me wonder whether this meeting is merely a patronising gimmick or whether it is a serious endeavour to find out the views of women in the community.

The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Senator Ryan) wrote to the Chairman of the Federal Women's Committee of the Liberal Party of Australia earlier this year. The main part of the letter relates to pre-Budget discussions and explains why they were not being held this year and the purpose of the Economic Planning Advisory Council. It then goes on to state:

In addition to these formal arrangements, the Government intends that informal consultation, including on a bilateral basis, will be greatly increased. The Prime Minister has committed all Ministers to be available to consult with, and to receive representations from, individuals and groups in the community on matters of common interest irrespective of industrial, political or social affiliation. This is a genuine undertaking on behalf of a government which is keen to receive the benefit of the reserves of knowledge and experience of the community at large, and to be of assistance to groups and individuals to the greatest extent possible.
I trust that in the days, weeks, months and years ahead that your organisation will take advantage of that unequivocal offer and statement, and continue to maintain your contact with the Government.

I hope I am not being cynical when I suggest that those words sound a little hollow in view of the fact that that organisation has not been included. One can think of other groups that are not included on the list. As I have said, one organisation has now been abolished. I think it is time the Government told us what is going on. It should publish the agenda, let us know where the meeting is to be held and answer some of the matters I have raised because if it is of importance, if it is worth spending taxpayers' money to hold the meeting, these things need to be addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can respond to some of the specific questions which Senator Reid has asked. The meeting will be held in Parliament House. I am not aware of whether an agenda has been prepared. I will make inquiries about that and inform the Senate and/or Senator Reid as soon as possible. The National Women's Advisory Council will continue for a period of 12 months or thereabouts. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the United States stepping up production of plutonium for military use as was reported in the 29 June 1983 edition of Wise.

(2) Is the United States looking at a plan to re-establish an agreement with Great Britain to trade tritium and highly enriched uranium for Britain's Polaris warheads and nuclear submarine fleet in exchange for plutonium from British Magnox reactors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is not aware of United States' plans in respect of production of plutonium for military use.

(2) Under the United States/United Kingdom Defence Agreement, plutonium from United Kingdom civil reactors was exported to the United States before 1971 in exchange for highly enriched uranium for the United Kingdom defence program. The United States Government has stated that the plutonium was used for civil purposes only. The United Kingdom Government has stated that there have been no subsequent transfers of United Kingdom civil plutonium to the United States under the Agreement. The Australian Government is not aware of any proposal of the kind mentioned, which would be inconsistent with the declared policy of the United Kingdom Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there adequate provisions in the Freedom of Information Act, or other legislation, to deal with witnesses who conceal the existence of documents subject to a Freedom of Information application from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT); if so, what are these existing provisions; if not, will the Attorney-General consider including appropriate provisions in the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill to be considered during the current session.

(2) Will the Attorney-General provide an assurance that prompt and effective action would be taken, in accordance with the pertinent legislation, on any concealment of documents from the AAT by any person or persons concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Freedom of Information Act 1982 and Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 together contain adequate provisions to deal with any case of improper document concealment that comes to light in review proceedings.

Under the AAT Act, a duty is imposed on the person whose decision is to be reviewed to lodge with the AAT every document in his or her possession or control which that person considers relevant to the review (section 37 (1) (b)). The AAT may require any other document it considers may be relevant to be produced (section 37 (2); section 40 (1A)), and any person who fails to do so commits an offence (section 62 (c)). Further, any witness who gives evidence about the existence or whereabouts of a document that to his or her knowledge is false or misleading also commits an offence (section 62A).

The FOI Act (section 64 (1) and (3)) expressly modifies the AAT Act with respect to the production of documents claimed to be exempt or in respect of which a 'conclusive certificate' is in force. These provisions do not limit the capacity of the AAT or the Document Review Tribunal (DRT) in proceedings under the FOI Act effectively to deal with improper document concealment. Even in respect of an exempt document or a document in respect of which a 'conclusive certificate' has been given, there is a reserve power in the AAT or the DRT (as the case may be) to require the document to be produced for inspection by the Tribunal.
It should however be noted that the FOI Act expressly authorises a Minister or agency to withhold information about the existence of a document in certain circumstances. Section 25 of the FOI Act-

(a) provides that nothing in the Act requires information to be given as to the existence or non-existence of a document if that information would prejudice defence, security or international relations, or would adversely affect certain law enforcement functions; and
(b) permits an agency to respond to a request under the FOI Act by notifying the applicant that the existence of a document is neither confirmed nor denied in such a case.

(2) As indicated in (1), adequate machinery exists to deal with improper concealment. Whether or not proceedings in respect of an improper concealment of a document are brought in a particular case depends on the sufficiency of evidence and whether in all the circumstances of the case, prosecution is appropriate. Disciplinary action might also be taken against any officer found to have concealed relevant documents (see, for example, Division 6, Part III, Public Service Act 1922). In recent proceedings before the AAT, the President of the Tribunal has said that any agency which is in doubt whether a document is within the ambit of a request should alert the Tribunal to the existence of the document. My Department is preparing a memorandum to all agencies to draw their attention to the President's remarks.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 6 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How will the royalties from the Jabiru oil well in the Timor Sea be distributed.

(2) Will the Northern Territory receive any royalties; if so, what percentage of the profits will the Territory receive, and under what formula; if no royalties are allocated to the Northern Territory, will it receive any other financial return from the oil find.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All royalties on petroleum production in the Adjacent Area of the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands, within which the Jabiru discovery has been made, will be retained by the Commonwealth-as provided for in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act.

(2) The Northern Territory will not receive royalties from any petroleum production in the area. However, significant economic benefits are expected to accrue to the Northern Territory from the establishment of an operations base for the Jabiru development and related service industries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1983 (Hansard, page 524) Senator Chaney asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice concerning the decline in employment and labour force participation indicated by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) labour force survey for August.

QUESTION.PARA: The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following additional information relating to the honourable senator's question:

The ABS labour force statistics are subject to quite large seasonal variations, and August is a month in which employment normally falls by 30,000-40,000 and the participation rate by around 0.4 per cent. If seasonally adjusted figures are used-as they should be when interpreting short term movements in employment- the apparent decline is not 52,000 but rather 19,500. The statistician also warns in the relevant publications that allowance should be made for sampling error in interpreting the figures. On this basis, the fall is not statistically significant using the accepted statistical test at the 95 per cent confidence level.

Reflecting these considerations, too much emphasis should not be placed on the decrease in employment in August, particularly following the strong gains of the preceding three months. This view is supported by the strong growth in seasonally adjusted employment which occurred in September, to the highest level since November 1982.

The seasonally adjusted participation rate also decreased in August by 0.3 percentage points to 60.3 per cent. This decrease was statistically significant, although it was difficult to interpret given the signs of stability in other labour market indicators. The decline was expected to be reversed as employment gathered strength-an interpretation supported by the large increase in the seasonally adjusted participation rate in September.

The Government has made a commitment to increasing employment in 1983-84 and the Budget was framed with this objective in mind. The impact of our policies are now being reflected in employment levels, which have risen in seasonally adjusted terms in four of the last five months.
